IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 40% of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) cases in the U.S. are due to modifiable lifestyle factors such as hypertension, obesity, physical inactivity, heavy alcohol use, and smoking. Yet, some people have access to environmental opportunities (e.g., fitness centers) that promote healthy behavior engagement, whereas others are constrained by their environments, or engage in health behaviors despite environmental constraints. This project will lead to new knowledge about modifiable health behaviors and environmental opportunities as prevention and intervention targets for promoting healthy cognitive aging in place among minoritized adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing and supporting the “real world” assessment of strategies used to foster adoption of several safe and highly efficacious mechanical ventilation liberation and symptom management practices in healthcare systems that provide care to critically ill adults with known health disparities. We expect study results will impact the field by developing simple, yet effective, ways of accelerating the reliable uptake of evidence-based ICU interventions that will ultimately improve the care and outcomes of millions of critically ill adults annually. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness, disability, and healthcare disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One strategy to expand the donor pool for the escalating numbers of patients who require lung transplants is recovering lungs from donors when deaths occur unexpectedly inside or outside of hospitals. Our study team developed a novel protocol that preserves lungs non-invasively for just over 3 hours after death using positive end expiratory pressure (PEEP) and supplemental oxygen. Non- invasive lung preservation initiated soon after unexpected death could markedly increase lung donation opportunities in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peer suppoRt for adolescents and Emerging adults with Sickle cell pain: promoting ENgagement in Cognitive behavioral thErapy (PRESENCE) will be the first study to compare the effectiveness of a cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) program with and without peer support to usual care as a non-pharmaceutical option for pain management in people living with sickle cell disease. CBT is delivered through an innovative digital app that is accessed on a mobile device with one group receiving self-guided CBT and the other receiving CBT plus peer support. The PRESENCE program is comprised of strong community partnerships that provide the peer support component of the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: CENTRE FOR ADDICTION AND MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will determine whether regular cannabis consumers can effectively self-titrate the THC doses of high- potency cannabis concentrates and characterize the acute subjective, cognitive, physiological and pharmacokinetic effects of a range of THC potencies that have been associated with public health harms, such as cannabis use disorder and accidental injury. This experimental evidence will inform policy decisions on the need to decrease access and/or prevent initiation of high-THC products and implement information or education campaigns to increase awareness on the risks of using high potency products.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Postpartum hemorrhage is a common and significant contributor to maternal morbidity, with many complications arising from acute hypovolemia and end-organ damage from subsequent hypoxia. This project will study a digital health solution using a machine learning-based prediction model to identify those at high risk for hemorrhage and then apply a proactive management algorithm (via a clinical decision support tool) to decrease the prevalence of anemia before delivery. This project will demonstrate how applying prediction models at the point of care in obstetrics can directly address the increasing maternal morbidity and mortality rates, which remain a public health priority.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: An AI-Directed CDS Tool to Reduce Iron Deficiency Anemia in Pregnancy: A Randomized Controlled Trial (AID-IDA Trial)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This Exploratory/Developmental Research Grant proposal seeks to advance the state of the art in diagnostic pediatric retinal imaging by developing a novel, auto-aligning hand-held optical coherence tomography and optical coherence tomography angiography probe capable of routine and repeatable high- quality imaging of infants and children. This probe will find application for diagnostic assessment of pediatric retinal diseases such as retinopathy of prematurity, a leading cause of childhood blindness in the US and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Laser scanning microscopy is the standard technique for imaging at depth in thick, scattering tissue. However, further scaling of imaging performance is limited by tissue heating. To circumvent this limit, this project seeks to develop new detection modalities based on nonlinear amplification in optical fibers to improve signal-to-noise ratio, imaging speed, and depth penetration for common techniques including optical coherence tomography, confocal, and multiphoton microscopy; thereby representing a new scaling axis for information capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral mucositis and bloodstream infections remain as a serious complication in hematopoietic cell transplant (HCT) recipients. The focus of this project is to understand the oral microbial community changes during the development and progression of OM and BSI in HCT recipients, and to define the bloodstream microbial profile in this cohort to determine if the oral cavity is the likely source of bloodstream infections. The results of these studies will inform future preventive and therapeutic strategies to reduce OM and BSI burden in this high-risk patient population.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative  Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is the most common skeletal rare disease accompanied by bone fragility disease, with an incidence of approximately 1 in 15,000 worldwide and 25,000–50,000 in the US. This proposal will develop and test precision gene editing strategies to repair OI mutations including type I collagen gene mutations, using bone-targeting recombinant adeno-associated virus (rAAV).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The social motivation theory of autism posits that reduced motivation to interact with people and decreased pleasure derived from social interactions may derail typical social development and contribute to the emergence of social communication deficits in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The objectives of this proposal are to investigate relations between (i) neural responses to social rewards, measured via electroencephalography, (ii) a blood-derived composite marker of systemic inflammation, and (iii) ASD symptoms and quality of life. This project will provide a deeper understanding of relations between neural responses to social rewards, immune functioning, and symptom expression in ASD and has the potential to contribute to the development of EEG-based measures that may be suitable endpoints in future mechanistic trials investigating novel ASD interventions targeting inflammatory processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis (OA) is a debilitating, degenerative joint disease for which there is no cure or effective therapy. A persistent challenge with OA drug candidates is achieving adequate joint bioavailability and retention with minimal systemic toxicity. This project will explore a drug delivery strategy for targeting OA joints after an intravenous injection, thereby advancing therapeutic options for long-term management of OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research will create a bacterial vector to deliver oncolytic viruses directly into hepatocellular carcinoma. This therapeutic strategy will induce immunogenic cell death, activate immune cell infiltration and generate antitumor immunity. Triggering immune responses with engineered bacteria and oncolytic viruses will create an immune therapy that is effective in tumors that are resistant to immune checkpoint inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addressing disparities in global mental health care access requires structured outcomes-focused measurement to ensure efficient use of resources and effective and equitable service delivery. Existing mental health services access measures are limited in their ability to measure the impact of services interventions on patient- and population- outcomes, and ultimately their effectiveness in reducing mental health disparities. We propose to develop and pilot a service-level access measurement system using existing data that is culturally responsive, appropriate to local resources, and can guide resource distribution within integrated mental health care systems and, ultimately, improve mental health care access in global settings.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research strongly implicates defects in the life-sustaining brainstem serotonin system in a major subset of the Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), a major cause of death in the first year of life for which there is no known cause. Here we test the hypothesis, directly in SIDS tissue and serum, that abnormalities in two microRNAs and their gene targets hypothesized to relate, directly and indirectly, to abnormalities in serotonin function, exist in the medulla of SIDS infants in a cell-specific fashion, and can be utilized as biomarkers of brain pathology. Data generated will support future research examining the implications of these changes through animal models related to SIDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this proof of concept study is to advance medication development for alcohol use disorder by testing whether diclofenac, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, can inhibit the enzyme Kynurenine 3-monooxygenase (KMO) in humans. Inhibition of this enzyme in rodents reduces alcohol, cocaine, nicotine, and THC administration, but no KMO inhibitors are available in humans. Testing new medications, with novel pharmacological mechanisms, is a research priority for NIAAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To serve as a catalyst to generate knowledge and translate it into successful strategies to prevent, treat and cure HIV infection, we organized the Einstein/Rockefeller/CUNY-Center for AIDS Research (ERC-CFAR). The ERC- CFAR brings together a highly synergistic partnership of complementary resources by linking a strong basic and clinical research institution `treating a large patient base of people with HIV (Einstein), a globally pre-eminent basic science institution (Rockefeller), and a strong public health/implementation science institution (CUNY) to energize and mobilize our complementary basic, translational, clinical, epidemiologic, behavioral, and implementation research programs to attain our shared goal of Ending the HIV Epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE V(D)J recombination is a DNA rearrangement process that is responsible for generating a diverse population of B and T cells that together provide highly specific immunity to pathogenic microorganisms. The proposed research will determine if a protein called VprBP(DCAF1) stabilizes the histone-lysine N-methyltransferase Enhancer of zeste homolog 2 (Ezh2) in primary B cells, and through VprBP’s association with the RAG1 protein that initiates V(D)J recombination, modulates Ezh2 methyltransferase activity on histone H3 to regulate gene expression and immune repertoire in B cells. This work will not only illuminate a novel role for VprBP in regulating V(D)J recombination, but will also reveal how VprBP(DCAF1) and Ezh2 collaborate to support transcriptional programs during early B cell development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Emory CFAR will contribute to ending the HIV epidemic by accelerating the highest caliber translational research — fostering team science, equity, and multidirectional stakeholder engagement. We will strive to build community trust in research through the intentional inclusion of key stakeholders at all stages of the research pipeline. We will achieve our goals by providing innovative services, tools, expertise, and access to state-of- the-art equipment through an Administrative Core, a Developmental Core, five Science Cores (Biostatistics and Bioinformatics; Clinical Research; Prevention and Implementation Sciences; Systems Immunology; and Virology and Molecular Biomarkers); and two Scientific Working Groups (SWGs) - Health Equity and Next Generation Therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative While a large amount of observations in humans and experimental animals has documented a key role for acetylcholine (ACh) in learning and memory, the underlying cellular and circuit mechanisms have not been elucidated. This application uses state-of-the-art and innovative behavioral, functional and genetic methods to test novel hypotheses and advance our understanding of the cellular and circuit mechanisms by which ACh mediates its effects on learning and memory formation in the cerebral cortex. These studies are important for the understanding and treatment of neurological diseases that cause cognitive impairments such as schizophrenia and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: The hallmarks of chronic kidney disease (CKD) include fibrosis, increased inflammatory responses, and dysregulated mineral metabolism, which are all especially problematic in aged patients and strongly associated with morbidity and mortality. There are no direct therapies for the fibrosis of CKD, and it remains unclear whether targeting this manifestation using broad spectrum drugs is feasible in clinical practice because most drugs that decrease fibrosis in pre-clinical models target multiple essential pathogenic pathways (eg, renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system blockade). Thus, our proposed studies are innovative as we will test for the first time whether a novel transient LNP-FAPCAR CAR-T cell therapy can be used to reduce CKD fibrosis in the aged, and whether this treatment improves mineral metabolism, a key pathology that also has inadequate treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Drug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae is listed as one of the 5 urgent threats in the US by the CDC and one of the 6 high priority pathogens by the WHO. The objective of this project is to create workflows to sequence N. gonorrhoeae from non-culture based clinical urine and extragenital specimens and use phylogenetic analysis from resulting genomic data to enhance detection of emerging strains of N. gonorrhoeae with reduced antimicrobial susceptibility. Knowledge gained would transform future genomic N. gonorrhoeae studies by allowing us to better understand transmission networks across broader reaches of risk groups who are often excluded from traditional culture-based surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus, GBS), is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause pneumonia, skin infections, sepsis, and is the leading cause of neonatal meningitis. Discovery of host- pathogen interactions remains crucial as currently there is no vaccine available. Using CRISPRi technologies, we will generate knockdowns in every gene present in the hypervirulent GBS strain COH1 that will provide the field with a rapid method of testing phenotypes of interest prior to classical mutagenesis strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low income, ethno-racial minoritized children exhibit higher rates of persistent mental health disorders and are at greater risk for lags in identification and treatment creating a mental health equity concern for the most vulnerable. Our team developed and tested an ethno-racially matched, peer-based family navigator program for Head Start preschoolers with developmental concern bringing about increased caregiver engagement in child services. The current proposal is an adapted family navigation program for caregivers of young children at risk for mental health conditions to increase engagement in services and improve child mental health outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this feasibility study is to develop and test a novel Parents-helping-Parents for youth Vaping Cessation (PhP-VX) program, which will be built on our prior studies and inputs from an advisory board including both parents and adolescents (Aim 1). We will conduct a randomized control trial with 100 dyads recruited from pediatric EHR systems to determine the feasibility and acceptability of the program (Aim 2) and explore the effectiveness of the intervention (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overall: Project Narrative The UCLA-CDU CFAR is located in metropolitan Los Angeles, which is a major epicenter for the AIDS epidemic, and is the most populous county in the nation, ranking second in the number of documented cases of advanced HIV disease. The UCLA-CDU CFAR seeks to catalyze and expand HIV research by providing the infrastructure to connect, support and enhance the capacity of investigators affiliated with UCLA and CDU. The UCLA-CDU CFAR will strengthen and amplify the impact of existing research activities and launch new partnerships across Los Angeles and globally through our focus on three themes: we will STOP HIV by preventing new HIV infections (Prevention), reducing morbidity among people living with HIV (Treatment) and developing strategies for eradication (ART-free Remission).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improving the survival and healthy development of low birthweight infants is an urgent global priority, especially in low-resource settings where the risks of prematurity, neonatal hypothermia, and neonatal mortality are high. This proposal seeks to address this issue by evaluating whether offering mothers of low birth weight infants emotional, informational, and motivational support through peers and material support with a package of neonatal care related items is an effective strategy for increasing kangaroo care at home. Findings hold the potential to not only advance neonatal care in low-resource settings but may also be relevant to underserved populations in high-income countries similarly facing a high risk of neonatal mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the Southwest United States, Indigenous communities are disproportionately affected by morbidity and mortality related to Staphylococcus aureus infections, despite similar levels of S. aureus carriage as the general United States population. Existing strategies have not been sufficient to control disease and a better understanding of the epidemiology of S. aureus carriage is needed so that effective and feasible approaches to decolonization can be developed. This proposal will address this public health need by evaluating the molecular epidemiology of S. aureus carriage within households in an Indigenous community in the Southwest with the goal of informing the design and evaluation of decolonization interventions for prevention of S. aureus disease, to be implemented in similarly under-resourced and burdened communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Neurons and astrocytes are two key cell types in the brain that collaborate to enable our thoughts and actions. This proposal examines how these cell types respond to proteotoxic stress associated with neurodegenerative diseases, individually and in collaboration. This information will inform cell-type-specific vulnerabilities in neurodegenerative disease and enable more specific strategies to mitigate neuronal dysfunction and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL: NARRATIVE Benign prostatic hyperplasi is one of the most common symptomatic conditions in aging men, resulting in millions of medical consultations, high healthcare expenditure and loss of productivity. This Center assembles a team of three Early Stage Investigators with expertise in benign urology, inflammation and bioinformatics to pursue a Project to identify the similarities and differences between mouse models of BPH and the human disease, establishing the most appropriate platforms on which to develop and test new medical strategies. The progress of the research, the career development of the team, grant applications derived from the project and data dissemination to the broader research community will be supported by the Administrative Core.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The formation of α-syn aggregation, called amyloid fibrils, is known to cause numerous neurodegenerative diseases, collectively referred to as synucleinopathies. Given its implication in the disease-specific spreading of α-syn pathology in synucleinopathies, it is of critical importance to understand how distinct forms of α-syn fibrils are observed despite their structural diversity. To fill this knowledge gap, this proposal seeks to elucidate the molecular interactions between polymorphic α-syn fibrils and diverse cellular factors in microengineered brain tissue, which will provide the structural insights into the development of disease-specific aggregation inhibitors and antibodies based on the structural specificities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: In transcranial electrical stimulation (tES), two electrodes are placed on the head, and weak electric currents non-invasively stimulate the human brain. This project will define how two types of tES (alternate current and direct current stimulations, namely tACS and tDCS) affect not only neurons but cells of the brain microvasculature. Understanding the cellular targets of tES is essential for the rational design of this technique.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This study will investigate a new mechanism for Ulcerative Colitis (UC). UC is an inflammatory intestinal disease that affects almost 1 million Americans and the cause of it is unknown. Circadian rhythms are 24h rhythms in our bodies that control many important processes like sleep, eating, inflammation and our immune system. When these circadian rhythms in our body become disrupted it can cause inflammation and disease. This study will test, for the first time, if circadian rhythm disruption is an important part of what causes inflammation in UC and could result in new treatments for UC based on correcting disrupted circadian rhythms in UC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schizophrenia is a neuropsychiatric disorder that affects approximately 1% of the population worldwide, with a significant global public health burden; it can exact a devastating toll on patients who suffer from the illness, their families and loved ones. Through the use of cutting-edge genomics tools and resources, the current project will investigate a specific class of variant, "tandem repeat variation", that may increase schizophrenia risk. The project may thereby elucidate an aspect of the biology of schizophrenia, novel genetic risk factors, with consequent translational implications, paving the path for improved schizophrenia diagnosis and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no FDA-approved medications available to prevent preterm delivery of an underdeveloped fetus. The research planned in this application will employ tissues from pregnant women to explore novel signaling pathways that explain the dysfunction of preterm labor that leads to preterm birth. The goal of this supplement is to perform basic, translational research to provide data in support of a full application that will advance our understanding of underlying mechanisms of drug action to discover novel therapeutics that provide more effective treatment for pregnant women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Muscles that move our bodies do so through interactions between the thin and thick protein filaments from which muscles are built. Myosin-binding protein C (MyBP-C) is a thick filament component that helps regulate muscle contraction, and genetic defects in MyBP-C are a cause of skeletal muscle diseases. In this project we will use zebrafish as a model system in conjunction with sophisticated microscopy and other techniques to reveal how MyBP-C functions, providing new insights into the molecular mechanisms by which skeletal muscle contraction is regulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We will investigate whether the pre- and post-systemic treatments gut microbiome affect breast cancer outcomes (recurrence and mortality) and evaluate whether changes in the gut microbiome, particularly cancer treatment-related dysbiosis persist after the completion of cancer therapy. Results from this study will be valuable in developing interventions to optimize the pre-treatment gut microbiota and attenuate dysbiosis during and after cancer treatment with an optimal goal of promoting health and reducing recurrence risk among breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Existing clinical trial data provide many opportunities for analysis after the primary study is completed, especially considering the funding, the time, and the commitment of the study participants that went into generating the data. This proposal will enhance the reusability of clinical study data by simplifying the annotation of laboratory- based clinical trial data for integration into the Immunology Database and Analysis Portal (ImmPort) database and creating a user-friendly tutorial. This focus on re-use of clinical study data shared through ImmPort will maximize the return on investment for biomedical research with significant implications for scientific knowledge and clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Despite its prevalence, ME/CFS remains a poorly understood disease that lacks lab-based, objective diagnostic markers. We propose to study the gene expression, function and electrical property of donor derived, proliferative adult skeletal muscle mononucleated cells (SMMCs). The resulting electrical characteristics coupled with single cell genetic and biological studies have a potential to identify pathology and biomarkers in these cells for future development of ME/CFS diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proprioceptive sense is critical for numerous aspects of motor control as well as for the sense of self. Many decades of work have yielded remarkable progress in our understanding of the sensory neurons involved in this sense and the type of feedback they contribute, yet the role of muscle spindle (MS) group II afferents has remained incompletely understood due to the inability to examine these afferents selectively through physiological or genetic means. Building on our recent findings that MS group II afferents can be distinguished from other proprioceptive muscle afferents by virtue of the expression of Nxph1, this proposal aims to deliver a Nxph1:Cre mouse model to permit a more systematic and selective examination of MS group II afferent function and circuitry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UW/Fred Hutch Center for AIDS Research (CFAR) is a multi-institutional consortium based in Seattle which catalyzes new HIV research and develops new research leaders across the multidisciplinary spectrum of basic, clinical, epidemiologic, statistical, sociobehavioral, and implementation science expertise necessary to bend the curve of the global HIV epidemic. During 35 years of continuous funding, the UW/Fred Hutch CFAR has facilitated substantial growth in research infrastructure, domestic and international partnerships, research impact, and development of emerging HIV researchers (with a return on investment on CFAR developmental awards of 1767%) with high added value and aided by significant institutional commitment. Through our proposed eight Cores and two Scientific Working Groups, we aim to expand multidisciplinary HIV research that spans bench to bedside to populations and grow new researchers, research leaders, infrastructure, and resources to impact the global epidemic.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: The drug supply chain is global and susceptible to disruptive unanticipated events, such as the 2019 Corona- virus (COVID-19) pandemic, but the impact of drug shortages during a global public health emergency and effectiveness of strategies to alleviate drug shortages is unknown. The proposed research is relevant to public health because policy-makers need real world evidence to plan for future global emergencies, drug shortages at large, and inform national- and international-policy to decrease the impact of drug shortages on patient outcomes. Thus, this project is relevant to the AHRQ research priority areas of patient safety, im- provements in health care practice, providing timely response to critical questions, and AHRQ priority groups.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Impact of COVID-19 on Drug Shortages

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a new and alternative strategy for sensing biomolecules through antigen-antibody interactions using electrochemical single nanoparticle detection. These measurements can potentially advance the detection of disease markers down to a single nanoparticle-bioconjugate, providing an efficient diagnosis before symptoms appear and guiding therapy and isolation decisions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission concerning reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most myopia (short-sightedness) represents a failure of emmetropization in which the eye continues to grow after a match between its length and optical power is reached. Myopia’s association with sight-threatening complications and projected near-epidemic levels world-wide (~50% by 2050) makes it critical to develop effective myopia control treatments. This project will apply modern molecular biology and in vivo clinical and optical imaging techniques to better understand an existing drug treatment for controlling myopia and explore new ones, including a novel drug combination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Recent evidence suggests that diminished learning over repeated evaluations (web-based memory tests on the same content for 12min/day for 7 days) reveals subtle AD-related memory decrements otherwise undetectable using traditional single timepoint cognitive testing. Whether this paradigm is similarly sensitive to AD-related cognitive decline in a demographically and geographically diverse population with heightened cerebrovascular risk is unclear; furthermore, it is unclear whether change in an individual’s learning curve, captured biannually, can further improve monitoring of AD-related decline. We will recruit 300 well- characterized cognitively unimpaired older adults with AD biomarkers (amyloid and tau Positron Emission Tomography (PET)) enrolled in the U.S. POINTER study (Study to Protect Brain Health Through Lifestyle Intervention to Reduce Risk); we will explore whether a personal learning curve-PLC collected every 6 months for 12 months is a valid and sensitive marker of AD-related decline while also exploring the moderating effects of non-AD related risk (e.g., non-specific neurodegeneration, cerebrovascular risk) in this representative at-risk population (32% from underrepresented ethnical and racial groups, family history of cognitive decline, hypertension, geographic diversity).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the genes BRCA1 or BRCA2 increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancers, and we have found that having obesity or unhealthy metabolism increases damage to the cells of the breast and fallopian tube that can become cancerous. In mouse models, we discovered that having a mutation in BRCA leads to unhealthy metabolism which may contribute to cancer - this has not been shown before. A first step will be to understand which metabolic tissues are affected and whether this is also true for women, as this could help us understand why some women develop cancer and find ways of reducing their risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on the testing of a psychosocial intervention for the management of anxiety among adolescents and young adult cancer survivors. Approximately 50% of adolescent and young adult cancer survivors will experience clinically significant anxiety in the months to years following cancer treatment. The results are expected to have a positive impact because demonstration that virtual tailored, music-based relaxation is feasible to implement among adolescent and young adult cancer survivors will inform the design of a Phase II clinical trial to demonstrate efficacy of the intervention for anxiety, a distressing side effect of cancer treatment for which little is known about how to best support the psychosocial needs of adolescent and young adult cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Macrophages are white blood cells that function as the front line of defense against many infectious microbes. An in-depth understanding of how macrophages sense and respond to viral pathogens, and specifically, Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) and influenza, is the goal of this project. Our research findings can be expected to lead to identification of new therapeutic treatments that will increase the capacity of macrophages to prevent or repair damage to tissues caused by viral infection, and thereby promote survival of infected people.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall The DC CFAR's mission is to intensify our multi-institutional effort to promote and support research that contributes to ending the HIV epidemic in Washington, DC and beyond in partnership with government and community. The CFAR achieves this mission by providing scientific and administrative leadership to advance HIV research among the eight collaborating DC CFAR institutions; stimulating and supporting innovative and consequential HIV research in the basic, clinical, prevention and social and behavioral sciences; driving the development and recruitment of early stage, new, and women and underrepresented minority HIV investigators; and enhancing communication and fostering meaningful new collaborations between DC CFAR investigators and academic, government, community and clinical partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene therapy with recombinant adeno-associated viral (rAAV) vectors provides the promise of curing inherited genetic disorders, however, it is challenges include the need to produce adequate amounts of rAAV to meet the needs of clinical trials and the poor efficiency of gene expression. Understanding the role of cellular proteins in replication of rAAV vector genomes will suggest ways to improve rAAV production and effective gene delivery. The studies proposed here seek to identify cellular proteins that associate with the AAV genome during replication in producer cells and transduction in target cells, and these results will lead to generation of resources to improve production and overcome current limitations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this study, we will develop a refined rehabilitation toolbox that can be used to improve outpatient physical therapy service delivery for older adults with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). We need this study because current rehabilitation approaches do not address the unique needs of older adults with ADRD. Study findings will set a solid foundation for my future research and career as a leader in aging-focused rehabilitation research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Our proposed project will build upon previous research which has shown an association between oral health and systemic health, including the relationship between heart disease and periodontitis. We will benefit from recent methodological advances in computational genomics and be the first study to provide causal evidence about the postulated relationship between poor oral health and heart disease using nationally-representative, longitudinal data. Specifically, we will construct polygenic scores using a GWAS-by-subtraction genomic structural equation model that are suitable for use in instrumental variables estimation. To accomplish our Aims, we will use longitudinal files containing 11 years of data (2006-2016) from the Health and Retirement Study (HRS). This longitudinal database will provide over 22,000 older Americans producing a sufficiently large sample size to overcome prior analytical obstacles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Proper integration of emotional and social information is essential for thriving and relies on the brain systems implicated in mental disease and often work differently in males and females, but the mechanisms of sex differences remain largely unknown. Based on a new paradigm for social synchronization in mice, this study tests a hypothesis that a female-specific alternative visual stream to the auditory fear circuit drives negative fear synchrony. The resulting basic knowledge will inform how the brain organizes even simple behaviors in a sex- specific manner using competing circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Community dwelling patients with dementia and their family caregivers represent a burgeoning and vulnerable population with significant unmet needs, one of which is pain management. The proposed study will refine and pilot test a novel non-pharmacological caregiver-assisted pain coping skills intervention to train patients and caregivers in skills to help them manage patient pain. The intervention is expected to benefit both patients and their caregivers by improving patient pain and quality of life and caregiver self-efficacy for managing pain, caregiver burden, and caregiving satisfaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Auditory-guided behavior is ubiquitous in everyday life. The deep layers of the auditory cortex gives rise to a major projection system that exerts brain-wide influence over many downstream regions, providing a putative substrate for such behavior. The proposed studies will monitor and manipulate this cortical output in awake, behaving mice, providing an important first step in understanding how corticofugal circuits govern animal behavior and insight into how descending contributions that may underlie sensory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The structure of brain ECM is dynamically regulated by experience and plays a critical role in neuronal plasticity and behavior. However, how the brain’s ECM is structured, maintained, and remodeled is poorly understood, in part due to the limitation of tools that monitor the structural heterogeneity and dynamics of the brain’s ECM. Using a novel live-cell imaging probe that we developed, we will identify neuronal ECM organizers and reveal the regulatory process of the brain’s ECM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Our selection of foods we consume is governed in large part by taste pathways in the periphery (sweet, salty, sour, etc). However, there is a paucity of information about the molecular identities of afferent sensory neurons that process taste signals and transmit these signals to the brain. Understanding how basic tastes are encoded by sensory neurons whose molecular profiles are known is key for understanding diet selection and making rational choices of what we eat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The descending auditory efferent pathway may be involved in supra-threshold hearing, but a comprehensive understanding of how the efferent system develops in humans is lacking. The proposed work will investigate the development of the temporal aspects of efferent mechanisms in children. It is clinically and scientifically relevant, as the knowledge gained can be used to develop objective tests for assessing auditory function, guide intervention efforts and may be applied for designing hearing devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Recent studies have uncovered the existence of at least 16 mechanistically distinct forms of regulated cell death, and commonly used anti-cancer drugs have the ability to activate many, if not all, of these pathways. Understanding which forms of cell death are activated by a drug is critical for predicting mechanisms of drug resistance and for improving drug efficacy; however, this information is not currently known due to the lack of tools needed to simultaneously evaluate all types of cell death. This proposal aims to develop new tools to enable a comprehensive evaluation of which forms of cell death are activated by a drug, and how these features vary across patients, disease types, and treatment contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) affects nearly 50% of adults over the age of 60 and has a profoundly negative effect on speech comprehension, leading to increased social isolation, reduced quality of life, and increased risk for the development of dementia in older adulthood. The studies in our proposal use combined pupillometry and cognitive event-related brain potentials to characterize the effects of listening effort on comprehension and memory functioning in older adults with and without hearing loss. If successful, this project will lead to the identification of objective and reliable neural markers of comprehension and memory processes impaired by SNHL, leading to better future clinical assessment and the improved design of evidence-based interventions to improve speech comprehension and memory in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing and balance disorders affect millions of people worldwide, yet the underlying damage patterns in the ear are not understood well for many inner ear-related clinical problems. This project will develop a large human temporal bone collection as a resource for the scientific community to investigate the inner ear correlates of hearing and balance problems in a diverse population. The project will also refine methods for rapid processing of newly obtained temporal bones and create a multi-platform imaging and analysis pipeline for maximization of the information obtained from each specimen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evaluating interventions that consider both social communication and disruptive behavior strategies is critical for children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who have challenges in both domains, which limit a family's participation in everyday activities. Understanding when, in what sequence, and how best to teach parents to use social communication and disruptive behavior interventions is critical to reducing family burden and increasing the efficiency and efficacy of each intervention. Developing and evaluating interventions for children with ASD supports NIDCD's mission of behavioral research aimed to support social communication in children with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The proposed research is relevant to public health because it maximizes the biological information from human biospecimens by creating a comprehensive multi-omic platform that results in genotype to phenotype analysis that will be used in diagnostics for personalized medicine and target identification for drug discovery. A multi- omics extraction methodology combined with pathway analysis software will increase the rate of biomarker discovery, which will allow early identification of sensitive individuals, provide biomarkers of responsiveness to therapy, and new drug targets and thereby therapeutic agents. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge and technology that will help reduce and treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research is to better understand the efferent auditory system’s role in speech-in-noise perception by: 1) improving methods used to study it and 2) evaluating its function in normal-hearing adults with and without speech-in-noise deficits. The outcomes of this research can be used to: 1) create clinical assessments and targeted treatments for individuals with severe difficulties understanding speech-in-noise and 2) create biologically-inspired noise reduction algorithms for hearing aids and cochlear implants that are based on neural processing strategies in the normal auditory system.

PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this study is to employ Bayesian inference to design subject-specific models of voice production for norm and structural vocal pathologies. The proposed models utilize high-speed videoendoscopy, electroglottography, and acoustic data for parameter inference and model validation. The vocal dynamics, glottal aerodynamics and their interactions are studied comprehensively using the computational models to better understand the normal and disordered function of voice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will create a widely accessible tool for alleviating an immense neurological burden in brain cancer patients, i.e. seizures induced by brain tumors. This research is relevant to the NIH’s mission, and in particular the mission of NINDS because it will transform how scientists can study seizures occurring in a brain cancer microenvironment, generate fundamental knowledge about the neurobiology of the seizure-brain tumor nexus, and pave the way for physicians to test new synergistic anti-seizure/anti-tumor therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) Hearing loss, including deafness, poses obstacles to children's language development and social relationships. This project employs innovative, longitudinal modeling of objectively measured naturalistic behavior to investigate young children's vocal interactions in preschool, and the influence of those interactions on their language development. The project will indicate whether understudied processes of peer- and teacher-influenced language development differ between children with hearing loss and their typically hearing preschool peers over months and years. These efforts will pave the way for classroom-based interventions to enhance the language development of children with hearing loss and other children with language delays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing disorders such as tinnitus, presbycusis, and noise-induced hearing loss are incredibly common and have long been recognized as public health epidemics. This project employs novel strategies to identify how feedback loops between high and low-level auditory centers contribute to hearing, which could eventually inspire new treatments for hearing disorders. More broadly, similar feedback loops occur across all sensory systems; these studies thus lay the conceptual groundwork to understand a general principle of mammalian sensory perception and higher-order brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative People with brainstem stroke, advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease), or other disorders can become unable to move or speak despite being awake and alert. In this project, we seek to further translate knowledge about interpreting brain signals related to movement, and to further develop an intracortical brain-computer interface (iBCI) that could restore rapid and intuitive use of communication apps on tablet computers by people with paralysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Discovering mechanisms to enhance adult brain function is of utmost importance when devising therapeutics to recover and refine normal brain function later in life. We found that temporarily depriving vision leads to recovery of plasticity in the adult auditory cortex, which can benefit auditory function. In this proposal, we aim to determine the mechanisms that allow recovery of adult brain plasticity, and whether temporary visual deprivation improves auditory performance in adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Gut microbiota may play a role in the progression of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). We will follow patients with MASLD-related HCC treated with immunotherapy to assess the impact of gut microbiome and host susceptibility in the disease progression and response to immunotherapy. Our long-term goal is to improve dismal survival rates in HCC patients and to develop a new method of intervention and strategy to complement current clinical efforts focused on personalized and effective care for MASLD-related HCC.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The human genome and that of its experimental surrogate, the mouse, contain an estimated 20,000 genes. Studying these genes has traditionally involved modifying the mouse genome on a gene-by-gene and study-by- study basis. The proposed experiments are designed to accelerate the development and decrease the cost of mouse genome studies, moving strain development efforts from a gene-by-gene method to a more massively parallel approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Many Latinas with untreated depression and/or anxiety do not get the care they need. This study compares a choice-driven, interactive, evidence-informed storytelling web-based app intervention with links to resources and local treatment recommendations, to a web-based app with links to publicly available informational internet videos, resources, and a local treatment locator for at least moderately anxious/depressed untreated English and Spanish speaking Latinas to determine if a story-based, character-driven approach is more effective for catalyzing mental health treatment initiation. Knowledge gained about drivers of action will expand strategies to connect Latinas to sources of needed treatment via our scalable web-based app for low cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative: Excessive use of prescribed opioids during and after major surgery is a significant contributor to persistent opioid use, misuse and ongoing opioid epidemic, which are recently worsened by the pandemic. The proposed research has significant public health relevance because it aims to reduce surgical pain and opioid use with a promising non-pharmacological tool, digital cognitive behavioral intervention, that helps decrease anxiety and depression before surgical procedures. By proactively reducing mood disorder (anxiety, depression) severity, postoperative surgical pain, opioid use and opioid-related serious adverse effects with digital cognitive behavioral intervention, this research will enable the best-in-class post-surgical pain and opioid-related outcomes in millions of Americans undergoing painful surgeries every year while minimizing the nation's opioid epidemic burden.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: In Hirschsprung disease (HSCR), we have just completed whole genome sequencing of 766 unrelated HSCR cases, their 99 affected and 1,293 unaffected first-degree relatives. Here, we use state-of-the-art genomic and functional analysis to enable a near complete genetic characterization of HSCR by improved detection of all variant types in coding and cis regulatory elements of known and novel genes. In addition, using other available genetic data, we test whether HSCR genes contribute to the risk of associated neurocristopathies, to explain the wide spectrum of HSCR phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs), which often lead to disability, reduced quality of life, and amputation, require offloading foot pressure during walking to prevent recurrence after healing. However, many patients struggle to follow the recommended offloading treatment. Thus, we propose a lifestyle-focused occupation therapy (OT) intervention to help patients develop self-care routines and habits that support consistent offloading.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  This project proposes to establish paradigm-changing geometric deep learning models to uncover tissue domains coherent in both histology and gene expression and enable automated prediction of pathology from single-cell spatially resolved transcriptomics (SRT) tissue samples. As SRT is anticipated to revolutionize the study of cellular biology, this new modeling paradigm will have a transformative impact on the computation and machine learning methods for SRT analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The aims of this study are to: (1a) estimate the extent of comorbidities among pregnant women with prenatal alcohol exposure; (1b) build maternal morbidity risk profiles based on social and behavioral determinants of health among women with prenatal alcohol intake using machine learning (ML) methods; (2a) examine the effects of comorbidities on adverse birth outcomes among alcohol-exposed pregnancies; and 2(b) build risk profiles for adverse birth outcomes using ML methods. This study presents a model of study that combines both maternal and infant health in the context of maternal-fetal exposure to alcohol, using innovative methods of data analyses that will yield previously unidentified risk profiles. Given the need for careful allocation of scarce health care resources for prevention and treatment programs, the identification of women and their infants for adverse health outcomes most at risk is critical. .

PHR: Relevance Mutations in LRRC57, an evolutionarily conserved gene of unknown function, have been identified among the top hits in bipolar disorder studies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Central nervous system (CNS) injuries result in severe disability or death partly due to lack of axon regeneration in CNS neurons. This proposal uses a recently developed method of purifying CNS neurons that regenerate axons after injury, from those that do not. Coupled with established high-throughput single-cell methylomic and transcriptomic protocols, this approach provides a unique opportunity to distinguish molecular profiles specifically associated with regenerating neurons and unique to select neuronal subtypes, and how a known neuroprotective and pro-regenerative molecule (folic acid) alters the regenerative capacity of specific cell subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The identification and quantification of low-abundance and post-translationally modified proteins is a formidable and unmet challenge with tremendous potential to impact human health. The proposed research will develop a new chemical platform employing N-heterocyclic carbenes and gold nanoparticles to improve the ionization efficiency of peptides, which is critical for elucidating protein structure. This increased sensitivity has the potential to reveal new disease biomarkers and provide a protein-level view of cellular functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Neck pain is a highly prevalent condition that leads to considerable pain, disability, and economic burden. Despite the clinical significance of neck pain, limited treatment options are available and often ineffective or unsafe. In this project, we will develop a wireless soft electronics-enabled smart transdermal microneedle patch to manage neck pain by integrating electronic devices with therapeutic microneedles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Typical visual environments are dynamic: object motion or navigation shifts visual information over the retina, challenging the brain to understand the world as an organized collection of objects. The proposed research will explore how the neural circuits that assign borders in visual scenes to foreground surfaces aid in predicting future visual input. Understanding these neural computations is important to develop better visual cortical prostheses and to yield insight into the aberrant scene perception that occurs in disorders such as visual agnosias or schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pseudomonas aeruginosa can infect any tissue in the human body and is difficult to treat. This proposal will determine the regulation of a novel regulator of the type III secretion system. The results of this study will aid in developing improved therapeutic options for P. aeruginosa infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enzymes called protein kinases are important regulators of cellular responses to environmental cues, and their deregulation is a hallmark of cancer. We will develop technology based around engineering of kinases and their protein substrates that will allow us to better understand how protein kinases carry out their functions in cancer cells. Understanding signaling pathways important for tumor cell survival and growth may suggest new therapeutic opportunities for treating cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recreating the complexity and properties found in human tissues remains a challenge in bioengineering. This proposal uses a tunable hydrogel platform to form complex cell-matrix adhesion that include ligands for both the integrin and syndecan protein families. The ability of these materials to better recapitulate the extracellular matrix will improve our ability to model tissues in the lab and deliver effective regenerative therapies in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The research objective of this project is to develop a noninvasive, miniaturized, and wearable sensor monitoring carbon dioxide pressure in the blood. Our new technology is proposed as an alternative to the clinical practice of blood withdrawal to measure this parameter informing about the ventilation and respiratory effectiveness of the patient. This new device will allow the monitoring of vital respiration parameters continuously in real-time at home which will revolutionize the monitoring and treatment of numerous respiratory diseases, such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which are amongst the principal cause of death and illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: LAY NARRATIVE MCD, FSGS, MN, and IgAN are rare glomerular diseases of the kidney that cause serious illness including kidney failure and high mortality, generating enormous individual and societal burden. CureGN has assembled nephrologists, researchers with expertise in different scientific disciplines, and patients in a consortium that maintains and analyzes a large, longitudinal observational data and biosamples like blood, urine and images of kidney biopsies. This initiative has developed a critical infrastructure that will advance our ability to study, classify, characterize, diagnose, and treat primary glomerular diseases of the kidney.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Volumetric muscle loss is the irrecoverable loss of muscle tissue that leads to life-long dysfunction or permanent disability. Current treatment options are extremely limited, and there are no physical rehabilitation or surgical standards of care. Using an animal model, the goal of this research is to develop a novel sensor to assess a promising treatment for volumetric muscle loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial persister cells are phenotypic non-growing variants that play important roles in chronic infections and facilitate the development and wide spread of bacterial multidrug resistance. This project aims to develop an optogenetic system and an animal model for controlling and monitoring persister formation in vivo, which are useful for fundamental studies of persister formation and for development of new control agents. Thus, it has significance in infection control, which is critical to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Opioid overdoses will cause the death of ~80,000 Americans in 2023. Narcan has stemmed the rate of increase in opioid deaths, but in some cases Narcan is ineffective, so alternative strategies are needed. This proposal will examine cannabidiol derivatives that have the potential to decrease opioid receptor signaling and improve the efficiency of Narcan in reversing opioid overdoses.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Remote therapeutic monitoring is a new point of care mobile health solution designed to enhance patient engagement with physical therapy care, as well as improve patient-provider communication for those attending physical therapy. While remote therapeutic monitoring stands to improve patients’ experiences with physical therapy and improve the overall effectiveness of physical therapy care for patients with musculoskeletal pain, little to no research has been conducted examining the feasibility or effectiveness of integrating remote therapeutic monitoring into physical therapy. As such, we propose a phased research project (R21/R33) that we will examine the feasibility or implementing RTM into physical therapy care (R21), as well as its effects on patient-centered outcomes and health care utilization among patients attending physical therapy for musculoskeletal pain at a large academic hospital in the US (R33).
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Examining the Feasibility and Effectiveness of an mHealth Solution Designed to Enhance Clinical Outcomes Among Patients Attending Physical Therapy for Musculoskeletal Pain

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Over the past several decades, genetic studies in animal models and in humans have identified and validated a number of longevity-associated genes. Together, these findings strongly suggest that modest changes in the expression of these genes can have significant impact on healthspan and lifespan. In this project, we will develop antisense oligonucleotides to modulate the levels of selected longevity-associated genes, and then test if they can extend lifespan and improve healthspan using a mouse model of accelerated aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food allergies are a potentially life threatening disease with increasing prevalence, and while oral immunotherapy and sublingual immunotherapy are two therapies that can modify this disease, outcomes are extremely variable. Our research studies protein breakdown products called metabolites, and we found that children who develop remission of their food allergies on oral immunotherapy have higher levels of bile acids and other metabolites that are known to alter the immune system. Using studies of oral immunotherapy and sublingual immunotherapy in younger children, we will study changes in these bile acids and other metabolites that affect the immune system to learn more about how children develop remission of their food allergies and identify new targets for food allergy therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Preventing adolescent suicide mortality: Exploring barriers and facilitators of school officials’ participation in child death review meetings Child death review (CDR) aims to prevent adolescent suicide mortality through multidisciplinary review teams, yet fewer than 3 in 10 review teams have participation from school representatives, representing a major implementation gap. Because adolescents spend considerable time in school, school representative participation in CDR reviews is a major undeveloped area of research for identifying mechanisms, correlates, and modifiable risk factors of adolescent suicide deaths. The goal of this mixed methods research is to explore school representatives’ barriers and facilitators to CDR participation and characterize leading barriers and facilitators, which leads to next steps of practice and policy interventions to improve their participation in CDR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an exponentially growing number of nanoparticles engineered to enhance the precise delivery of genetic material to the diseased tissue for safe and effective gene therapy. The ability to cross-compare multiple nanoparticles in a single animal offers a powerful opportunity for personalization across many clinical applications, all while reducing the time, resources, and money in the process. The proposed project aims to develop an effective, efficient, and enabling nano-tool for high-throughput screening of nanoparticles in animals to assess their individual’s preferential delivery to different diseased tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE. This research is a pioneering effort to unravel the complex interplay between ambient air pollution and adverse health outcomes through the development of innovative data analytic methodology. Our analysis spanning two decades of emergency department visits in Atlanta will quantitatively assess the health effects of several air pollution mixtures. Our findings will not only contribute to a deeper understanding of these relationships, but will also have implications for public health interventions, the establishment of air quality standards, and the formulation of evidence-based policy decisions.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allogeneic mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) are a promising cell source for treating inflammatory and immune- mediated diseases, but are targeted for death by the recipient immune system due to mismatched-major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules expressed on the cell surface. The aim of this proposal is to analyze how transforming growth factor-β2 (TGF-β2) regulates MHC expression in MSCs and how the recipient immune system responds to TGF-β2-treated MSCs in vivo. Results from the completion of these studies will support the generation of allogeneic donor MSCs that can be used “off-the-shelf” manner for safe and efficacious treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uveitis is a group of ocular disorders characterized by increased inflammatory cells and protein levels inside the eye. This project aims to develop novel ways to use optical coherence tomography (OCT), an imaging technology with micrometer precision, to detect, grade, and monitor inflammatory cells and protein levels in the aqueous and vitreous humor of the eye so that proper treatment can be delivered on a timely basis. Artificial intelligence algorithms will be developed to analyze OCT images and differentiate the types of cells suspended in the aqueous and vitreous humor.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Human calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) maintains extracellular Ca2+ homeostasis through regulation of parathyroid hormone secretion, and malfunction of CaSR is associated with calcium homeostatic disorders including life-threatening neonatal hypercalcaemic conditions. We are pursuing structure-based functional studies of the pleiotropic signaling pathways of the CaSR in order to elucidate the molecular determinants of its G protein selectivity and promiscuity. Our work will shed light on how naturally occurring mutations in the CaSR gene impact signaling to cause human diseases and initiate the exploration of precision pharmacotherapies targeting these mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Perinatal depression (PND) is the most common complication in pregnancy and postpartum, which increases risk for adverse perinatal outcomes such as preterm birth, maternal suicidal thoughts, and impaired mother- infant bonding. Insomnia precedes over half of PND cases and may serve as an entry point for interventions preventing PND. The proposed project is a large-scale clinical trial to test the effectiveness of a mindfulness- based sleep program designed for pregnant women to improve sleep and alleviate cognitive arousal to reduce risk for PND across pregnancy and postpartum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging-related neurodegenerative diseases affect millions of people worldwide and occur when cells in the nervous system lose function over time and ultimately die. One of the challenges in treating these disorders lies in the complex genetic interplay that drives disease progression. By investigating the interaction between C9orf72 HRE and TMEM106B and exploring the toxicity of TMEM106B fibrils, this study aims to uncover essential mechanisms underlying brain aging and neurodegeneration in FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to develop a novel approach for testing the function of the primate prefrontal cortex in decision-making and other forms of executive function. Such an approach would significantly improve the ability to understand the basis of cognition in the healthy primate brain, and therefore would provide opportunities to improve the diagnosis and treatment of diseases in which cognition is compromised, including substance abuse, depression, eating disorders, OCD, schizophrenia, and others. The findings are therefore expected to be relevant to the part of NIH’s mission pertaining to behavioral and mental health, in particular the missions of NIMH and NIDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative The mosquito disease vector, Aedes aegypti, is troubling because it spreads viruses that cause diseases such as dengue, yellow fever, and Zika, which infect >100,000,000 people/year. The identification of opsins as the first bitter taste receptor in mosquitoes offers the potential for identifying receptor antagonists to improve the efficacy of attractive toxic sugar baits, and reduce populations of insect disease vectors, and human disease. In addition, identifying mammalian opsins as the first receptor for the bitter compound, naringin, which is a common bitter ingredient in grapefruit and other fruit, provides the possibility of isolating antagonists for this receptor, to improve the palatability of many nutritious fruit that promote human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most common form of hearing loss is caused by the death of hair cells in the cochlea. Young mammals are capable of regenerating some hair cells, but this ability disappears by the time they are old enough to hear. In our proposal, we will use genetic reprogramming to drive cells of the inner ear to produce new hair cells, and to understand the mechanisms through which this reprogramming can happen in clinically-relevant conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative  This study proposes to finalize the development of a smartphone AI-app-based intervention for adolescent electronic cigarette (e-cigarette) cessation using a formative evaluation process and to pilot test the app as a summative evaluation. To achieve this, this study will attempt to develop and test a feasible, effective, scalable program using a smartphone application, which can be deployed to a large pool of adolescents through schools, primary care clinics, and community settings. Developing an AI-enhanced program is promising for addressing the emerging health threats of e-cigarette use among adolescents because such programs can provide individualized contents based on user profiling techniques and provide immediate help to manage cravings based on real-time recorded data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying key alternative poly- adenylated mRNA isoforms underpinning the detrimental action of pathological tau oligomers that characterize various tauopathies including Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD related dementia (ADRD). This is ultimately expected to drive the development of a novel, effective preventive/curative therapy for AD and tauopathies, thus improving patients’ health while driving down the societal cost for their care, which is expected to increase to unbearable proportions by the year 2050. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission concerned with fostering creative discoveries by new generation of neuroscientists, and their application to advance the nation’s capacity to protect and improve human health.

PHR: Project Narrative After our considerable progress in reducing the need for anesthesia during pediatric MRI scans, this work aims to further reduce anesthesia through faster imaging, greater motion-robust acquisition and reconstruction tech- niques, and less need for intravenous access. Developments will focus on the clinical testbed of MRI for Inﬂam- matory Bowel Disease, a particularly challenging exam for children. This will make MRI safer, cheaper, and more widely available to children, reducing the population risk of radiation from CT.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Axolotl salamander limbs are anatomically and functionally similar to human limbs, yet, unlike humans, they can be completely regenerated throughout life following amputation, providing clues for future therapeutic approaches toward stimulating limb regeneration in patients. Here, we develop a precise map of all the cells and their gene expression patterns during embryonic development, and we investigate newly-identified putative stem cells relevant to axolotl limb regeneration. These studies will reveal information about stem cells that will be important for understanding how they relate to the development and regeneration of the axolotl limb.

PHR: Project Narrative Auditory processing abnormalities (e.g. auditory hypersensitivity and reduced auditory spatial attention) are common and prominent features in neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The long-term goal is to investigate the mechanisms how altered myelination and brain connectivity impair auditory processing in neurodevelopmental disorders. A better understanding of the contributions of the neural mechanisms underlying the auditory processing abnormalities to ASD will help guide better therapeutic strategies for individuals with ASD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because preimplantation uterine fluid regulation is crucial for several early pregnancy events and its dysregulation is associated with two public health issues: infertility and contraception. This proposal aims to investigate uterine fluid dysregulation as a mechanism for contraception, an area that has not been investigated but some observations implicate its importance. The completion of the proposed studies will not only fill in the knowledge gap about preimplantation uterine fluid dysregulation for conception, but also provide insights into optimizing and developing hormonal contraceptives targeting uterine fluid.
