IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) is one of the top causes of death in humans worldwide, with children accounting for about half of those deaths. It is not understood how the TB bacteria resist viruses (phage) that can infect and kill them, making it important to explore how the bacteria resist viruses to help us develop innovative ways to treat TB using viruses, particularly in the face of ongoing increases in drug-resistance. Knowledge gained from these studies will help us to better fight tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Modeling human amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS or Lou Gehrig’s disease) has been challenging, with current stem cell-based and animal systems showing mild or limited phenotypes. The lack of models that recapitulate disease phenotypes impedes the development of much needed therapies. Here, we aim to establish direct fibroblast-to-neuron conversion, which preserves epigenetic age, as a novel system to understand human ALS and associated frontotemporal dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Structural racism in the forms of residential segregation, concentrated poverty, and limited access to education and employment opportunities results in a disproportionate burden of community violence exposure (CVE) among Black youth. Despite the disproportionate burden of community violence and associated health inequities among Black youth, effective culturally and contextually responsive models of care are lagging. The proposed study seeks to address CVE with a pediatric health care model focused on healing rather than risk to empower minoritized and systematically oppressed CVE urban families.

PHR: Project Narrative Mechanisms of learning and memory and their dependence on behavioral contexts have important implications in memory disorders such as Alzheimer's disease and age-related dementia, as well as post-traumatic stress disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Though the physicochemical properties of aerosols play a key role in respiratory virus transmission and in the effective delivery of drugs to the lungs, a comprehensive understanding of these properties has been hindered by the absence of high-quality in situ measurement techniques. This project aims to develop a fluorescence- based experimental apparatus capable of in situ measurements of the phase state, viscosity, and pH of size- resolved fine and ultrafine respiratory and drug aerosols. The eventual application of this instrument to characterize respiratory and drug aerosols will advance our ability to understand, predict, and control airborne virus transmission and pulmonary drug delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will investigate the organization of speech sound representations in the developing brain from childhood to adolescence. In addition to its overall organization for speech, we will determine how the brain is able to segment continuous speech sounds in different contexts, including when speech is self- generated or occurs in the presence of noise or other competing information. Understanding such processes will inform developmental milestones for brain development, and could lead to brain-based treatments of language disorders delayed language learning and dyslexia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This proposal is to advance the Mississippi Center of Excellence in Perinatal Research (MS CEPR) COBRE at the University of Mississippi Medical Center into Phase 2. Perinatal research encompasses the study of disease states that have their etiology during gestation and early post-natal development that result in long term consequences in the mother and offspring across their lifespans. The long term goal is to develop an nationally recognized, sustainable MS CEPR dedicated to reducing health care disparities and improving the lives of women and their offspring, especially in Mississippi, through discovery, innovation, and translation to prevent and reduce death and disability from perinatally-induced diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is a major risk factor for both Alzheimer’s Disease development in the brain and loss of Merkel cell touch receptors in the skin. This Administrative Supplement proposal will investigate convergent mechanisms that underlie these two age-related diseases. If proven, our application will unlock new avenues of investigation for the Alzheimer’s field and establish the skin Merkel cell pool as a prognostic factor for Alzheimer’s risk.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Enhancing Policy Impact for Reproductive Health Equity (EnPIRHE) Project Narrative- 3 sentences Individuals can be reluctant to obtain sensitive health services because of insurance and billing confidentiality concerns, and resulting gaps in care worsen population health overall and health inequities. Massachusetts’ PATCH law is one of only a handful of state-level laws that afford privacy protections for individuals using insurance to access sensitive services. The EnPIRHE study will estimate the proportion of insured dependents who refrain from using their insurance for sensitive services even in the setting of legal protections, quantitatively assess population knowledge of the PATCH law, and qualitatively assess barriers to use of the law’s protections among different demographic subgroups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scleroderma is an immune-mediated disease of the connective tissue, characterized by fibrosis of the skin and underlying organs, which has the highest mortality rate of any rheumatic disorder; there is no cure and only limited targeted treatments. We hypothesize that T cells interact with fibroblasts in the skin to regulate the gene programs of healthy tissue and that pathogenic T cell cytokines promote dysregulated fibroblast gene expression changes leading to fibrosis and organ failure. This proposal will utilize innovative techniques such as spatial transcriptomics and organotypic skin culture to fill critical knowledge gaps about T cells during disease and overcome existing technical hurdles in the field to inform future therapeutics for scleroderma. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) As much as 50-60% of cancer is preventable, and tobacco is by far the leading preventable cause of cancer, accounting for one-third of cancer mortality. Interventions to stop adolescent e-cigarette use “vaping” are important for cancer prevention, as those who vape are almost 4 times more likely to smoke cigarettes. Lessons learned from developing effective social media interventions for adolescents can also be applied to enhance other cancer-related communication efforts to improve equity in cancer control and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA) is one of 9 polyglutamine diseases that are part of a larger family of neurodegenerative diseases characterized by protein misfolding and accumulation; these diseases include Alzheimer’s disease, Huntington’s disease, Parkinson’s disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Understanding molecular mechanisms of disease has the potential to unveil new and innovative approaches to therapy. We propose here to understand how a specific modification of the androgen receptor (AR) in SBMA is regulated so that we can manipulate it for therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS) are increasingly popular among adolescents and young adults for “vaping” of nicotine and cannabis products and are often considered “healthier alternatives” but may have the same negative impact on oral health, including tooth decay, as previously reported for tobacco and cannabis smoking. Current research has largely focused on studying the effect of pure nicotine on the pathogenic activities of the cariogenic bacterium Streptococcus mutans and its partner species Candida albicans, and the effect of the more relevant vaping products of nicotine and cannabis on their interaction is currently largely unknown. This study is designed to address this knowledge gap by evaluating the action of nicotine and cannabis vape aerosols produced by ENDS on standard laboratory microorganisms and, importantly, clinical isolates from the actual adolescents and young adults who vape and those who do not use these products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this Administrative Supplement application is to secure funding necessary to purchase a confocal microscope, which is critical for the completion of experiments detailed in NEI funded R01 (EY032543), titled “Neural Retina-Specific Bim Expression and Hyperoxia Sensitivity of the Developing Retinal Vasculature”. The confocal microscopy system will be used for high-resolution imaging of retinas from mice with different genotypes and treatments as described in the application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposal aims to address the challenge of managing antibiotic-refractory recurrent urinary tract infections (rUTIs) by utilizing BactVue, a novel bacteria-specific photothermal dye developed in the Gassensmith lab. BactVue is a bacteria-selective probe that can permeate epithelial cells, bind to intracellular bacteria, and, upon brief irradiation with a laser, fluoresces to reveal the bacterial location or, with prolonged irradiation, causes photothermal heating to destroy infected tissue selectively. This proposal intends to validate the efficacy of BactVue in selectively staining diverse intracellular uropathogenic bacteria and its utility for the targeted ablation of infected bladder tissue through photothermal heating, potentially transforming the treatment paradigms for antibiotic-refractory UTI.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  This research program is highly relevant to public health as spina bifida (SB), resulting from the defects of spinal neural tube (SNT) formation, is the second most prevalent birth defect in humans with life-long disabilities and neurological disorders. We will investigate how genetic predisposition and its interaction with environmental factors regulate human SNT formation with in vitro 3D SNT organoids and develop an SNT chip with an advanced microfluidics system to recapitulate the spatiotemporal microenvironment. The ultimate goal of this research program is to provide the scientific and technical progress toward developing novel intervention strategies for SB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New preventive and treatment modalities are needed for persons with weakened immune systems against enteric infections. The Hang lab has recently discovered specific Enterococcus peptidoglycan hydrolases can confer protection against bacterial diarrhea illness. We therefore propose to evaluate the activity of orally available recombinant Enterococcus peptidoglycan hydrolase hydrogel formulations in mouse models of enteric infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Ultrasound neuromodulation is a targeted and non-invasive approach to treating the precise regions in the brain that contribute to neurological disease. The platform will enable the development of non-invasive protocols for precise and effective treatment of neurological disorders using ultrasound.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low-income, racial/ethnic minoritized individuals have limited access to evidence-based interventions for men- tal health, especially Black adults living in low-income areas. Peer recovery specialists, individuals in recovery from mental health and/or substance use problems, may have potential for increasing access to evidence- based interventions for Black individuals from low-resource communities, particularly when trained and super- vised in models that are acceptable and feasible in these communities. By evaluating a peer-delivered evi- dence-based behavioral intervention, and how well it could be sustained, findings may have the potential to significantly improve access to mental health treatment in traditionally underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this mixed methods study is first, to refine our current model of financial and health-related social needs navigation to integrate an established digital platform of community resources and to optimize our vocational navigation support (Aim 1). Then, we will evaluate the feasibility, including AYA uptake and engagement (Aim 2) and explore the preliminary impact on reducing financial toxicity and improving global health outcomes (Aim 3) among 80 racially, ethnically, and socioeconomically diverse AYA cancer survivors in New York City. Our intervention is patient-informed, leverages clinical and community partnerships, and thus has a high likelihood of success as well as sustainability, scalability, and overall impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum parasites remains a devastating infectious disease marked by increasing treatment failures with frontline artemisinin combination therapies. These parasites require nutritional iron for survival, but their cellular mechanisms to acquire and distribute iron remain largely undefined. The proposed studies will test the essentiality and function of a putative iron transporter targeted to a key parasite organelle, thus elucidating a critical metal acquisition mechanism and defining a potential new therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinx/a/o people are the largest ethnoracial minoritized group in the United States and face considerable disparities in oral health, particularly among its adult population. This study will examine how immigration policy vulnerability affects the clinical and self-reported oral health of Latinx/o/a adults. These findings will expand our understanding of how structural racialization via immigration policy shapes the oral health of Latinx/a/o immigrants and their U.S. born co-ethnics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative Many bacterial diseases are caused by intracellular pathogens that deliver proteins into host cells to remodel them into a niche of survival, replication or persistence. These so-called “effector” proteins act together to promote bacterial virulence, yet how their functions are coordinated in space and time remain elusive. We found that the zoonotic bacterial pathogen Brucella abortus injects into host cells three effector proteins that form an intracellular complex. This proposal aims to characterize the structure, assembly and functions of this unique multi-effector platform and determine whether it allows coordination of effector functions during the Brucella intracellular cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to rural public health in the cancer care continuum. Understanding the impact of rural hospital closures on cancer outcomes will provide critical insights into their consequences on cancer care and racial/ethnic disparities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: LEGACY EMANUEL HOSPITAL AND HEALTH CENTER
PHR: Narrative Myopia is a global health concern due to its wide prevalence. Nearly half of the population in the world will be myopic by 2050. The molecular and cellular pathways that underlie myopia remain poorly understood. This proposal will identify novel cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie myopia development and link them to their hallmarks at tissue level optical coherent tomography imaging. The proposal’s overarching goal is to foster and facilitate the design and development of novel treatment strategies to halt the global myopia epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Retinal degenerative diseases are the leading cause of irreversible vision loss. Retina prosthesis are invasive implantable devices designed to stimulate sensation of vision in the eyes of individuals with these significant conditions. In this application, we aim to develop an injectable optoacoustic prosthesis as a minimal invasive approach for high precision genetic-free optoacoustic stimulation with translational potential to human.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Surgical training is a time-intensive activity for both the trainee and teacher, furthermore, expert clinicians are unevenly distributed geographically, and face competing demands on their time for clinical and instructional work. Our proposed autonomous coaching system is a key step towards increasing accessibility and lowering the cost of effective surgical instruction by capturing expert surgical cognition and presenting it to trainees when they practice surgery. The project’s significance to public health is to accelerate the acquisition of surgeon skills, which is associated with improved patient post-operative outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Present methods for assessing color vision (CV) are not sensitive/specific enough to detect the changes in CV caused by Parkinson’s disease (PD), or are unsuitable for people cognitive impairments and/or motor deficits (CIs/MDs) that occur during both the prodromal and clinical stages of PD. We recently demonstrated a new brain- computer interface (BCI)-based method for CV assessment and propose to test the hypothesis that this new assessment has enhanced sensitivity, specificity, and test-retest reliability for detecting color vision deficiencies (CVDs) related to PD compared to existing behavior-based assessments. If successful, our research will enable the use of CVDs as early biomarkers of PD, CV assessment as a method for monitoring PD progression, and may lead to the use of CV assessment for the early detection of CVDs caused by other neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed mixed-methods study will investigate xylazine’s growing prevalence in the illicit drug markets in the Appalachian foothills of North Carolina and investigate its epidemiological impact on consumer perceptions, behavior, and health. Knowledge gained from this study will clarify xylazine’s overall prevalence in the illicit drug market and its relative prevalence in specific drugs; identify consumers’ homegrown strategies for discerning xylazine in their drugs; and identify Drug, Set, and Setting (DSS) risk factors, psychosocial consequences, behavioral risk, and adverse health outcomes associated with xylazine exposure. Because the sharp growth in xylazine exposure among people who use drugs comprises an emerging health crisis, this study will directly inform local and national efforts for combatting harms associated with xylazine use by disseminating findings to community members and decisionmakers in real time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Management of HIV infection is facilitated by a number of current antiretroviral therapies that effectively block HIV function. However, the probability of patient relapse increases over time, as HIV mutates and becomes resistant to approved therapeutics. This project involves the development of a new class of compounds that can target both the original and the mutated form of HIV, allowing for long-term management for HIV patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to air pollution contributes to 6.7 million deaths annually worldwide, and the majority of death and disability due to air pollution is in low and middle-income countries (LMICs). While portable air cleaners (PACs) have been demonstrated to effectively reduce particulate matter in high-income countries, their use in LMICs has been limited by several challenges. This project will study several of these challenges and seeks to demonstrate that PACs can reduce particulate matter, can remain continuously powered, and can be used consistently in an LMIC setting. This project is highly relevant to the NIH mission of reducing illness and disability and to the NIEHS strategic priorities of reducing environmental health disparities and ensuring environmental justice.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite the National Institute of Health's recommendation for exclusive breastfeeding in the first 6 months for improved child health and development, challenges such as return to work, inconsistent milk supply, and postpartum stress hinder successful breastfeeding outcomes for mothers. Leveraging passive longitudinal monitoring through smartphones and smartwatches, this study aims to explore how physiological and behavioral patterns, along with self-reported factors, in the third trimester impact breastfeeding. The study's approach seeks to transform our understanding of breastfeeding outcomes, paving the way for personalized recommendations, and ultimately improving child health and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-term maintenance of regular physical activity significantly lowers risks of cancer. Emotional responses during physical activity can trigger unconscious implicit attitudes towards the behavior (e.g., favorable/ unfavorable) that contribute to the likelihood of future behavior engagement. This study will examine whether implicit attitudes towards physical activity can be experimentally manipulated by daily “emotion-based” intervention strategies and whether changes in implicit attitudes lead to changes in physical activity behavior among adults at elevated risk of cancer due to inactivity and overweight/obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents experiencing homelessness (AEH) have higher rates of suicidal behavior compared to their domiciled counterparts, especially during school breaks (i.e., summer, Fridays, and Saturdays), while their domiciled counterparts have lower rates during these periods. Although recent studies noted decreased rates of suicidal behavior among adolescents in spring 2020, coinciding with nationwide school closures as a pandemic control measure, we hypothesize increased suicidal behavior among AEH in spring 2020 based on our prior study indicating AEH face higher risk when away from school. The proposed project will investigate annual rates of suicidal behavior among AEH and domiciled adolescents from 2016 to 2022 to determine whether the pandemic has exacerbated existing disparities, as well as assess monthly trends before, during, and after the pandemic with the goal of informing tailored suicide prevention measures for AEH, especially before and during school breaks, and enhancing preparedness for potential future school closures due to pandemics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Using a quasi-natural experiment approach with unique data, this research will contribute fundamental knowledge about the medium- and potential long-term effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and childcare services disruption on the developmental progress of vulnerable and at- risk children. Child care services may be instrumental to timely identification of developmental delays, therefore findings of the study will provide essential evidence about these impacts and the mechanisms behind them that can inform and alert health care providers and child care and early education policy makers dealing with the consequences of this crisis. Our results will also speak to the broader issue of the consequences of structural inequalities and lack of family support for our children’s developmental outcomes, and can serve as guidelines for policies and health initiatives targeted at vulnerable children and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative DNA is the biomolecule in cells that carries instructions for making the proteins, lipids, and other molecules that make up living cells and tissues. In addition to the instructions carried in our DNA for making normal cellular proteins, we have many stretches of DNA in our genome that encode retrotransposons, which are similar to retroviruses, but they don’t infect other cells. A special ability of retrotransposons is that they can take copies of their DNA and insert those copies into new locations in our genome. This process can create mutations in our DNA, leading to cancer and other diseases. In addition, retrotransposon DNA, just like our DNA, makes proteins. Unfortunately, we know very little about the effects of these retrotransposon proteins in our cells, but we know that many types of diseased cells make much more of these proteins than healthy cells. Retrotransposon proteins also increase in cells as we age. The diseases associated with increased retrotransposon proteins include neurodegeneration, autoimmune disease, and others. The primary reason we know so little about retrotransposon proteins and their effects in our cells is because we lack reliable methods to study them. The lack of methods to study these proteins arises from the fact that there are so many copies of retrotransposon DNA in our genome, which makes conventional DNA editing technologies unfeasible. We propose to develop a novel method to eliminate retrotransposon proteins using molecules called “nanobodies”, which can be modified and introduced into cells to eliminate specific proteins. We can also use nanobodies to track retrotransposon proteins in cells to see where they go and what other proteins they interact with. Developing this new system will advance our ability to study and understand the effects of retrotransposon proteins on our health and how they influence aging and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rates of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) are higher in women and in Black and Hispanics; and identifying modifiable risk factors in this population is a priority in lowering the burden of AD. Compared to white women, Black and Hispanic women experience worse menopause symptoms, including hot flashes, sleep disturbance, and cognitive difficulties. The goal of this study is to determine whether sleep disturbance, hot flashes and sleep- wake activity are linked to memory performance in Black and Hispanic menopausal women, and therefore could represent midlife risk factors for cognitive decline and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study examines resting state functional brain connectivity in infants with and without a family history of autism followed from birth to 18 months. The study will characterize the brain connectome during a period of extremely rapid development and plasticity, and test predictive models to demonstrate that the early changes in the connectome are meaningful and related to the core social features of autism. The study has great potential for improving identification of early brain-based risk factors for development of social difficulties and implementation of early interventions to support social attention and engagement in infancy and early childhood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Our sense of taste is mediated by taste buds on the tongue that allow us to choose what to eat and what to avoid. Taste function is perturbed by a host of factors, ranging from viral infection, e.g. COVID-19, to cancer therapies, but we have little understanding of the underlying effects on taste buds themselves. Here, we will develop tissue culture techniques to grow taste buds from lingual tissue of recently deceased human donors, with the longer-term goal of understanding how disease and cancer drugs affect human taste buds directly and by extrapolation, taste function in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Prepubescent children have historically been protected from the severe pulmonary pneumonias that have occurred during pandemic outbreaks of viruses such as influenza and Covid. We have identified a unique population of cells that we hypothesize are involved in this protection. The studies proposed here are designed to identify how these cells protect, in order to design therapies to reduce inflammation in non-protected populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Spreading depolarization is a slow-moving wave of abnormal electrical activity in the brain that occurs in many neurological conditions such as stroke. Recent experiments show that this phenomenon pulls cerebrospinal ﬂuid into the brain, killing additional brain cells, but the underlying mechanisms of this phenomenon are not understood. We will use simulations and mouse experiments to uncover the relative importance of three different likely mechanisms that lead to disruptions in the cerebrospinal ﬂuid ﬂow due to a spreading depolarization wave.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This research addresses the pressing issue of underdiagnosed myofascial pain, which plays a significant role in various musculoskeletal pain conditions, including plantar fasciitis. By developing novel imaging biomarkers, this study aims to provide objective means of detecting myofascial pain, understanding its underlying mechanisms, and guiding personalized treatments. Given the high prevalence of plantar fasciitis and its long-lasting impact, this research has the potential to improve the diagnosis and treatment of not only this condition but also other lower extremity musculoskeletal disorders, ultimately enhancing public health by reducing illness and disability associated with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Our project addresses the critical need for improved treatments in Huntington's disease (HD), a devastating neurodegenerative disorder. We're developing GLYN122, a novel small molecule therapy, to lower mutant huntingtin protein (mHTT) levels and alleviate HD symptoms. As we investigate GLYN122's unique advantages and conduct a comprehensive analysis of sex-specific responses, our research aligns with the "Advancing Science for the Health of Women" initiative, and we will utilize the Molecular Center of Health and Disease (MCHD)-COBRE infrastructure to delve into the molecular and physiological mechanisms underpinning these sex-specific responses to GLYN122.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project provides a timely opportunity to explore and understand how cumulative precarity prior to and during a recession may have long-term consequences for health and survival disparities. As the remnants of the COVID-19 economic recession persist, with additional and disproportionate insults on both employment and health in Blacks, the full extent of which will not be fully understood for years to come, understanding prior cumulative effects will be important for addressing the effects of COVID-19 and future economic shocks. The study findings have great relevance for health and social policy aimed at building safety nets for vulnerable older workers approaching and preparing for retirement.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genomic signatures provide insights into past mutational processes driven by DNA damage and repair, but they may not reflect the current status of DNA repair pathways in individual cells. A lack of functional assays has hampered efforts to understand the relationship between DNA repair and mutation signatures. We are therefore developing a high-throughput platform for measuring the activity of all major DNA repair pathways in hundreds of cell lines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tissue-based genomic analyses enabled by next-generation sequencing technologies have emerged to investigate race-specific somatic alterations and their clinical implications; however, tissue-based analyses are extremely challenging in metastatic prostate cancer because, as a bone-predominant metastatic disease, tissue samples are not always obtainable. In this proposed study, we aim to identify race-specific somatic mutations that are associated with survival disparity between black and white patients with metastatic prostate cancer, using a liquid biopsy approach based on circulation tumor cell sequencing to characterize and monitor tumor dynamics. The identified race-specific prognosis-relevant mutational signatures may assist in prognosis stratification, precision medicine, and optimal management of prostate cancer patients, including racial minorities who are underrepresented in previous molecular profiling studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is currently no therapy that can prevent the development of epilepsy after brain trauma. Here we propose to test the efficacy of a novel compound, and determine its efficacy and tolerability in an animal model of posttraumatic epilepsy, in a setting that resembles the clinical practice of care of people with severe traumatic brain injury. We also aim to identify and validate novel biomarkers that can predict who will develop epilepsy and who may respond to a treatment that can prevent epilepsy, in hope that this may accelerate and optimize future efforts to develop new antiepileptogenic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonresponse significantly undermines the representativeness of patient-reported outcome (PRO) data that is routinely collected as part of clinical care, thereby compromising its utility for facilitating high-value, equitable patient-centered care in cancer clinics. Using a multilevel framework and a mixed-methods approach, the proposed project strives to augment the understanding and management of nonresponse in PRO data collected as part of routine cancer care. This initiative will set the stage for harnessing pre-existing, routinely collected PRO data for equitable healthcare and quality improvement while also planning for future interventions aimed at expanding the reach of PRO data collection to underrepresented populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Facial paralysis can compromise control of the eyelids, leading to pain, discomfort, and loss of facial aesthetics. The state-of-the-art treatments that are intended to treat loss of eyelid function are not able to recapitulate the eyelid’s many behaviors, in part because it is not yet known how the human nervous system produces these behaviors. The objective of this project is to study the neurological mechanisms that underlie eyelid function in both healthy people and patients with facial paralysis, as a first step toward neuroprostheses that reproduce natural eyelid function to alleviate pain, protect the eye, and restore confidence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objectives of this project are to deepen our understanding of the molecular functions of the ubiquitin ligase Anaphase-Promoting Complex (APC) in inherited neurodevelopmental disorders. We previously identified key mechanisms by which APC-mediated ubiquitin signaling controls the composition of heterochromatin in neurons, and we are proposing sophisticated structural experiments to understand how ubiquitin ligases recognize substrates within protein complexes. These experiments will provide crucial molecular insight that hastens progress toward modulating key ubiquitin signaling pathways and/or their targets in order to therapeutically intervene in the pathogenesis of a class of debilitating diseases that represent a major unmet medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: ––– PROJECT NARRATIVE –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– Alcohol use disorders are a chronic human condition driven by numerous factors, including one’s initial sensitivity to ethanol intoxication, how easily one develops tolerance to these intoxicating effects with continued alcohol experience, or how one becomes insensitive to the pleasant, rewarding effects of alcohol over time. How exactly these different alcohol responses depend on each other has not been systematically analyzed. The results from this proposal will examine how these different alcohol responses depend on each other, thereby illuminating critical mechanisms driving addiction and substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Development of potent and safe CRISPR tools for in vivo gene editing using directed evolution Research Narrative Though genome editing technologies provide therapeutic promise many diseases, the CRISPR sgRNA is prone to cellular instability and immunogenicity thus reducing clinical potential. Full chemical modification has been essential for the clinical success of past RNA therapeutics, but Cas9 does not function well with fully chemically modified sgRNA. In this proposal, we describe the development of fully-modified sgRNA:Cas9 pairs to improve in vivo stability and safety while enabling enhanced genome editing strategies, including self-delivering sgRNA, multiplexed targets, orthogonal sgRNA:Cas9 pairs, sgRNA redosing, transient editing, and vector inactivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Survey methods for estimating adult mortality are critical in populations that lack complete death registration (including most of Africa and Asia), but current methods require large samples and rely on largely untested assumptions. The proposed research will analyze already-collected pilot data on new methods that require smaller samples; estimates will be compared to a gold standard for validation, and new qualitative data will be collected to help understand which methods perform the best. The results will produce tools that can improve measurement of adult mortality, and so improve science and policy around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infectious diseases cause an estimated 14.4 million deaths each year due to a lack of potent vaccines against some diseases (12.7 million deaths) as well as a lack of access to existing vaccines in low-resource settings (1.7 million deaths). Exponentially increasing the amount of antigen administered over time to mimic a natural infection has been shown to be an effective method for enhancing the immune response; however, the methods used to demonstrate this effect have consisted of infusion pumps or a series of tightly-spaced injections—both of which are infeasible to implement clinically. To employ this strategy in a clinically viable manner, we will develop formulations of modular biodegradable microparticles that, in combination, recapitulate the antigen kinetics of native infections to improve the efficacy of poorly immunogenic vaccines and/or truncate immunization schedules to enhance protection and increase vaccine assess.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Humoral Immunity to Enteric Viruses among Infants and Mothers in Bangladesh Narrative Diarrhea is a leading cause of death among children under five years of age worldwide. This problem is particularly acute in low- and middle-income countries where access to clean water, vaccines and medical care may be limited. We will study antibodies produced by mothers and children that protect children from viral causes of diarrhea to identify the targets of protective antibodies which will be excellent potential vaccines in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite significant research and investment, no FDA approved broad spectrum countermeasures are available to rapidly mitigate vesicant-induced injury following intentional or accidental chemical exposure. A major limiting factor in the development of therapies is the lack of a comprehensive understanding of the inflammatory damage that occurs following cutaneous vesicant exposure. The goal of this proposal is to implement and establish a state-of-the-art spatial multi-omics platform to investigate conserved mechanisms of inflammatory damage induced by dermal exposure to sulfur mustard and lewisite vesicant classes in a clinically relevant porcine skin model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of this study are to culturally adapt the online version of the Family Check-Up and identify strategies to reduce barriers to engagement and support effectiveness through a community-engaged approach. We will integrate iterative feedback from a community advisory board into the adaptation of the online model. Our team will assess feasibility, accessibility, adoption, and potential effectiveness, with the goal of targeting key parenting mechanisms (parenting practices and cultural socialization) to reduce substance use risk among Latinx youth and inform broad public health efforts to prevent substance abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advances in deep learning and computer vision for surgical intelligence is currently limited by challenges to labelling large swathes of data from endoscopic video, which requires expert knowledge and high annotation costs. This project proposes a semi-autonomous pipeline for reduce drastically reducing the annotation cost for segmenting large sets of endoscopic videos by develop a robust set of learning-based approaches to data sorting and parsing and evaluating them on a cholorectal surgery dataset. The models developed for this pipeline would contribute to key knowledge about best practices for algorithms analyzing surgical video both during surgery and offline, for recommending assistance, noticing unsafe behavior, providing relevant semantic information, and disseminating key training materials, as examples.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growing body of evidence suggests that in-utero experiences of housing insecurity are associated with an increased risk of adverse birth outcomes in low-income households . By reducing exposure to housing insecurity, prenatal housing assistance programs may play an important role in reducing the risk of adverse birth outcomes among low-income children. This study seeks to evaluate the impact of prenatal housing assistance on risk for adverse birth outcomes using quasi-experimental methods and a novel linkage of U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development administrative records with California vital statistics birth records.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Overdiagnosis of cancer generally causes the patient to engage in aggressive treatment and may result in anxiety, serious physical harm, unnecessary losses in quality of life, and financial health-care costs. Estimates of overdiagnosis in lung cancer due to population-based lung cancer screening have thus far only been estimated in randomized control trials, however, individuals participating in community-based screening programs are different from those participating in randomized control trials. This project will determine if overdiagnosis exists in lung cancer due to lung cancer screening and will estimate a range of overdiagnosis values.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The purpose of the proposal is to develop a unique animal model, the leopard gecko, in which to study tooth development and loss. The adult leopard gecko, unlike mammals, has teeth that are replaced and shed throughout life and that can be directly accessed in order to expose the teeth to surgical procedures. The ability to stop and then restart tooth development in the gecko will one day be applicable to the bioengineering of human teeth and the prevention of tooth loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging evidence shows that phenotypic alterations in neurodevelopmental disorders are caused by a multitude of factors, including altered interaction between neurons and astrocytes. This proposal asks how astrocyte-secreted Sema3c, upregulated in release from astrocytes in multiple neurodevelopmental disorders, mechanistically contributes to Rett syndrome pathology. Unbiased proteomics experiments will inform on how neuron-astrocyte communication is altered in Rett syndrome providing insights into dysregulated cellular interaction in vivo and identifying potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As the global population ages, addressing aging-related musculoskeletal disorders gains importance. To prepare scientists for diverse post-training career prospects beyond academia, the Aging Research and Entrepreneurial Development Immersion (A-REDI) R25 proposal aims to provide training in aging research and various career paths through didactic training and an immersive period, supported by experts in regulation, law, and entrepreneurship. The program's goals encompass comprehensive training, practical experience, communication skills, and fostering collaboration in an interdisciplinary environment, empowering trainees to translate their research and explore careers in aging innovation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative- Component A  We propose a study among patients requesting medical care for respiratory virus symptoms to determine influenza and COVID-19 vaccine effectiveness by comparing vaccine histories of participants who test positive for influenza or COVID-19 to those who test negative for influenza or COVID-19. We aim to enroll 1000-1200 outpatients during the influenza season in age groups 6 mos-18 years, 19-49 years, and ≥50 years, plus remote enrollment outside of influenza season (another 400-900 if COVID-19 persists). We will genetically sequence specimens for virus types (clades) and determine the annual, population-based burden of influenza and COVID-19 for Allegheny County (Pittsburgh) from the UPMC Health Plan.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-22-004, Evaluating respiratory virus vaccine effectiveness in a large, diverse healthcare system

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most-prevalent chronic liver disease worldwide and can progress to cirrhosis and liver cancer, but has no approved pharmaceutical treatments. The proposed studies are relevant to the mission of the NIDDK because they will identify novel mechanisms by which the gut microbiome regulates hepatic gluconeogenesis in states of health and obesity-related metabolic disorders. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will determine specific gut microbes and microbially-derived metabolites that regulate hepatic gluconeogenesis, with the goal of identifying new pharmacotherapeutic approaches to the management of NAFLD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: In response to concerns about access to and quality of care at VA facilities, the VA has begun to redirect resources toward financing care for Veterans outside of the VA. However, the quality and cost of care for Veterans that will result from this “make-or-buy” decision remain a scientific unknown. We will evaluate this question in emergency department (ED) care, using natural experiments that quasi-randomly assign Veterans to VA versus non-VA EDs. In our preliminary work, we have found that VA EDs reduce elderly Veteran mortality by 50%, or 5 percentage points. We will estimate the effects of VA versus non-VA ED care on health outcomes, process measures, and cost. We will further assess factors that influence these outcomes and evaluate mechanisms modifying the effect, such as staffing and care coordination. This research will help guide policymakers to optimally direct resources toward VA or non-VA care, and to tailor choices regarding non-VA contracting or VA investment to local conditions, with the goal of maximizing Veteran health outcomes.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: WESTERN MICHIGAN UNIV SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative  In 2021, an estimated 391,827 pediatric patients treated by emergency medical services personnel received an incorrect drug dose, with many suffering adverse drug events. Previous strategies and developed tools have failed to have a significant impact on this issue due to their failure to address the many common causes of error with pediatric medication administration in emergency medical services and failure to rigorously design and test solutions. Using a multidisciplinary team and a comprehensive design thinking process, we will develop and test a highly dynamic cognitive aid application for use through a head-mounted display to dramatically decrease pediatric medication errors in emergency medical services.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Augmenting the On-scene Medic (ATOM): Development of a head-mounted display application to reduce prehospital pediatric medication errors
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Improving access to high-quality care is a top priority for VHA, and the Veterans Choice Program (VCP) and MISSION Act are intended to increase Veteran access to care. However, access is difficult to measure, and correlational studies are prone to unobserved confounders. Our study leverages natural experiments, in the form of arbitrary administrative rules, that enable Veterans to access care outside VHA in the forms of Medicare and VA Community Care (VACC). We apply novel econometric techniques to identify a new measure of access and find the causal effects of increasing access on Veteran health care utilization and outcomes. Using linked VA and non-VA care data from CY 2007-2017, our results will show gaps in VHA services as well as the causal effect of expanded access for Veterans. The findings from this research will provide crucial information that VA must have to effectively implement the MISSION Act and provide high-quality care to Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative – Miami Center for AIDS Research The Miami Center for AIDS Research (CFAR) at the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine is applying for funding for 5 more years, representing a 4th renewal cycle. It is the only CFAR in Florida, a state with the highest rate of new infections in the U.S., and Miami is the epicenter of the HIV/AIDS epidemic, underscoring the need for a CFAR. The mission of the Miami CFAR is to advance HIV/AIDS research by providing scientific leadership and developing an infrastructure that fosters integration of basic, clinical, and behavioral/social sciences, promotes education and mentorship, and partners with the community and Florida Department of Health to prevent, treat and cure HIV/AIDS, ultimately to end the HIV epidemic.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Providence/Boston CFAR (Prov/Bos CFAR) is a collaboration between Lifespan/Brown University and Boston University/Boston University Medical Center leveraging our complementary and synergistic strengths to build a multidisciplinary HIV research portfolio. Our CFAR is particularly focused on marginalized populations including men who have sex with men (MSM), people who use substances, justice-involved persons, women, gender minorities, and at-risk youth both domestically and globally. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the ZEB2 gene cause an intellectual and developmental disability, Mowat-Wilson syndrome, which is characterized by developmental delays, intellectual disabilities, and various physical malformations. This work will identify the primary functions of the ZEB2 protein in human cells that are relevant to neural development and illuminate the impacts of gene changes found in children suffering from the disorder. The knowledge gained from the proposed work will inform future research, including diagnoses and potential therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Spatially resolved transcriptomics (ST), the Nature Methods 2020 Method of the Year, is poised to transform our understanding of how the spatial organization of cells in complex tissues influences function, disease initiation, progression, and therapeutic response. However, existing statistical methods to analyze these data fail to address new challenges, thereby limiting appropriate interpretation of these increasingly complex data. These urgently needed spatially-aware, unsupervised statistical methods and open-source software proposed in this award will enable ST technologies to transform precision medicine through novel biological insights relating to spatial properties of cell populations and gene expression in healthy and diseased tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Statement Our proposed studies will yield essential insights into early diagnostic biomarkers for ovarian cancer. This work will have important implications for early detection, which will have a direct impact on the precision prevention landscape for ovarian cancer. In addition, our studies will shed light on fundamental parameters that drive significantly lower survival rates for black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorders (AUD) and panic disorder (PD) are highly comorbid and debilitating mental health disorders that may co-occur because of shared underlying mechanisms, such as dysregulated acid-sensing. The goal of this project is to investigate the role of an acid-sensing mechanism in AUD-associated outcomes and determine if dysregulated acid-sensing contributes to development of comorbid PD following alcohol dependence. This study will improve our understanding of acid-sensing in AUDs and the development of comorbid outcomes, and identify novel therapeutic targets to better treat or prevent AUD and PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals living with serious psychiatric disorders often experience significant social-cognitive dysfunction secondary to mental illness, yet these impairments are not amenable to psychiatric medications and psychosocial interventions for social impairments are often difficult to access or otherwise limited in their scope or clinical benefit. Though social-cognitive impairment has known neural bases and is a recognized area of clinical relevance and unmet need, emerging evidence suggests that the cerebellum has a critical role in social- cognitive function that has largely been overlooked in the study of mental illness. The proposed study will examine a brain network model unifying dynamic interactions between cerebral and cerebellum brain regions involved in social cognition and the association of neural function to key outcomes in a transdiagnostic sample of individuals with mental illness, which has important translational implications for the refined identification of treatment targets most strongly associated with difficult-to-treat social dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL The Universities, Hospitals and Community Organizations in Rhode Island are well positioned to bridge the gaps between the worlds of clinical and basic science. Using the targeted resources of an IDeA-CTR Award, the Brown Institute for Translational Sciences, and a statewide consortium of collaborators, hospitals, universities, non-profit organizations and government agencies, will draw on the resources already developed in the NIH Institutional Development Award (IDeA) programs (core labs and faculty development programs) to enhance the Advance Clinical and Translational Research Program’s (Advance-CTR) ability to support clinical and translational research. We will serve as a bench-to-bedside research network and career development umbrella for the investigator community in affiliated institutions. In so doing, we will enhance patient-centered research and accelerate discoveries and health innovations to benefit our communities and to serve our State.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Although financial hardship (including financial stress, financial strain, asset depletion, and financial toxicity) is highly relevant for families of people living with Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's disease related dementias (ADRD), public health efforts to support these families are lacking. One reason for this shortcoming is that there is no systematic way to assess financial hardship for families affected by ADRD, precluding our ability to characterize the problem and identify families at risk for poor outcomes. To address this gap, we propose developing a new measurement system that can capture the multi-faceted aspects of financial hardship experienced by these families and be used to identify families at high risk for poor financial-related outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Wnt signaling is a rapidly evolving and important field of investigation and new regulators involved in this cascade are continuously being identified. Our study focuses on developing a mechanistic understanding of PTPRF-mediated regulation of Wnt signaling and intestinal stem cell function. Results from our studies will help identify new therapeutic strategies for treating Wnt-driven diseases by using PTPRF as a target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Socioeconomic disparities in physical and mental health problems are large, persistent, and severe and stem in part from adaptations to biological, cognitive, affective and behavioral systems necessitated by chronically stressful developmental contexts. Interventions attending to these adaptations and taking the context of a child’s development seriously are needed to address the ever-growing health disparities affecting low-income youth. The proposed study promises to further NIMH’s Strategic Framework on Youth Mental Health Disparities by improving our understanding of culturally affirming interventions with potential to treat internalizing syndromes and disorders, protect against biological embedding of chronic stress, and reduce mental health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will engage family caregivers to identify factors underlying preventable hospital complications in injured children and youth with special health care needs (CYSHCN). The study’s results will inform interventions to improve emergency care quality and reduce hospital complications in this population. The proposed research is therefore relevant to the NIH’s mission because interventions will enhance the health of injured CYSHCN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is a randomized controlled trial which will test whether a brief group-based behavioral intervention, called Resilience Training (RT), leads to sustained reductions in subclinical psychotic symptoms (“psychotic experiences”) and other transdiagnostic symptoms of psychopathology, and linked changes in emotion reactivity, hippocampal connectivity and hippocampal responses, when compared to a psychoeducational control condition. The study will also assess whether RT positively impacts objective functional outcomes and the onset of psychiatric disorders over time and whether the hypothesized linked psychological (emotion reactivity) and neural (hippocampal connectivity and responses) mechanisms of RT mediate its effects on these functional and clinical outcomes. If the predictions of this project are confirmed, follow-up work can begin to implement RT within college campuses and other communities of young adults, providing one evidence-based, transdiagnostic tool for addressing the worsening mental health crisis in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nephrolithiasis is a common and painful condition with considerable morbidity the incidence of which is increasing among youth. The evidence base supporting management of common scenarios is weak due in part to the few urologists engaged in research. In this project, we leverage existing data and research infrastructure to accelerate the research careers of early-stage investigators and generate important knowledge of the course of non-obstructive kidney stones and the experiences after surgery to remove kidney and/or ureteral stones among pediatric patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will advance our understanding of how changes in brain cell function relate to malfunctioning decision-making in alcohol use disorder. The results of this research will guide future studies that seek to develop new treatments for people with or at risk of developing alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Adoptive cell transfer T cell immunotherapy has immense potential for treatment in several diseases, including cancer. Non-invasive quantitative imaging would be a powerful tool for evaluation of the impact of T cell modifi- cations and delivery routes, monitoring of off-target T cell accumulation, and stratification of groups of responders or non-responders to therapy on the basis of measures of T cell tumor accumulation. This project will pioneer non-invasive and quantitative tracking of adoptive T cell cancer immunotherapy using a new molecular imaging modality called magnetic particle imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will lead to the development and preliminary testing of a novel intervention, Geriatric Assessment Strategy for Ostomy Management and Adaptation (GA-STOMA), aimed at addressing unmet needs of older adults facing fecal ostomy surgery. Surgical teams are not trained to address the biopsychosocial needs of the rising number of older adults undergoing fecal ostomy surgery. The proposed intervention includes geriatric assessment and management steps to improve integration of geriatric principles into surgical care of older adults undergoing fecal ostomy surgery and will provide the training necessary to launch my career as an independent surgeon-scientist and national leader at the intersection of geriatrics and colorectal surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative We propose a randomized controlled trial of valsartan in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension and right heart failure. There are no current medications that change the natural history of right heart failure. There is ample evidence to suggest angiotensin receptor blockers may impact right heart failure, and - if confirmed by randomized evaluation - this would address a clear unmet need in heart failure management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinal degenerative diseases frequently cause failures in adaptation to changes in the statistics of visual input such as changes in the mean light level. The work proposed here aims to understand how visual adaptation operates under naturalistic stimulus conditions. This is likely to provide new insights into the diagnosis and treatment of disorders of the visual system and retinal degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Financial hardship is common in people with Alzheimer's disease and dementia and their families but brief, valid and reliable measures to screen for financial hardship are not available. Current measures of financial hardship are too general or specific to other medical conditions. This project will create a group of ten patient- reported and caregiver-reported measures using item response theory that will be able to screen for patient and caregiver financial hardship in Alzheimer's disease and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying specific forms and features of talk that may help or hinder partners as they navigate intimacy in the context of metastatic breast cancer (MBC) is a pivotal first step in understanding if and how communication can benefit individual and relational well-being within the understudied population of metastatic breast cancer patients (MBCPs). Using a communication-based approach, this project will provide preliminary data regarding the relationships between communication and sexual, relational, and individual well-being for MCBPs, and determine the feasibility of collecting data from partners of individuals with MBC. The findings of the pilot study will address the dearth of research on communication about sexuality among MCBPs and identify forms and features of communication that patients find beneficial when navigating sexuality and intimacy in their relationship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Among patients with posttraumatic stress disorders and substance use disorders (PTSD/SUD), reductions in PTSD symptom severity are associated with less subsequent substance use. The goal of this pragmatic Hybrid Type I randomized clinical trial is to compare treatment as usual with prolonged exposure, a gold standard PTSD therapy, delivered in a massed format (i.e., multiple sessions per week where patients complete PE in 2- 4 weeks instead of 3-5 months) to treatment as usual for patients with PTSD/SUD in intensive outpatient treatment at Gateway Community Services, Inc., a nationally recognized SUD treatment program. The successful completion of this project can help change the practices that drive treatment for patients with SUD/PTSD, yielding a high public health impact for a challenging comorbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Autoantibodies initiate inflammation and tissue injury in patients with autoimmune disease. This proposal will define how the ubiquitin ligase Itch regulates metabolic pathways in B cells that distinguish selection of foreign-antigen specific as compared to autoreactive B cell responses. Information from completion of these studies is the essential first step in designing therapies that could specifically inhibit autoantibodies in patients with autoimmune disease without affecting B cell responses to foreign antigens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many pathogenic and symbiotic bacteria require the metal manganese to survive in eukaryotic hosts, like mammals and plants. This project will determine the mechanism of action of a small protein of only 42 amino acids in manganese homeostasis in the model bacterium Escherichia coli. As small proteins are a newly-recognized class of proteins with unique features that could be exploited as biotechnology reagents, this study will not only increase understanding of bacterial survival and growth in stressful environments, but will provide insight into a poorly- understood type of gene to expand fundamental knowledge of how cells work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Five percentage of pregnant women have clinically severe disordered eating symptoms, with devastating consequences for both mother and infant, and high societal cost. This proposed research will identify which disordered eating symptoms are most problematic and frequent for driving disordered eating in pregnant and postpartum women, and develop and test interactive, relevant, personalized digital interventions for this high-risk population. This research has significant public health relevance to provide the first highly accessible digital personalized self- guided therapeutic to address the unique challenges that pregnant and postpartum women with disordered eating face and is relevant to NIH’s and IDeA strategic initiatives to develop personalized intervention and treatments, and to provide better healthcare access for women and infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Completing the proposed studies will provide an important proof of concept for a gene addition therapy for ABCA3 deficiency. We will gain new insights into how ABCA3 mutations alter the biology of human alveolar type 2 epithelial cells. In addition to developing a therapeutic strategy for this currently untreatable disease, these studies may also provide a platform for the treatment of other diseases of the surfactant system affecting newborns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) is a common and disabling psychiatric disorder; gold standard treatments leave many patients with ongoing symptoms and profound socio-occupational deficits. Mindfulness training is at the core of one of the best-evidenced BPD treatments, Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT), and mediates some of the therapeutic change seen with treatment. Accordingly, the proposed research will investigate whether an innovative mindfulness-based real-time fMRI neurofeedback intervention elicits change in the brain circuits associated with mindfulness to improve clinical outcomes in adults with BPD undergoing DBT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal has direct public health relevance since it proposes novel strategies to prevent and treat heart failure which is a major public health problem with a worldwide prevalence of 38 million. By identifying the underlying mechanisms of heart failure, our studies should allow rational development of effective therapeutic approaches to prevent myocardial fibrotic remodeling and heart failure. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of heart diseases worldwide.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Pelizaeus Merzbacher Disease (PMD) is a rare (1.9 per 100,000 live births in the United States) X-linked hypomyelinating leukodystrophy caused by pathogenic variants in PLP, which encodes proteolipid protein 1 (PLP1). As therapies emerge there is an urgent need for tools to discriminate disease severity in PMD early in the disease course, which is often the optimum window for clinical trial enrollment. In our project, we propose to develop a new PMD Severity Scale with face and construct validity through an informed consensus building approach among experts and validated for prospective application for its, validity and determine its context of use in future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE … When a person experiences heart and lung failure, he/she may require a life-saving treatment called Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO). ECMO is accomplished by hooking up the patient to a machine that functions like an extra set of heart and lungs, thus allowing the patient to recover their own heart and lung function while being supported by an ECMO machine. Unfortunately, ECMO support often is associated with brain injury leading to major disability or death. Our work will investigate the cause of this brain injury and ultimately, if we are correct, help avoid or decrease it. Using an innovative brain imaging system called “portable MRI” that can be performed at the patient’s bedside, as well as blood tests that can detect early on ongoing brain insults, we will examine whether rapid and large reductions of carbon dioxide levels in the blood contribute to ECMO-related brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD8+ T cells are critical to the anti-tumor immune response, with therapies targeting these cells providing substantial clinical benefit. A specific subset of these cells, marked by expression of TCF1, is critical to their therapeutic effect; however, how this population is generated and maintained remains unclear, limiting its potential. This project aims to identify core characteristics of these TCF1+ cells, as well as identify and validate key proteins controlling their generation and anti-tumor function for future in depth analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Teleophthalmology using retinal cameras in primary care clinics has been shown to improve diabetic eye screening rates and visual outcomes, but remains greatly underutilized in the U.S. This multi-center randomized controlled trial proposes to test the effectiveness and generalizability of a promising implementation program (I- SITE: Implementation to Sustain Impact in Teleophthalmology) for sustaining increased diabetic eye screening rates using teleophthalmology in rural health systems. This research seeks to identify methods for successful integration of telemedicine technology into rural primary care workflows to prevent blindness from diabetes, the leading cause of blindness among working-age U.S. adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Photoreceptors are the main detectors of light that relay visual information to the brain. This proposal investigates the key molecular interactions that mediate selective wiring of photoreceptors to their respective synaptic targets. The long-term goal of this research is to uncover the molecular basis of retinal wiring in order to devise new forms of therapies to treat and restore vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Within a decade, many blind individuals are likely to be offered a wide range of options for sight restoration - including electronic prostheses, gene therapy and optogenetics. However the vision provided by almost all of these technologies will differ substantially from normal sight. The question of this proposal is – What role can cortical plasticity play in helping patients make use of the artificial visual input provided by sight recovery technology?

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current project examines the neural basis of Braille reading in proficient congenitally blind adults, late blind readers with varying degrees of proficiency and blind children learning to read, using fMRI and high-density diffusion imaging (dMRI). IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Identification of the synaptic loci that control critical periods of enhanced plasticity is required to improve the success of treatments for amblyopia. Here we propose a series of experiment to test a provocative new model in which the initial response to monocular deprivation during the critical period is a rapid, transient and synapse-specific elimination of local L2/3 PyràPV INs synaptic connections. We propose that this early elimination of local L2/3 PyràPV INs excitatory synapses is obligatory for subsequent changes in ocular dominance and spatial acuity induced by monocular deprivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Central retinal artery occlusion is an acute emergency that results in retinal cell death via a number of mechanisms. Preventing retinal cells from dying is a major public health necessity. Our objective is to study mesenchymal stem cell secreted extracellular vesicles (EVs) as a therapeutic tool to prevent the loss of vision from central retinal artery occlusion, wherein we plan to develop functionally engineered EVs (FEEs) for retina- specific protective actions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is a group of genetic disorders that are particularly common in Puerto Rico and are characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, excessive bleeding, and in many cases a fatal lung fibrosis and/or immune deficiency. The symptoms result from the failure to form certain specialized membrane structures, or organelles, within affected cell types. This proposal uses the melanosome, a target organelle within pigment cells, as a model system to understand how the products of the genes that are disrupted in Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome patients normally function together to generate specialized organelles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite advances in targeted therapies and immunotherapies, cancer remains a clinical challenge, indicating a need for new targeting modalities. In this proposal, we will determine whether activation of a toxic RNase, SLFN12, is controlled by dimerization, or linking of two SLFN12 proteins together. Our ultimate goal is to investigate whether SLFN12 can be turned into an anti-cancer agent by dimerizing SLFN12 specifically in cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Vertebrate vision starts with a photochemical isomerization reaction involving proteins known as visual pigments that contain retinaldehyde as their chromophore. Despite the fundamental nature of the process and its relevance to human physiology and disease, many of its properties remain poorly understood. Here, we employ a host of new approaches enabled by the development of novel experimental tools to address critical questions pertaining to the functioning of the visual pigments as well as their abnormalities in retinopathies.
