IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Embryonic stem cells (ESCs) form the basis for transformative cell therapies for retinal blindness, which affects over 300M worldwide. Yet the time-dependent mechanisms by which ubiquitous chromatin modifiers and embryonic transcription factors (TFs) interact to direct ESC retinogenesis remain unknown: the proposed research focuses on how the chromatin regulator WDR5 interacts with p53 and MAX, broadly expressed TFs, to control retinal development. Successful completion of the research will advance key concepts related to birth defects of the retina in p53-associated syndromes, current clinical trials that transplant p53 mutant ESC-derived retinal cells in individuals with macular degeneration, and potential off-target effects of WDR5 inhibitors, which are currently in therapeutic development through a $1 billion effort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is marked by metabolic dysregulation and a well-known comorbidity in female breast cancer. Interestingly, obese mammary adipose tissue contains significantly thicker and aligned collagen I fibers, which might drive breast tumor innervation, as neurites are known to prefer extending along aligned extracellular matrix fiber organization. The overall goal of this supplement research is to probe the specific effects of obesity-driven altered extracellular matrix topography in breast tumor innervation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Research into the human microbiome has begun to show that microbial modification of host molecules can affect health and disease. We recently discovered that the microbiome modifies host bile acids by acyl-conjugation of the steroid core with amino acids, creating a hidden and diverse component of the human bile acid pool. This project will deeply explore how these molecules are made and how their bioactivity can alter inflammatory signaling in disease models to better understand their role in human health and potential use as drugs to treat GI disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many urban settings including Baltimore face dual opioid and HIV epidemics, one among older predominantly minority PWID who are disproportionately affected with HIV, and an emerging epidemic among younger white individuals living in suburban Baltimore who are at high risk for HIV. The findings from this study will inform both interventions targeting new PWID populations at risk for HIV as well as programs to optimize engagement of PWID in care and treatment for not only for HIV but for non-communicable diseases which will improve overall health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on defining the neuroadaptations that underlie cocaine use disorder. These studies will determine how activity of a gene called Rac1 disproportionately effects cocaine-activated neurons compared to food-activated neurons, and may form a foundation for new strategies for treating cocaine use disorder. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal and infant health are a growing concern worldwide, especially related to underserved populations. The research proposed will attempt to assess the impact of socioeconomic, demographic, policy, health, and healthcare factors on maternal and infant health, using geospatially explicit modeling techniques across the state of Idaho. By better understanding the spatiotemporal interactions and effects of these set of variables on maternal and infant health, we seek to provide more quantitatively focused recommendations to policymakers, community leaders, and others who shape the decisions effecting women’s overall health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Image-guided thermal ablation treatment is a minimally invasive, low cost, and accessible renal cancer treatment for patients including those who are too ill to be candidates for surgery or radiotherapy. However, it remains under-utilized due to relatively higher post-procedure recurrence rates when compared to traditional intervention, such as surgical resection. The proposed research program aims to curate a large database of intra and peri-procedural ablation imaging that will be used to develop computer vision algorithms for improving treatment efficacy and broaden the applicability and success of these treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance Phosgene gas is a terrorism and warfare agent and, due to transport and industrial accidents, has injured many Americans. Currently, no effective treatment for phosgene gas-induced lung injuries is available. Our proposal will identify and optimize potential therapeutic lead compounds that mitigate lung injury and inflammation in mice and swine for future development as a human treatment of this devastating injury under the United States Food and Drug Administration’s (US FDA) animal rule.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer kills more than 40,000 individuals annually in the US alone, largely because most patients that have advanced estrogen receptor (ER)-positive breast cancer have tumors that develop so-called ”endocrine resistance” to anti-cancer therapy. We have identified three previously unknown types of ER mutations in advanced tumors in multiple patients, and found that they directly make these tumors endocrine resistant, which poses a major problem in the clinical setting. This proposal aims to study these novel ER-mutated tumors and determine 1) how the mutations make tumors resistant, and 2) whether they will respond to the newest class of anti-cancer drugs; the ultimate aim is to find the best therapeutic approaches to transform clinical care for patients whose tumors have these novel ER-mutated tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sarcoidosis is an enigmatic disease that varies from mild to life-threatening, is difficult to diagnose and even more difficult to predict. Our project aims to identify biomarkers that can help us accurately diagnose and characterize patients, particularly those most likely to be severely affected, and also to understand disease mechanisms. This project will capitalize on our unique combination of unmatched data, cutting-edge technologies, and dedicated researchers to lay the groundwork for diagnostic, prognostic, and treatment advances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This research aims to pinpoint genetic mutations and cellular mechanisms involved in the emergence of vascular malformations. Specifically, we propose to identify variants that function collaboratively with RAS activation to promote abnormal growth and aberrant organization of endothelial cells and to seek novel therapeutic drugs to treat vascular malformations. This research is directly relevant to the NIH mission: to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will establish the relationship between blood, liver, and skeletal muscle levels of iron, the onset of cellular declines, and the mechanistic pathway(s) that lead to a reduction in the work capacity across iron levels. The work is relevant to public health and the NIH mission because iron deficiency is the most common micronutrient deficiency in the world, is common in life stages including women of reproductive age and children, and may contribute to skeletal muscle impairment before iron biomarkers are compromised.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are over 7 million homebound older adults with serious illness who suffer from untreated symptoms such as pain, shortness of breath, or symptoms of dementia (e.g., agitation and sleep disturbance), and their caregivers are often not empowered to assess symptoms or know when or how to reach out to primary care teams for assistance. The objective of this proposal is to empower caregivers in symptom assessment and prevent symptom crises by co-designing and pilot testing a digital symptom assessment tool with caregivers and primary care teams of homebound, low-income older adults with serious illness. Findings from this study will inform the design and implementation of digital symptom assessment tools and other novel digital interventions to improve the care of homebound older adults with serious illness and their caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Community agencies that provide support to socioeconomically disadvantaged communities have tremendous potential to help their clients who use tobacco get help in quitting tobacco. Pragmatic research can help identify strategies community agencies can use to connect their clients with evidence-based tobacco use treatments. This project will first refine and pilot test promising strategies designed to engage social service workers and clients in tobacco quitline referral, and then will evaluate these strategies in a randomized controlled trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a debilitating neurodegenerative disorder affecting more than 40 million people world-wide but for which we lack drugs to slow disease progression. AD drug development is limited by our poor understanding of the biology that cause this disease. Here we take an open approach to catalyze drug development by developing and openly distributing high-quality reagents for evaluation of a diverse set of next generation AD drug targets across the research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although the clinical high risk for psychosis (CHR) criteria offer an important public health target and opportunity to prevent psychotic disorders, drug development tools (DDTs) need to be tested for use in Phase 2 clinical trials before new medications can enter clinical practice. The 15 US sites of the Psychosis Risk Outcomes Compound Assessment Network (ProCAN) will test DDTs from the Accelerating Medicines Partnership® Schizophrenia Observational Study in one or two 16-week proof-of-principle clinical trials. Study drug signal on outcome measures, biomarkers, and safety will also be evaluated; in addition, in partnership with the Clinical Trials Data Processing, Analysis, and Coordinating Center, ProCAN will deliver outcome and biomarker metrics that are analyzable to detect drug signal upon trial completion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This cross-over study will test a culturally-tailored diet for Hispanic/Latino (H/L) patients with ulcerative colitis and determine predictors of response to diet therapy, including stool microbiome composition and polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) metabolism. By the end of this study, we seek to gain a better understanding of the role of individual patient factors as biomarkers of response to diet and to develop a blueprint for the development of anti-inflammatory culturally tailored diets for patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The findings from this study may guide food-based recommendations based on cultural background, stool microbiome makeup, and an individual’s capacity for PUFA metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Skipping the hospital: Acute hospital care at home for people living with dementia The harms of hospitalization are magnified for people living with dementia (PLWD) such that they have 5 times the odds of suffering an adverse event; acute hospital care at home (AHCaH) was specifically developed as a substitutive delivery model to avoid these common harms while receiving the care that they need at home and is now operating in 37 states. Few AHCaH efforts specifically target PLWD, and we propose a year-long enrollment 3-part model: 1) in-home serious illness conversation and caregiver resourcing; 2) video and in- home acute illness evaluation on demand with in-home mobile integrated health paramedics, remote physicians, and home health aides; and 3) AHCaH as needed with additional resources for PLWD including additional home health aide care and delirium prevention measures. Our overarching aim is to implement and evaluate (NIH Stage III) a year-long pre-enrolled AHCaH pathway specifically for PLWD that will serve as a national model and will represent a paradigm shift in how hospital-level care is delivered to PLWD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) is a prevalent group of conditions may involve mental deficiencies from fetal alcohol exposure that typically persist for a lifetime. Vinpocetine is a pharmacological agent that improves neuronal plasticity and has been shown to improve cognitive deficits in multiple animal models of FASD. The proposed studies are designed to determine the effective dose of vinpocetine and to obtain preliminary data on safety and efficacy of vinpocetine for treatment of FASD in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project is designed to test a brief therapy to reduce suicidal ideation among a diverse sample of youths ages 12 to 17 who experience anxiety or depression. The goal of the study is to conduct two clinical trials testing whether this therapy reduces suicidal ideation and related beliefs that one is a burden on others. This project will contribute to the field by potentially showing evidence supportive of a brief strategy to reduce suicidal ideation in a way that can be readily understood and used by mental health providers in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The risk of developing classic Hodgkin lymphoma has increased in persons living with HIV whose HIV is well- controlled by combination anti-retroviral treatment. Our proposal investigates how benign and classic Hodgkin lymphoma lymph node samples, with respect to RNA and protein expression in the non-malignant cells in the tissue samples, differ from those in people without HIV. Our proposed study will eventually help in reducing the risk of developing classic Hodgkin lymphoma in persons living with HIV.

PHR: Development of an integrated informatics and data infrastructure for women’s precision health Project Narrative The proposed program will leverage past women’s health cohort and intervention study data to develop an integrated environment for storage, management, integration, and analysis of metabolomics, genomics, proteomics, microbiome, clinical biochemical, and patient personal phenotypic data, for precision health research. The integrative tools will include a research database, software, and cloud-based infrastructure designed to facilitate machine learning and AI data analytics; a dashboard to support monitoring, measuring, analyzing, and visualizing data - providing improved data interfaces and interoperability workflows to support research into the relations between women’s genetics, environment and health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a need for interventions that can mitigate mustard induced chemical burns and resolve secondary immune reactions. The strategy couples a methodic algorithm in three successive models with robust clinical endpoints to down select and deliver an optimized Synthetic Melanin Particle (SMP) lead drug for healing the skin. These studies will enhance our understanding of how to effectively treat skin damage after exposure to mustard agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor stem cells are the major players involved in tumor metastasis, immune evasion, therapeutic resistance, and relapse and therefore are closely related to cancer deaths. In the proposed R03 application, we aim to study a new mechanism on how tumor stem cells mask immune macrophage activation and metabolism via actively transferring their malfunctional mitochondria into macrophages. Successful completion of the project will determine a way forward in the development of new therapeutic strategies against tumor stem cells and tumor macrophages and is of paramount importance for cancer community.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance) Significant expense and effort by groups of scientists around the world has identified regions of the human genome that are associated with the genetic risk for various forms of cardiovascular disease, including coronary artery disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Equity of access to soon to be approved gene therapies for sickle cell disease is hampered by the costs and logistics of collecting sufficient bone marrow stem cells for gene modification and infectious and transfusion- related risks posed by the time until bone marrow recovery. Improving stem cell homing to and lodging in the bone marrow would mitigate these barriers. This proposal examines whether returning the immune and accessory cells that are removed with the gene modification process along with the stem cells will improve the stem cells’ bone marrow homing and lodgment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Converging lines of evidence indicate that chromatin organization is dynamic during development, plays a key role in orchestrating the transcriptional programs that are necessary for lineage specification, and is critical for correct brain development and function. In this pilot project, we aim to utilize a human stem cell model of CTCF- related disorder (CRD), a rare neurodevelopmental disorder caused by mutations in the chromatin organizer CTCF, to study the role of this understudied protein in neural differentiation and brain development. This research promises to shed light on the molecular mechanisms underlying neurodevelopmental disorders that stem from dysfunctional chromatin organization, such as CRD, and offer potential insights into novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative High concentrations of the cytokine TGFβ in the tumor microenvironment contribute to cancer progression by facilitating tumor proliferation and metastasis while simultaneously inhibiting the function and differentiation of immune cells. Detecting and quantifying TGFβ in vivo would be a valuable diagnostic tool for clinicians as they assess treatment options and monitor patient responses to immunotherapy. The proposed 64Cu-Fc:TβRII PET radiotracer has the potential to fulfill this clinical unmet need.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Neurogenic osteoporosis is a common complication of spinal cord injury (SCI) that is associated with low impact bone fractures. It is concerning that more than 46,000 Veterans affected with SCI and are at risk of osteoporosis and possible low impact fractures. About fifty percent of all individuals with SCI will develop low impact fracture in their life time. The management of osteoporosis-related fractures can impose substantial economic burden on the health care system, the individual and the families. Previous studies did not succeed in reversing the process of bone loss after SCI. In the present pilot study, we will evaluate the effect of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation Resistance Training in combination with oral Vitamin D supplementation, on bone quality in Veterans with chronic SCI, using a randomized experimental design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic nucleic acids have emerged as a novel approach to treat human diseases that are resistant to treatment by traditional small molecule drugs. Molecular simulations can assist in the design and optimization of therapeutic nucleic acids by providing insights into and generating hypotheses about the atomic details of their mechanisms. We propose to improve the accuracy of computational models of therapeutic nucleic acids by enabling the efficient generation of accurate force field parameters for a wide range of covalently modified RNA residues—including glycol nucleic acid analogs that are important for the function of gene silencing small interfering RNAs—and to apply these in molecular simulations aimed at understanding how RNA modifications impact the ability of these compounds to recognize their target genes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Women Veterans who use VA healthcare face elevated risks of poor pregnancy outcomes compared to civilians due to higher rates of chronic medical and mental health conditions. Proactive planning and optimization of health prior to pregnancy can mitigate these risks; however, nearly 40% of pregnancies among Veterans are unplanned. Although national guidelines recommended routine assessment of women’s childbearing goals followed by tailored contraceptive and preconception counseling in primary care, these reproductive planning services are delivered infrequently in VA. This study is a multicenter pragmatic randomized controlled trial of “MyPath,” a novel web-based patient-facing decision support tool. MyPath is designed to be used by women Veterans prior to clinic visits to increase patient-centered reproductive planning discussions and facilitate high-quality decisions. If effective, this innovative, scalable intervention will improve delivery of guideline-recommended services as well as reproductive health outcomes in Veterans nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer remains the leading cause of death from cancer worldwide and current manual or robotic bronchoscopes provide limited or no direct sensor feedback. Hence, there is a need for safe, advanced sensing methods to monitor tissue-tool contact as well as tool position and shape during navigation, diagnosis, and therapy tasks. This supplement research will fulfill this clinical and technological need and will ultimately improve procedural safety, biopsy accuracy, and diagnostic yield of bronchoscopy by developing miniaturized soft optical sensors that can be integrated on the soft robotic bronchoscope developed in the parent grant. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This randomized controlled trial will be the first to examine the efficacy of an evidence-based Cognitive- Behavioral Therapy for Adherence and Depression (CBT-AD) treatment for altering microbiome-gut-brain (MGB) axis pathways in depressed people with HIV (PWH) receiving effective anti-retroviral therapy. Leveraging an evidence-based CBT-AD treatment as an experimental probe will advance our basic understanding of the MGB axis pathways whereby decreasing depression potentiates alterations in key neurobehavioral substates relevant to depression in PWH. Examining MGB axis moderators and mediators using multi-level, high dimensional data will support efforts to identify subgroups of individuals who may be most responsive to CBT-AD as well as inform the development of a new generation of pharmacologic and behavioral treatments for depression targeting the MGB axis in PWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: LAY NARRATIVE MCD, FSGS, MN, and IgAN are rare glomerular diseases of the kidney that cause serious illness including kidney failure and high mortality, generating enormous individual and societal burden. CureGN has assembled nephrologists, researchers with expertise in different scientific disciplines, and patients in a consortium that maintains and analyzes a large, longitudinal observational data and biosamples like blood, urine and images of kidney biopsies. This initiative has developed a critical infrastructure that will advance our ability to study, classify, characterize, diagnose, and treat primary glomerular diseases of the kidney.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Intervertebral disc degeneration is strongly implicated as a cause of low back pain. Current therapies address symptoms but do not restore native disc structure or function. Delivery of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) represents a highly translational therapeutic strategy; however MSC performance in vivo is limited due to low oxygen and nutrition. The overall objective of this project is establish the long term efficacy of an optimized MSC and hydrogel therapy for restoring disc structure and mechanical function, and alleviating symptoms, using a preclinical large animal model of disc degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria, which is caused by Plasmodium parasites, remains a major global health problem with over 600,000 deaths annually worldwide. Our incomplete understanding of the mechanisms underlying the slow acquisition of immunity to malaria has hindered efforts to prevent and treat it. This project investigates the effects of an immune-modulatory therapy on the T cell, B cell, and antibody responses to Plasmodium infection and vaccination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The regulation of the inflammatory response is critical in normal physiological processes but also in acute and chronic inflammatory diseases. We are proposing to test and molecularly dissect the contribution of a repressive regulatory factor, which responds to heme, a molecule essential for life and a major component of blood and muscle tissue in macrophages, a cell type of the innate immune system. We will determine its role using cellular and animal models of inflammation which will provide a better understanding of the inflammatory response, and will support the designing of more rational and effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical unmet medical need for safe blood thinning drugs that do not cause bleeding. This unmet need is especially important in kidney failure patients who require chronic vascular access to perform life- saving kidney replacement therapy via vascular access sites that are highly prone to blood clots and occlusion. The proposed research addresses this critical need by continuing the clinical development of a unique drug candidate, AB023 (xisomab 3G3), which has been shown in primate studies and early human trials to potently inhibit blood clot formation without bleeding side-effects, and therefore has the potential to safely prevent vascular access clotting and failure.

PHR: Narrative To help children with language delays and disorders, we need to understand the basic facts about language learning. The CHILDES project does this by allowing rapid searching for developmental patterns across a large database of transcripts from children learning language. We also provide tools for automatic speech recognition and automatic annotation of phonological and grammatical patterns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, is the most common chronic skin disease in children and the leading cause of skin disease burden worldwide. While highly efficacious, targeted systemic therapies have recently emerged for the treatment of moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis, there remain critical gaps in our knowledge about their long-term effectiveness and safety in pediatric populations. This project seeks to set the stage for comparative effectiveness research in pediatric atopic dermatitis by developing and testing the tools needed to conduct future pragmatic trials and multi-center observational studies in routine care settings, with the ultimate goal of optimizing treatment selection for young patients and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal promotes public health because although many men and women will experience venous thromboembolism as they age, existing treatment strategies do not incorporate their experiences, goals and values and carry important risks. Understanding older adults’ priorities for venous thromboembolism decision- making, examining the real-world outcomes of older adults with venous thromboembolism, and creating an aging-centered estimate of bleeding risk on long-term anticoagulation are all essential to develop a decision aid that facilitates individualized treatment decision-making. Thus, this project is consistent with the National Institute on Aging’s mission to develop and advance knowledge to improve the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of common diseases and conditions of aging in vulnerable patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative. Bipolar Disorder, defined by a history of mania/ hypomania (periods of elevated mood and energy), and characterized by heightened sensitivity to rewards and higher than normal levels of often risky, approach-oriented decision-making and behavior, is common, with harmful effects on health, but current treatments often do not work and can have unpleasant or intolerable side effects; therefore, better treatments are needed. Our overarching hypothesis is that mania/hypomania results from abnormally high activity and high levels of dopamine release in the brain reward network (RNet) but abnormally low (or no change in) levels of activity and dopamine release in the brain central executive network (CEN). We will test this hypothesis with multimodal neuroimaging studies measuring activity and dopamine release in the RNet and CEN; and relationships among these measures and indices of approach-oriented behavior, and mania/hypomania, to help develop new treatments that specifically target the RNet and/or the CEN, have fewer side effects, and more effectively reduce mania/hypomania and the likelihood of its recurrence in people with Bipolar Disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of the Ensuring Quality in Psychological Support and Mental Health Helping Skill–Service User version (EQUIP-SU) project is to develop a quality assessment tool that can be completed by people with lived experience of mental health conditions to rate the services they receive. Using a co-creation approach, the quality assessment tool will be developed with people with lived experience (the demand side of mental health services) and health system managers and policy makers (the supply side of mental health services). Successful development of a quality assessment tool will enable people using mental health services to provide feedback to managers and policy makers to improve decision making for strengthening mental health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Serum biomarker measurements have been widely used as diagnostic/prognostic indicators, but many markers are not sufficiently sensitive and/or specific to accurately identify the disease state. This project aims to build a machine perception nanosensor array platform technology to detect whole disease fingerprints from patient biofluids. The sensor technology will be optimized and validated for pancreatic cancer to improve diagnoses and biomarker discovery processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work will address key knowledge gaps about the clinical, geriatric, and ethical dimensions of need for hospitalized incarcerated older adults. We will leverage a unique dataset from a 5-state hospital network, spanning 25 years and thousands of hospital admissions, to define prevalence and trends in factors such as age, delirium, and advance directive completion. We will also conduct interviews to characterize the experience of hospitalization for an incarcerated older adult from multiple vantage points: patient, family, correctional officer, and bedside nurse. Finally, we will evaluate prevalence and contents of state and federal policies pertinent to the hospital care of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) is a uniformly fatal cancer, partially due to a highly immunosuppressive microenvironment caused by the adenosine (ADO) metabolism and signaling pathway. We will determine if antibodies or small molecules inhibiting CD39 and CD73 ectonucleotidases, adenosine receptor, or novel oncolytic herpes simplex virus (oHSV) vectors expressing adenosine degrading enzymes (ADEs), or a combination can inhibit the ADO pathway in a novel panel of mouse and human glioblastoma stem-like cells (GSCs) and immune cells in vitro. Finally, we hypothesize that the combination of intratumoral oHSV expressing an ADE plus systemic inhibitors of the ADO pathway will synergistically improve GBM treatment efficacy in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: During stroke, cancer, and other traumatic situations, many cells undergo necrosis and apoptosis after injury; the swift removal of these cells prevents tissue injury, inflammatory responses, and auto-immune responses, clears the wounded area, and promotes tissue repair. Necrosis is closely associated with neurodegeneration. Understanding the mechanisms controlling the recognition and engulfment of necrotic neurons will have important therapeutic implications in fighting chronic inflammatory and auto-immune diseases, and in treating neurodegenerative diseases and stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research addresses the critical issue of artemisinin resistance in Plasmodium falciparum parasites, which has emerged in east Africa, and which threatens antimalarial treatment and control efforts across sub-Saharan Africa. Our project leverages recent discoveries from genetic crosses to define the multigenic basis of artemisinin resistance and identify genetic markers of resistance to quinine, an alternative first-line drug for severe malaria. We will also assess the resistance risks of currently used partner drugs and identify which of the candidate therapeutics currently in clinical trials have the lowest risk of succumbing to parasite resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neglect of the Jackson, MS, water system has led to widespread water contamination in recent decades and potential downstream health effects. Many toxicants present in a contaminated water supply can contribute to cardiovascular risk via high blood pressure, diabetes, and obesity. We use innovative methods to quantify water exposures over 20 years for participants in the Jackson Heart Study and test their association with key cardiovascular and metabolic outcomes to inform policy interventions to reduce the impact of the water crisis on cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The scale and scope of scientific collaborations in the Human Islet Research Network (HIRN) bring together extraordinary resources to solve complex problems in type 1 diabetes (T1D). To capitalize on this initiative, extensive efforts are required to coordinate, communicate, and catalyze research effectively. This proposal to renew the Human Islet Research Enhancement Center (HIREC) provides the infrastructure and environment needed to accelerate progress and success in HIRN, transforming discoveries into strategies that prevent and/or treat T1D.

PHR: The overall goal of this project is to translate a laboratory-based apparatus and method into a stand-alone BreEStim device and to validate its clinical efficacy and safety for neuropathic pain management in people after spinal cord injury (SCI) in a single-center randomized controlled clinical trial. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will project will assess the usability, acceptability, and feasibility of remote monitoring technologies for supporting aging-in-place for rural low-income, African-Americans and their care partners. Study findings will contribute notably to the further development of innovative, connected, multi-sensor remote monitoring systems that can facilitate the activities of daily living of African Americans living with ADRD. Combining this technological support system with other services may increase the likelihood that African Americans living with ADRD can age-in-place while reducing caregiver burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Women are twice as likely to suffer from stress-related psychiatric disorders, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and depression, however, the neurobiological basis underlying this sex difference is unknown. The proposed research could provide evidence demonstrating how the neuropeptides orexins contribute to sex differences in stress and cognition and the mechanism behind sex differences in the orexin system. This project will have immediate implications for treatment, as orexin antagonists are currently used to treat insomnia; given the broad effects of orexins, targeting orexins may treat a broad range of psychiatric symptoms in a sex-specific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Myofascial pain syndrome (MPS), characterized by the presence of painful myofascial “trigger points”, is one of the most common forms of acute and chronic musculoskeletal pain, affecting 10-15% of patients seen in general medical clinics and as many as 85% of individuals at some point in their lifetime. Despite its clinical significance, the subjective nature of current diagnostic methods, together with the lack of objective markers of MPS, has hinders the precision of MPS diagnosis and treatment. This work aims to develop PET and MRI methods to identify novel imaging biomarkers of myofascial damage and the resultant inflammatory mediators that can diagnose and characterize MTrPs and the sources of pain in MPS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: Narrative. Exposure to metals/metalloids like arsenic, lead, and cadmium may be major risk factors for the development of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias. The goal of this project is to use advanced mouse models, which better capture genetic risk for Alzheimer’s, to understand how metals/metalloids may cause the disease and provide new strategies for early detection of at risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Discrimination in healthcare settings disproportionately affects aging Black adults and may exacerbate disparities in cardiovascular and cognitive health. This project aims to first quantify the impact of healthcare discrimination on cardiovascular conditions like stroke and myocardial infarction among Black adults aged 50 and older, then subsequently evaluate its impact on cognitive health. The research seeks to inform interventions and policies that can enhance equitable healthcare delivery, aligning with NIA's mission to improve the health of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Rensselaer Alzheimer’s Fellows to Accelerate Entrepreneurship in Life Sciences (RAFAELs) program will provide crucial training in commercialization of ADRD research, providing new courses and experiential learning in the practical aspects of advancing discoveries from early-stage startups and academic research to real-world applications.  By offering educational modules, guiding students in startup development and industrial internship, the program equips participants with the entrepreneurial skills and knowledge needed to navigate complex healthcare ecosystems in ADRD in both the short and long term.  In the short term, the Rensselaer Alzheimer’s Fellows to Accelerate Entrepreneurship in Life Sciences (RAFAELs) program enhances the potential for emerging discoveries to move from the classroom or laboratory into incubation and acceleration settings, ultimately strengthening their position for future commercial success while directly contributing to the application of knowledge to enhance health and reduce illness and disability in ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The development of well-trained, clinical researchers in neuroscience will foster better clinical trials design and thereby hasten the introduction of improved regimens for therapy and prevention of neurological disorders. The Clinical Trial Methodology Course in Neurological Disorders (CTMC) teaches best practices in trial development to groups of early-career physicians, psychologists, nurses, and biostatisticians. The CTMC brings rigor, new energy, and new highlights to a valuable program in the mentoring of tomorrow’s academic research leaders with a focus on diversity, equity, and inclusion for recruitment of faculty and participants.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to develop and assess the clinical potential of quantitative imaging biomarkers of masticatory myofascial pain syndrome. The proposed biomarkers are myofiber diameter, sarcolemma permeability and sarcomere length scale from the Random Permeable Barrier Model (RPBM) that we have developed for analysis of diffusion tensor imaging data of the muscle with varying diffusion times. We plan to further develop the data acquisition and analysis methods for the masticatory muscles, test the diagnostic performance for myofascial pain, and apply it to assessment of treatment response in masticatory myofascial pain syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: A significant portion of opioid fatalities occur at home, with many unwitnessed overdoses proving fatal. There is a pressing need for a device that can identify respiratory disturbances from opioid overdoses and promptly alert nearby individuals and first responders. To bridge this gap, we propose to develop ODAlert, a groundbreaking wearable device designed to sense the cessation of breathing due to opioid overdose, triggering an audio alarm that alerts nearby individuals and also contacting first responders, thus enabling timely intervention and increasing the odds of saving lives from opioid overdose.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Impaired renal microcirculation caused by urinary tract obstruction is a significant cause of childhood kidney injury. The concept that neonatal obstructive vasculopathy is associated with ET-induced activation of vascular smooth muscle TRPC3 channels is a new paradigm for understanding the pathophysiology of this important disease. The outcome of the studies proposed in this application may lead to diagnostic and therapeutic targets to prevent renal loss in newborns with urinary tract obstruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The project will address the means by which influenza virus is able to hijack the host cell to assemble new viruses from proteins and membranes produced by the cell. The project will specifically explore the interactions between host cell membrane components, the viral matrix protein M1, and certain conserved portions of the viral glycoprotein hemagglutinin, which is responsible for binding of the virus to the respiratory tract and entry into host cells, but whose frequent mutations have required vaccines to be continuously updated from season to season. Results will be used to accelerate the search for universal anti-viral therapies which are less susceptible to seasonal mutations of the virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The challenges and benefits of high precision surgery are starkly apparent in the brain where maximal resection is the primary therapeutic approach, the primary indicator of overall survival, and where healthy tissue must be preserved. Advancements in diagnostic and imaging capabilities must be matched by surgical practices to be effective. Our proposal focuses on an order of magnitude improvement in surgical precision by resolving the persistent challenges of a) identifying tumor boundaries b) targeting them with ultrasound, and c) establishing interaction between imaging and therapy systems to avoid and/or target critical microvasculature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 1 million older adults with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) live alone in the US, and little is known about their use of medications, support for medication management, or how to intervene effectively to optimize their use of medications. The objectives of this Beeson K76 proposal are to characterize medication use and medication management supports among older people with ADRD who live alone, to understand in-depth multifaceted perspectives on their use of medications, and to develop a stakeholder- informed clinical decision framework to support clinicians and guide future interventions to optimize medication use in this group. Ultimately, the information learned from this proposal will lead to the development of clinical interventions to improve quality of life and reduce medication-related harms for older adults with ADRD who live alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Fuchs Endothelial Corneal Dystrophy (FECD) is the major cause of progressive blindness from corneal endothelial cell death and the second most common cause of corneal transplants performed on the elderly (>65 years old) in the U.S.; moreover, women comprise almost 75% of patients undergoing corneal transplantation for FECD. In FECD, corneal endothelium, a layer of cells whose primary function is to maintain corneal transparency, is hypothesized to have heightened susceptibility to ultraviolet light and smoking that activate abnormal estrogen and melatonin metabolism and cause mitochondrial damage, leading to formation of abnormal cellular deposits and progressive cell death, intensified with aging. Understanding key regulators of these pathogenic mechanisms may facilitate development of pharmacologic treatment for FECD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression in older adults is often treatment resistant, despite many effective treatment options. In the Biotype-assigned Augmentation Approach in Resistant Late-Life Depression (BAARD) project, we will develop and test a treatment selection tool informed by an individual’s depression characteristics to improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic retinopathy, a prevalent microvascular complication, is the leading cause of vision loss worldwide. This project seeks to understand the mechanisms through which endothelial cells control interactions with leukocytes, and, thereby, the outcomes of diabetic retinopathy. This information is critical to improve therapeutic strategies for retinal diseases and to prevent blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal lays out a new approach to use optical technology to provide novel imaging and physiologic measures relevant to the pelvic floor muscle as a method to quantify and spatially distinguish the muscular dysfunction underlying female myofascial pelvic pain. Once validated, this approach may serve as an effective, non-invasive, and scalable method to assess pelvic floor muscle fitness and allow for the prospective study of changes in pelvic floor fitness following myofascially-directed therapies. The development of machine learning models will also attempt to predict individual responses to different treatments for myofascial pelvic pain using the spatial NIRS assessment of the pelvic floor, both improving the clinical care of the condition and providing novel insight into the disease pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral amyloid angiopathy is a disease which affects the small blood vessels in the brain and common cause of spontaneous brain bleeds. Previous research has shown that it is caused by unnatural clumping of the protein amyloid β and that it can be transmitted between animals in experiments, and possibly also between humans. In this research study we will investigate if amyloid β can also be transmitted between humans through blood transfusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Carotid artery stenosis is a leading cause of stroke, accounting for 10-15% of ischemic strokes across the United States. This proposal will utilize computational fluid dynamics (CFD) informed by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data to identify changes in hemodynamic parameters after carotid endarterectomy as well as plaque features that may predict higher stroke risk. A better understanding of altered hemodynamics in cerebrovascular disease, including before and after carotid artery revascularization will allow for better patient selection for operative intervention in patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Pancreatic cancer is the 4th leading cause of cancer related deaths and has a dismal 5-year survival rate of 10%. Lethality is attributed to early metastasis, late detection, and resistance to currently available therapies. This study seeks to understand mechanisms of therapeutic resistance, immune dysfunction, and metastasis in order to identify new rational therapies for pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: COVID-19 is characterized by heterogenous symptoms and outcomes, and identifying what factors determine disease severity is a top priority. The airway microbiome has emerged as a differentiating factor, with a less diverse, dysbiotic microbiome found early in more severe disease. This work aims to carry these associations to the species level, understand how comorbidities influence the microbiome, and leverage advanced machine learning to start identifying potential microbe-host interaction mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaping products containing Δ8-tetrahydrocannabinol (Δ8-THC), an unregulated psychoactive compound, are increasingly popular across the United States; however, little is known about their respiratory health effects. Evaluation of Δ8-THC vaping products is a public health imperative because vaping-induced thermal oxidation converts Δ8-THC into electrophilic quinones which may cause lung injury. Studies outlined in this proposal will determine the biological effects of Δ8-THC aerosol exposure on human lung cells, components of commercial products driving Δ8-THC oxidation to reactive quinones, and proteins covalently modified by these quinones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research project aims to characterize the development and functions of the murine uterine lymphatics: we hypothesize that the uterine lymphatics develop postnatally under molecular patterning guidance from uterine blood vessels and functionally, they maintain fluid homeostasis within the uterine environment throughout estrous phases and pregnancy and are essential for successful embryonic implantation and gestation. This study has the potential to not only address the dearth of academic knowledge on uterine lymphatics but also provide novel understanding of the basis of uterine fertility and disease from the lymphatic perspective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Microorganisms use protein assemblies to produce diverse molecules that serve humanity as antibiotics, anticancer agents, and antivirals. This study aims to uncover how these assemblies select their small molecule inputs that are then transformed by the team of proteins into the programmed structurally complex output. Information from these studies will be used to strategically engineer these protein assemblies to incorporate desired molecular inputs, which in turn will unlock sustainable routes to new medicinally important molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Mindfulness meditation delivered by smartphone app has the potential to improve psychological wellbeing and decrease psychological distress at scale among young people placed in the legal system. Our team recently conducted a successful single-site feasibility trial of a mindfulness meditation app designed with and for youth on probation in Chicago Cook County, but now faces key barriers to running a fully-powered trial that can produce effectiveness and implementation data generalizable beyond a single site. The proposed multi-site feasibility trial will systematically expand our protocol into rural and urban counties in Oregon and New York, evaluating key feasibility benchmarks and setting the stage for a fully-powered hybrid type 2 effectiveness-implementation trial with youth placed on probation across the West Coast, Midwest, and East Coast.

This will also allow the patient to be supported while they are waiting on the transplant list. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mild cognitive impairment is common in older adults and can affect a person’s ability to understand, reason and appreciate the consequences of a decision. The goal of this proposal is to adapt, refine and test a deep brain stimulation surgery decision aid that addresses cognitive weaknesses and improves decisional outcomes for people with Parkinson’s disease. Our decision support tool will serve as a model for improving decision- making and care for older adults with neurologic disease and cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thousands of common genetic variants have now been robustly associated with neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders, including autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and schizophrenia, yet translating these genetic findings into a concrete understanding of the biological mechanisms underlying these disorders remains a major obstacle hindering clinical translation. To interpret these findings, substantial efforts have been undertaken to generate tissue- and cell-type-specific population-level functional genomic atlases linking genetic variants with nearby alterations in gene expression, splicing, and isoform changes. Here, we seek to develop new methods and resources to systematically characterize the regulation of alternative polyadenylation (APA) -- an understudied yet critical cellular mechanism for gene regulation and trafficking -- during human brain development and its contribution to neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) remains a debilitating and ultimately fatal lung disease; current therapies marginally slow progression and have very limited improvements in overall survival. The YAP/TAZ transcription factors have been shown to play a central role in fibroblast activation and matrix deposition, but they also play essential roles in other lung-resident cell types. We have devised a cell-type selective approach that has allowed us to identify novel molecules that inhibit the fibrotic activity of YAP/TAZ in fibroblasts, and our proposed work will further optimize toward a lead compound that can be developed in to an effective therapy for IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Bedside chest x-ray radiograph (CXR) is the most often requested imaging examination for the commonly encountered pulmonary diseases in the intensive care units (ICU) and is also routinely used for the assessment of various catheters and tubes. However, the diagnostic values of CXR are low and are severely limited by structural/anatomical overlaps and are further compromised by superposition of devices, tubes and catheters that are common for ICU patients. The aim of this proposal is to develop the world’s first mobile 3D digital tomosynthesis scanner to provide better diagnosis at the patient’s bedside in ICU.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the key features of asthma is exaggerated airway narrowing by hypercontractile airway smooth muscle. Our group has shown that smooth muscle cells transmit force to the surrounding airway via tethering proteins such as integrin α2β1. This research proposal aims to design, screen, and validate novel small molecule inhibitors of integrin α2β1 with the goal of improving therapeutic options for the treatment of asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is an age-related neurodegenerative condition characterized by the impairment of microglia, the cells responsible for clearing protein aggregates. This proposal aims to uncover novel microglial regulators that are disrupted in AD: the F99 phase will investigate the role of the RNA binding protein, Quaking, in AD progression, while the K00 phase will shed light on the significance of the lipid, PI3P, in microglial membrane dynamics. These findings have the potential to advance the treatment of AD by identifying novel therapeutic targets and shedding light on the molecular mechanism influencing microglial function in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of adults above 65 years of age report communication challenges, including age-related declines in speech motor control and motor speech problems caused by neurodegenerative conditions such as Parkinson’s disease. Given that efforts to develop effective treatments are hindered by a lack of data on how aging affects speech motor learning and control, this project investigates in patients with deep brain stimulation implants and in typically aging individuals which neural circuits and sensorimotor processes involved in speech production are affected by the aging process. The findings will inform effective motor learning-based behavioral and neuromodulation approaches to prevent and ameliorate aging-related speech motor difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to advance our understanding of how the brain prioritizes information from cluttered visual environments to guide ongoing behavior. This process, broadly referred to as selective attention, is impaired in several clinical populations, including individuals with spatial neglect after stroke, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), schizophrenia, and autism spectrum disorders (ASD). By better understanding the separable neural processes that contribute to selective attention, we hope to generate more pointed hypotheses about its dysfunction, leading to more effective treatments and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: LAY NARRATIVE  MCD, FSGS, MN, and IgAN are rare glomerular diseases of the kidney that cause serious illness including kidney failure and high mortality, generating enormous individual and societal burden. CureGN has assembled nephrologists, researchers with expertise in different scientific disciplines, and patients in a consortium that maintains and analyzes a large, longitudinal observational database and biosamples like blood, urine, and images of kidney biopsies. This initiative has developed a critical infrastructure that will advance our ability to study, classify, characterize, diagnose, and treat primary glomerular diseases of the kidney.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes (T2D) and cardiovascular disease (CVD) are major overlapping health concerns in today’s society. Therefore, developing novel drugs that treat both type 2 diabetes and thrombosis is a therapeutic priority. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NCATS because it proposes to develop LRRC8 complex modulators (SN-4XX) for to treat both T2D and thrombotic diseases to reduce stroke myocardial infarction in T2D patients. Exploring this therapeutic approach and testing a series of LRRC8 modulators will expand our understanding of novel therapeutic avenues and delineate an innovative target for the treatment and prevention of diabetes and cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) are devastating disorders, and therapies that slow or stop disease progression are urgently needed. Vaccines that generate anti-Aβ and anti-tau antibodies are a promising strategy, however vaccine design is stalled because of problematic inflammatory responses, which AD patients are already highly susceptible to. We will develop a new peptide nanofiber platform as a safe and effective vaccine strategy for inducing non-inflammatory protection against AD/FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proper temporal and spatial regulation of chromatin is key in human development and health, and dysregulation leads to diseases such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease, and developmental, neurological, and immunological disorders. The proposed research project will further our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that alter the structure and accessibility of chromatin. These studies will contribute to fundamental knowledge about mechanisms of gene regulation and how dysregulation leads to disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Pancreatic cancer has emerged as a major public health problem, and unfortunately, the incidence is rising. Most patients present with advanced tumors, and even those with small, surgically removable tumors ultimately succumb to pancreatic cancer, suggesting that pancreatic tumors spread (or metastasize) even before diagnosis in most people. Thus, new treatments are urgently needed and we propose the following studies to address this important unmet need: 1) To determine why pancreatic tumors behave aggressively and spread to distant sites, and, 2) To develop novel therapeutic approaches to treat, or even prevent, these highly lethal tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Brain development requires the establishment of synaptic connections between neurons, which by mediating data flow and storage in the brain, ultimately underlie cognition and emotion. Adhesion-GPCRs (A-GPCRs) are a large family of cell-adhesion proteins whose complex structures and signaling properties make them among the least understood cell-surface receptors, yet they play important roles in brain development and function and are linked to many human diseases, making them potential therapeutic targets. We will uncover the roles and signaling mechanisms of BAI A-GPCRs in orchestrating the formation, refinement, and plasticity of synaptic connections in brain circuits important for learning and memory; results from this study could impact human health as BAI A-GPCRs are implicated in autism, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and cognitive performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COPD is a leading cause of death worldwide and is linked to inflammation, yet the influence of fatty acid- derived compounds that resolve inflammation (called “SPMs”) on COPD outcomes is unknown. The proposed work, utilizing samples from the NIH BIOLINCC biospecimen repository, will allow for a deeper investigation into the role of SPMs in improving health disparities and outcomes in COPD. Findings from this study may ultimately lead to new therapeutic targets aimed at modulating inflammation in COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic interventions, such as exposure therapy, reduce pathological fear in patients with anxiety disorders—but this fear reduction is often transient and vulnerable to relapse. Stress undermines exposure therapy by disabling brain circuits critical for extinction learning. The long-term goal of this project is to understand the circuit and cellular mechanisms by which stress undermines extinction learning, a program of study that is essential for improving the long-term efficacy of exposure-based therapies .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to pilot and assess an innovative, enhanced closed-loop health-related social needs (HRSN) screening and referral model designed to maximize the proportion of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes (T2DM) patients with HRSN who connect with and obtain resources from social service organizations to address those needs. The objectives of this proposal are consistent with the goals of the RFA-DK-22-038 to assess both the feasibility and acceptability of screening and implementing referral service linkages initiated within the context of the health care visit and assess the impact on both HRSN and T2DM outcomes. We expect that evidence generated from implementing and piloting this community-engaged, patient-centered model with form the basis for a fully powered study of this approach, contributing critical evidence for how safety-net health systems can advance health equity at the clinical, institutional, and community levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Loss of muscle and bone mass with age are underlying factors contributing to falls and fractures in the elderly, and these fractures are very costly in terms of both financial burden and quality of life. A critical barrier to progress in correcting the problem of muscle and bone loss with aging is a poor understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying age-related musculoskeletal dysfunction. Our goal is to address this problem by providing critical, new information on the molecular and cellular mechanisms that control these processes, and thereby improve scientific knowledge, technical capability, and eventually clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the observed epidemiological evidence linking fine particulate matter (PM2.5) exposures and Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD), we still lack a deep understanding of the neurotoxicity of the specific PM2.5 components and the molecular mechanisms involved. By using innovative targeted and untargeted exposure assessment, single- and multi-omics analysis, and cross-tissue approaches, our primary objective is to offer valuable insights into how individual PM2.5 pollutants and mixtures interact with biological responses across epigenome, proteome, and metabolome, ultimately contributing to our understanding of AD/ADRD. This knowledge can aid future endeavors aimed at shaping environmental regulations and health policies to reduce the risk of AD/ADRD associated with air pollution.

PHR: Project Narrative: Older adults with serious illness have high rates of anxiety and depression not well addressed by current paradigms of care. This study aims to implement Collaborative Care, a model of mental health care integrated in medical care, in the palliative care setting to improve the treatment of depression and anxiety among older adults with serious illness. This work will lead the way to sustainable, scalable approaches to improving mental health care in the medical treatment of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: A large percentage of children with Down Syndrome (DS) have obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) that is suboptimally treated by first-line surgical interventions. The persistence of OSA-related nightly intermittent hypoxemia and fragmented sleep may contribute to a cognitive impairment, reduced daily functional impairment as well as pulmonary vascular disease and myocardial dysfunction. We propose a randomized trial of oxygen therapy to treat obstructive sleep apnea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Food insecurity disproportionately affects those who have been historically marginalized and significantly contributes to poor health outcomes. Increasing awareness and access to programs that promote food equity by providing affordable healthy produce is a promising way to improve health outcomes and empower patients and communities to achieve better health and well-being. The goal of this proposal is to refine and optimize implementation strategies that connect families to food security nutrition support programs through medical clinics, and improve communication between the healthcare and healthy food access systems to support greater patient autonomy and self-efficacy to obtain, prepare, and consume healthy foods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal tests the hypothesis that exposure to brief periods of 100% oxygen will have an anti- inflammatory impact on the injured cervical spinal cord. We further hypothesize that combining 100% oxygen therapy with treatment with a perfluorocarbon molecule will result in neuroprotection as shown by reduced loss of neurons after spinal cord injury. We predict that this will improve breathing ability after cervical spinal cord injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it explores development of new approaches to target injured neurons for the treatment of brain disorders, with a focus on seizures and epilepsy. The proposal develops a nanotechnology-based approach that targets the increased activity of neurons during seizures to deliver drugs specifically to them, thereby increasing drug efficacy and reducing side effects. Therefore, this work is relevant to the mission of NIH relating to treating neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial and ethnic minorities with chronic kidney disease are more likely to progress to end-stage kidney disease, to be disproportionately burdened by health-related social needs, and to receive suboptimal transitional care including less initiation of home dialysis therapies. This application tests the feasibility, acceptability, and possible effect of multipronged intervention to address both care delivery and social risk factors that undermine home dialysis uptake in minority populations. The results will be used to inform further studies in care delivery to reduce health inequities in home dialysis use and improve the quality of life for patients with chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability of muscle and other tissues to respond to internal and external mechanical forces with the expression of specific genes that allow cells to adapt to their dynamic environment is critical for the development, maintenance, and function of these tissues. Building on recent findings that indicate that the cell nucleus itself contributes to cellular mechanotransduction, the studies proposed in this application will determine the molecular mechanisms responsible for the rapid expression of mechanoresponsive genes upon mechanical stimulation, define the role of nuclear envelope proteins involved in the force transmission between the cytoskeleton and nucleus in this process, and assess the functional consequences of impaired nuclear mechanotransduction in skeletal muscle. Insights gained from these studies will be critical to the development of new targeted therapeutic approaches for muscular dystrophy and other diseases caused by perturbed cellular mechanotransduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Minimal change disease (MCD), focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), immunoglobulin A nephropathy (IgAN), and membranous nephropathy (MN) are rare glomerular diseases that cause serious morbidity including kidney failure and high mortality, generating enormous individual and societal burden. CureGN has assembled nephrologists, scientists with broad expertise, and patients in a consortium that will maintain and analyze a large, longitudinal observational data set and biorepository. This broad effort provides a critical infrastructure that will advance our ability to study, classify, characterize, diagnose, and treat primary glomerular diseases of the kidney.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The timing and sequence of animal development are genetically controlled. While many genes identified in model organisms have been found to play conserved roles in organizing the sequence of developmental progression in all animals, we still have a limited understanding of how the precise timing of developmental gene expression is accomplished. Using biochemical, structural, and genetic approaches, experiments outlined in this proposal aim to characterize a novel biological clock that directly coordinates the timing and output of key developmental miRNA genes during animal growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose using exceptional resources and cutting-edge technologies to conduct the first proteogenomics study and the first prospective breast tissue-based nested case-control proteomics study to discover and validate breast cancer risk proteins. The biological functions of promising proteins will be further evaluated by a series of bioinformatics analyses and in vitro functional assays. Successful completion of this proposed study will unveil causal protein candidates for future mechanistic research, improve our understanding of the biological basis for breast cancer, and have important implications for disease prevention and treatment for this common malignancy.

PHR: Narrative Schizophrenia is a major neuropsychiatric disorder associated with long-term disability and excess mortality. Large-scale brain imaging data sets capable of addressing the underlying causes and identifying novel treatment approaches are lacking. This study leverages the ongoing NKI Rockland Sample II study to collect a large-scale multimodal imaging data set in schizophrenia which will be shared on-line to allow open investigation into causes and consequences of brain imaging abnormalities in schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project investigates the impact of sleep disturbances and physical frailty on the cognitive progression of older adults with subjective cognitive decline (SCD) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI), as well as the moderating effect of physical frailty on the relationship between sleep disturbances and cognitive outcomes. By exploring these factors, the study aims to shed light on the mechanisms underlying the conversion from SCD/MCI to Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). The findings will help to identify vulnerable populations and proposing public health strategies for delaying or preventing ADRD progression in SCD and MCI cohorts, with a focus on sleep and physical frailty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease- and related dementias typically show pathological changes in the cerebral cortex, affecting brain and vascular cells. Mutations in PSEN1 are the most common cause of early onset, heritable Alzheimer’s disease. We will construct a 3D human stem cell model in tissue culture that will include the major cell types affected in patients carrying PSEN1 mutations and test whether the model shows key features of patient pathology. The goal is to develop a reliable and reproducible model that leads to a greater understanding of disease mechanism and improves our ability to predict the safety and efficacy of candidate drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 76 million Americans use opioid drugs as analgesics for the treatment of long-term pain, and more than 2 million Americans now have opioid use disorder. This research program will identify and evaluate molecular mechanisms intimately linked to treatment of chronic pain, addiction, and withdrawal. Thus, this project has long-term potential to contribute significantly to managing two major problems in medicine.

PHR: Project Narrative  This research addresses a critical public health challenge by developing an equitable, high-accuracy AI tool for early glaucoma detection, particularly in underserved Black, Hispanic, and Latino communities where the disease is a prevalent cause of irreversible blindness. By leveraging advanced AI in readily available fundus photography, we aim to bridge a gap in glaucoma care, making early and accurate diagnosis accessible and affordable, thereby preventing avoidable vision loss across diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Prostate cancer (PCa) is a leading cause of cancer-related death in American men, with lethality due largely to castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). This study will develop degraders (PROTACs) that fully target/degrade EZH2, a major driver of late-stage metastatic PCa and evaluate their therapeutic potential in PCa models. In addition, we will exploit PROTACs as tool compounds to study the EZH2 biology in various stages of PCa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growing number of Americans over the age of 65 live with dementia, brought on by a set of devastating neurodegenerative diseases with overlapping pathologies and symptoms, including Alzheimer’s disease (AD), frontotemporal lobar degeneration, and other AD related dementias (AD/ADRD). While the ultimate molecular mechanisms driving neurodegeneration in AD/ADRD are poorly understood, our previous work and preliminary results demonstrate disruptions to nuclear protein quality control are characteristic of AD/ADRD and that the activity of nuclear ubiquitin ligase complexes control pathological tau, TDP-43, and other protein aggregation in disease. The completion of the proposed work will provide further insight into biological mechanisms underlying the role of BRD transcription factor degradation (F99) and, more broadly, the role of disruptions to nuclear protein homeostasis (K00) in driving neurodegeneration in AD/ADRD.
