IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PI: YU) Proposed study aims to improve the efficacy of existing rheumatoid arthritis antibody drugs by attaching a peptide that specifically binds to degraded collagens abundant in inflamed joint tissues (bones and cartilage). Antibody drug that can be localized to diseased tissue will exhibit high efficacy and low systemic side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research shows that group singing can improve health and promote happiness. We will develop, refine, and investigate the feasibility and acceptability of an online group singing intervention for adults age 60+ with brain disorders of aging (i.e., mild cognitive impairment) according to the NIH music-based intervention (MBI) Toolkit principles. Results from this study will support a larger, subsequent effectiveness trial that will rigorously evaluate our online MBI following principles of the NIH MBI Toolkit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our proposal utilizes mouse genetic, live-cell imaging, flow cytometry, biochemistry, and molecular biology approaches to identify 1) how Hpf1 and Parp2 collaborate to regulate Parp1 dynamics at DNA damage sites; 2) how HPF1 regulates the substrate and PAR chain structural specificity; 3) how HPF1 prevents PARP1 trapping induced hematopoietic failure promoting PARP1 release. The goal is to understand the complexity of radiation and replication-induced PARylatio and develop strategies (e.g., targeting Hpf1 compound catalytic site) to mitigate bone marrow toxicities in radiation and PARPi treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults frequently cite maintenance of cognitive function and prevention of dementia as their top health priority. This is highly relevant to cardiovascular treatment decisions as the modifiable risk factors for cognitive decline and cardiovascular disease overlap and early data suggest potentially differential treatment effects of cardiovascular therapies on cognitive outcomes. We propose to evaluate the effect of two of the most commonly prescribed cardiovascular therapies (Beta-blockers & Calcium Channel Blockers) on cognitive trajectory and risk for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias among older adults by leveraging existing longitudinal data from SPRINT MIND and prospective randomized trial data from the PCORI-sponsored LIVEBETTER pragmatic trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT Hypertension is a leading risk factor for global morbidity and mortality due to its effects on the heart, blood vessels and kidney leading to heart attacks, heart failure, stroke, and chronic kidney disease. These effects of hypertension seem to be mediated by an imbalance of pro- and anti-inflammatory cells of the immune system, but the precise mechanisms are unclear. By investigating what causes this imbalance and reversing it, this project can potentially lead to novel diagnostic and therapeutic targets for hypertension and related cardiometabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neural connectivity is altered in many, if not most, neurodevelopmental disorders, such as schizophrenia and autism. A mechanistic understanding of how the neural circuitry is formed is crucial in revealing how neurodevelopmental disorders emerge and discovering new approaches to treat these debilitating diseases. The work proposed here will uncover fundamental molecular mechanisms that regulate neural circuit development, and although our work is conducted in Drosophila, these processes and mechanisms are conserved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative African diaspora communities and other underrepresented populations have been poorly represented in large scale genetic and epidemiological research on serious mental illnesses (SMI), and yet these populations have the largest disparities in health care and outcomes. This study builds on a prior study of untreated psychoses in Nigeria and Trinidad, newly adding a cohort of patients receiving inpatient psychiatric care, and featuring a philanthropically- supported whole-genome sequencing aim. Comparative clinical and genomic analyses with data for US veterans and civilians with linked electronic health records, and with other diverse populations in Africa and globally will inform how biological and non-biological factors influence clinical presentation and health outcomes among individuals with psychotic illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Surgery is often deferred for older adults with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) given the higher risk of adverse surgical outcomes as compared to younger adults with IBD. These delays, however, paradoxically increase the risk of an adverse postoperative event when surgery is required. A better understanding of which older adults with IBD are likely to need disease-related surgery, which preoperative factors contribute to the risk of adverse surgical outcomes, and which barriers exist for timely surgery can shift this trajectory and help inform evidence-based interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application responds to the PAR-22-131 RFA by validating a minimally invasive, robust, multi-stage artificial intelligence (AI)-based cytologic, histologic and epigenetic (multi-omic) biomarker to identify oral premalignant lesions (OPL) with high risk of progression to invasive oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC). Our biomarker, named the PROSPECT score, will be validated in a massive data set and a prospective study in racially and socioeconomically diverse OPL patients. There is currently no reliable clinical, histologic or molecular marker to determine individual risk in patients with the same dysplasia grade. A reliable biomarker will optimize survival in patients by optimizing risk stratification of OPLs and encouraging closer surveillance of patients with high cancer transformation risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Heavy metal pollution by arsenic (iAs) and lead (Pb) disproportionally affects low income communities and minority groups nationally and internationally. We found that these metals alone and in combination, at doses much lower than the World Health Organization (WHO) recommended limits, promote the reprogramming of treatment responsive ER+/PR+ breast cancer to ER+/PR- treatment refractory disease. As nuclear ROS were found to be mechanistically linked to PR downregulation this project proposes to test new and existing strategies based on organelle-targeted ROS scavengers as adjuvant therapeutics to restore treatment efficacy thereby providing short term pharmacologic solutions for patients impacted by socioeconomic and environmental health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE As we age, our cells begin losing the ability to properly respond to environmental or genetic stresses, decreasing cell viability while increasing the likelihood of developing age-related diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, or Huntington’s. Here, we will study one of the critical cellular pathways that is involved in helping a cell recover from stress, pinpointing the critical signaling factors that enable the cell to return to a healthy state. The molecular definitions resulting from this work will provide an atomic-level roadmap for the development of targeted therapeutics aimed at treating age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In mammals, while DNA methylation levels at specific CpG sites correlate with age and have led to the development of epigenetic aging clocks, the causal relationship between methylation and aging-related phenotypes remains unclear. This proposal aims to refine these clocks by incorporating causality, using Mendelian Randomization to identify causal CpGs, and further harnessing protein language models in the K00 phase to understand and design proteins linked to longevity. The outcome could revolutionize aging research by distinguishing age-related damage from adaptation, leading to precise aging biomarkers and a new approach to treat aging through proteome redesign.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Spatially-resolved single-cell sequencing data have the potential to explain how cells communicate and interact, how cell state is impacted by its local environment, how specific dysregulation might eventually lead to disease, and how targeted interventions might modify cell state to treat disease. Our goal in this proposal is to develop spatial statistical methods to ensure that this potential is achieved; in particular, our proposed methods will i) create robust software to build multiscale, three-dimensional, queryable, cell-type aware, and reference- free atlases of tissues and organs from a handful of two-dimensional spatial genomics samples, ii) annotate these atlases by finding spatially-resolved expression patterns within and across cell types, and iii) quantify the influence of each aligned cell in the atlas on their local environment. In this proposal, we are motivated by existing data from mouse and human heart, mouse and human brain, and human brain tumors, where both common and rare cell types, expression gradients critical to tissue function, and essential cell-cell interactions are just beginning to be discovered and understood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Systemic lupus erythematosus is a complex autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of circulating autoantibodies to nucleic acids and proteins with which they associate. These antibodies form immune complexes that then activate white blood cells, including plasmacytoid dendritic cells that are important in lupus disease. In this proposal, we investigate how different autoantibody types contribute to immune complexes, activation of plasmacytoid dendritic cells, and lupus disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Many Veterans experience impairing symptoms of anxiety and seek treatment in the primary care setting, yet behavioral (non-medication) anxiety treatment options in primary care are quite limited. Primary Care-Mental Health Integration (PCMHI), in which mental health clinicians embedded in primary care provide behavioral treatment, can help bridge this treatment gap, but brief anxiety interventions that are compatible with PCMHI practice are needed. This proposal evaluates a brief anxiety intervention that is evidence-based, transdiagnostic (applicable to a wide range of anxiety symptoms), feasible for delivery in PCMHI (brief sessions), and Veteran-centered (tailored to Veterans and personalized to individual patients). This research addresses a major gap in VHA treatment options for anxiety and will facilitate high quality Veteran healthcare that improves clinical outcomes and patient experience. The intervention’s innovative modular design, in which Veterans collaboratively select which coping skills to learn, improves treatment engagement and acceptability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain is a major global health problem, causing a significant economic and social burden. To address the need for novel therapeutics to treat acute and chronic pain, we designed new peptide- based analgesics suitable for intranasal administration that combine selective opioid and antidepressant pain-relieving mechanisms. These novel peptide-based dual-mechanism analgesics may exhibit improved efficacy in treating pain while reducing negative side effects associated with the traditional opioid pain medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: IMPERIAL COLLEGE OF SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND MEDICINE
PHR: Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is the most common cause of congenital infection, leading to hearing loss and various developmental disabilities in affected newborns, with the potential for life-long consequences. Despite its substantial clinical and economic impact, our understanding of how HCMV crosses the placenta to infect the fetus remains incomplete, and the specific role of placental macrophages in managing or permitting HCMV transmission is especially obscure. This research will contribute fundamental knowledge about the mechanism and functional impact of HCMV infection in placental macrophages; vital in our efforts to develop preventative and therapeutic strategies against congenital HCMV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance) As the world's population ages, the search for cellular rejuvenation, a way to restore cells to a youthful state, offers hope for addressing age-related health challenges. This project aims to explore cellular rejuvenation mechanisms, emphasizing the rejuvenating potential of transcription factors in post-mitotic cells. The success of this work could lead to new and safer treatments, and the identification of universal rejuvenating factors with the potential to rejuvenate multiple tissues, setting a stage for translation into human therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) have significant difficulties with organization, planning, prioritizing, memory, and materials management which negatively impacts their educational performance (e.g., academic achievement, grades, etc.). Given that the lifetime cost for an individual with ASD is estimated to be $1.4 million per patient, with the largest of these costs for special education and parental productivity loss, there is a clear need for interventions that target increasing academic skills that lead to more successful outcomes. Developing psychosocial skills-based treatments that target academic success for students with ASD and their parent as they manage the increased demands of middle school may improve immediate academic and educational outcomes as well as buffer long-term impairment.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The study goal is to promote viral load suppression among women with serious mental illness (SMI) and HIV in Botswana, given that these women are especially vulnerable to psychiatric medication nonadherence and symptom exacerbation, which are made worse by stigma and threaten antiretroviral therapy (ART) adherence. We propose to test an intervention to reduce stigma due to the statuses of SMI and HIV, against an attention control condition, in the high-risk transition period after discharge from an initial psychiatric hospitalization. Enabling women with SMI and HIV to resist stigma has the potential to improve their HIV outcomes and empower these women to elicit broader, structural-level change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Xeroderma pigmentosum-Cockayne syndrome (XP-CS) is a rare, severe genetic syndrome that has characteristics of two classic DNA repair disorders that are usually clinically distinct: XP and CS. We have characterized a mouse model for one genetic subtype of XP-CS (XPG) and have designed a gene therapy vector to treat the severe neurodegeneration and extend lifespan in these mice. The goal of this project is to refine our gene therapy strategy to optimize efficacy and safety in preparation for translation of this approach into human clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Relevance to Public Health The Montana Tech Safety, Health and Industrial Hygiene Department provides high quality, accessible, science and technology curricula and research opportunities designed to prepare students for successful OSH and IH careers. This is especially relevant to our public health because the burden of occupational injuries and illnesses in the U.S. has been estimated to be similar to the burden from cancer and exceed that of AIDS, Alzheimer’s disease, and arthritis.1 Despite the tremendous burden that occupational injuries and illnesses have on our society, fewer than half of the anticipated OSH professionals needed in the U.S. are anticipated to graduate in the coming years.2 We’ve been working hard to meet this demand since our first program was established in 1975 and we continue to grow and produce more qualified graduates thanks in large part to the support of the NIOSH TPG program.

PHR: The outcomes of the proposed study will identify potential panels of miRNA biomarkers associated with early cognitive dysfunction, providing avenues for early disease detection through a simple and relatively unexpensive drop test. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it capitalizes on intentional music listening to test the feasibility of a clinical trial aimed at improving mental health and wellness in chronic stroke. Findings will have direct, translational implications enabling clinicians to design large-scale clinical trials that allow for the optimization of music-based interventions for mental health recovery in stroke. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: The overarching goal of the wHOPE (Whole Health Options for Pain Education) study is to test the VA Whole Health model for chronic pain care in VA. Across six geographically distinct VA healthcare systems, we will test a Whole Health Team approach that includes an integrative medicine provider, a complementary integrative health provider (e.g., acupuncturist), and a Whole Health coach who collaborate with patients to identify a multi-modal non-drug approach for chronic pain management. The comparator will be more traditional Primary Care Group Education (modified group Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Chronic Pain), and both will be compared to Usual Primary Care for pain care in VA. The enrollment target is 765 veterans, and the primary outcome is pain interference. An implementation evaluation and budget impact analysis will be conducted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative – To ensure genomic integrity, it is essential that DNA synthesis is efficient and error-free, and that DNA damage is bypassed quickly to maintain an active replisome. Therefore, cells have evolved several translesion DNA polymerases to respond to different lesions with limited processivity. Substitution of a high-fidelity polymerase for a translesion polymerase are multidimensional and rely on specific contacts for the initial recruitment, insertion, and extension processes; however, the molecular mechanisms for these events are unknown.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public health relevance: Approximately 50% of the human genome is constituted by repeats some of which contribute to genomic instability and DNA variation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project provides fundamental insights into how insulin regulates aging-associated genes. In addition, this project also sheds light on how aging shifts the cell response to insulin to promote metabolic diseases. Ultimately, this project has the potential to provide new genes or DNA elements as targets to achieve tissue rejuvenation, and new therapies for aging-associated type 2 diabetes and insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the sixth leading cause of death in the United States, affecting almost 6 million people which is expected to more than double by mid-century. The neuropathologic hallmarks of AD including β-amyloid (Aβ) plaques and tau neurofibrillary tangles accumulate in the brain decades before symptom onset, and drive downstream neurodegeneration, cognitive impairment, and death. Identifying genetic drivers of early neuropathologic changes like conversion to Aβ positivity (Aβ+) may lead to novel therapeutic targets useful earlier in the disease cascade when treatment is most effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Asian Americans with depression disorder frequently complain having co-occurring somatic distress, and there is no effective treatment for this co-occurring condition. This randomized clinical study will examine the feasibility, acceptability, and safety of integrating the Stress Management and Resiliency Training (SMART) with Qigong/Tai Chi (QTC) to treat Asian Americans with co-occurring major depressive disorder and somatic distresses. The findings of this study will provide the preliminary evidence for a large and more definitive study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: The US population has been progressively aging, resulting in prolonged duration of environmental toxicant exposures and a potential for increased vulnerability to new environmental insults. Consequently, there is a growing population at risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. This project will examine the effect of various pollutants, including wildfire smoke, microplastics, and heavy metals, on neurological conditions and multi-omic pathways leading to neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of older adults rely on care from home health aides (HHAs) to safely age in place, but high turnover and severe workforce shortages among HHAs increasingly prevent older adults from obtaining the care they need. Given a substantial body of evidence showing greater participation in workplace decisions is a key driver of HHA job satisfaction and retention, this proposal uses a cross-sectional survey to examine the role of home care cooperatives – businesses designed to prioritize HHA workplace participation – in HHA turnover, job quality, and care quality, and also designs and pilot tests a scalable digital training product aimed at enhancing HHA workplace participation. The project will also provide critical training and mentorship for Geoffrey Gusoff, MD, MBA, MS, an early career investigator seeking to be a leader in long-term care workforce innovation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neuropathic pain, a debilitating chronic pain condition that affects millions of individuals is difficult to treat and drugs currently used have numerous side effects, high abuse liability and limited efficacy. Here, we will establish a multidisciplinary team with relevant experience in drug development, translational pain research, pain biology and clinical trials and create the required infrastructure for the development of novel non-opioid, GPR34 receptor antagonists for the treatment of neuropathic pain.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: The neurovascular unit changes fundamentally during brain injury, which leads to neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this study is to develop and validate an inclusive Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease- related dementia (AD/ADRD)-focused measure of financial hardship for use by care contributors to sexual and gender minority (SGM) and non-SGM persons living with dementia (PLWD). A validated screener that is inclusive enough to capture the unique experiences of SGM PLWD and their care contributors in the context of AD/ADRD will help with the early identification of those at greatest risk of financial hardship and related negative physical and mental health outcomes. The increasing prevalence of older adults (SGM and non-SGM) with AD/ADRD, the growing diversity of the population, and projections that AD/ADRD is becoming the most expensive disease in the world suggest that this project has the potential to make a significant impact not only on the lives of SGM and non-SGM PLWD and their care contributors, but may also contribute vital knowledge to inform future programs and policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity increases the risk for pancreatic cancer in patients, and high fat diet increases pancreatic cancer progression in mice. However, the mechanisms by which obesity and high fat diet increase pancreatic cancer remain unknown. This study will examine how diets enriched in specific fatty acids alter the pancreas to promote pancreatic cancer initiation and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Those with Down syndrome (DS) are at markedly increased risk for Alzheimer disease (AD); this disorder is referred to as DS-AD. Studies in animal models of DS-AD have provided important insights into pathogenesis and have phenocopied many DS-AD features. Importantly, as for DS-AD, increased APP gene dose is necessary for DS-AD-related phenotypes in models. Nevertheless, existing models fail to demonstrate the amyloid plaques, congophilic angiopathy and tau pathology of DS-AD. Given the importance of these lesions we propose to create them by genetically modifying the TcMAC21 model of DS through humanizing the Aβ sequence in mouse APP and introducing a wild type of human Tau transgene. We will seek internal validation in Aim 1 and external validation in Aim 2. Go/NoGo criteria for internal validation in Aim 1 and milestones for both Aims are defined. Our hypothesis is that genetically modified TcMAC21 mice will prove to be a fully valid of DS-AD to support studies of DS-AD pathogenesis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will validate the use of a novel, minimally invasive, microchip/video recording system as a platform for testing migraine treatments. We will characterize the physiological and behavioral responses in 3 different migraine models and examine the effects of widely used acute and preventive migraine therapies on these responses. This platform will increase the accuracy and translational value of animal models for migraine for the discovery and characterization of new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delirium affects millions of hospitalized older adults each year and increases one’s risk of dementia, functional decline, and death, yet comparatively little is known about delirium in older adults hospitalized for traumatic brain injury (TBI). While older adults suffering from even “mild” TBI are at increased risk for subsequent dementia and disability, whether delirium contributes to these worsened outcomes is unclear. This project combines an investigation of age-related delirium risk factors, using clinical assessments and novel biomarkers, with meaningful long-term clinical outcomes, to ultimately improve cognitive and functional recovery for older adults with mild TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Current mouse models of the highly lethal Glioblastoma (GBM) are not clinically relevant in humans due to huge dissimilarities of size, structure, and physiology. Here, we propose to develop a large animal syngeneic pig glioma model using a local anti-inflammatory treatment and the innate immunosuppressive microenvironment with optimum engraftment conditions at implantation site of oncogene activated transformed pig neural progenitor cells (Tr-pNPCs) or Cre-responsive virus. This first-in-kind, clinically relevant syngeneic pig GBM model will better recapitulate human brain physiology, improve clinical imaging, predict treatment responses, and ultimately provide better outcomes in GBM patients as compared to current GBM mouse models.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with bipolar disorder (BP) and comorbid substance use disorders (SUDs) have poor treatment adherence and poor clinical outcomes, high rates of suicide, and increased psychiatric hospitalization. They are at particularly high risk for treatment nonadherence when transitioning from psychiatric hospitalization to outpatient care, with little to no treatment options available to improve care of this high-risk population at the critical period following hospital discharge. The current project will test the effectiveness of Integrated Treatment Adherence Program (ITAP), which is the first adjunctive psychosocial program specifically designed to improve treatment adherence and reduce suicidality, bipolar symptoms, and substance use among high-risk patients with BP-SUD. If shown effective, ITAP could be easily and efficiently adopted as standard care for hospitalized Veterans with co-occurring BP and SUD within VHA. Findings from this study will inform clinical and policy efforts on the implementation of BP treatment for Veterans with co-occurring SUD post-discharge.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: A significant proportion of Veterans with substance use disorders (SUDs) have co-occurring psychiatric disorders, the combination of which frequently leads to high inpatient service utilization. Homelessness and higher risk for suicide is common among this population. The combination of SUD with co-morbid MH diagnoses warrants innovative treatment approaches that: a) identify and treat patients during their most vulnerable periods; b) leverage technology; c) partner with current VA programs (e.g. Home Telehealth) and operational priorities (i.e., VHA Handbook 1160.06), toward the goal of reducing inpatient admissions, enhancing treatment engagement and reducing SUD. This study investigates the effectiveness of Combined Recovery Program (CRP) for Veterans with SUDs in the inpatient setting and Home Telehealth in the aftercare setting. Outcomes are assessed at 1 and 3-month follow-up using a multi-modal approach. The ultimate goal is to increase outpatient utilization, reduce substance use, and reduce inpatient/ED visits.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed research will adapt CPT into a brief format using empirical methods. This project is relevant to Veterans’ health because will improve treatment effectiveness, reduce attrition, and improve efficiency, enabling providers to treat more Veterans with need. This proposal is directly responsive to the 2021 HSR&D mental health priorities to increase the engagement and retention of Veterans in evidence-based therapies for PTSD and to develop innovative and efficient models of healthcare delivery. It addresses the cross-cutting HSR&D Implementation Science priority to use a theory-based method to improve uptake of effective practices. It is also directly responsive to the VA National Center for PTSD’s operational priorities to develop adapted treatments that attend to patient preferences and to improve treatment efficiency, effectiveness, and engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity affects a large fraction of adults and children and is a major risk factor for leading causes of death such as heart attack and stroke. One major cause of poor health outcomes in obesity is increased inflammation in the fat due to a reduction in regulatory T cells (Tregs), a type of cell that normally suppresses inflammation. Therefore, this work will focus on the identifying the causes of this reduction in Tregs, with a focus on cell cholesterol, so we can rescue these cells and improve health outcomes associated with obesity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PRIOJECT NARRATIVE A key step in placental development is the invasion of trophoblast cells into the endometrium of the uterus. Dysregulation of this process can lead to severe pregnancy complications including preeclampsia and miscarriage, but the cell signaling mechanisms controlling the process of trophoblast migration are unclear. This proposal will establish a novel signaling axis governing trophoblast migration, and will shed light on how signaling becomes dysregulated during this process, potentially highlighting targets to be explored in therapies for common pregnancy complications related to aberrant placental development.

PHR: Project Narrative – Component A (Core Surveillance) The Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) is a surveillance project of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment. PRAMS collects state-specific, population-based data on maternal attitudes, behaviors, and experiences before, during, and shortly after pregnancy. PRAMS data are used by state and local governments and their stakeholders to plan and evaluate programs and policies aimed at improving the health of mothers and infants.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Poor sleep is a nearly universal experience for Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and the current first-line psychotherapy for insomnia disorder - cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) - is less beneficial for individuals with comorbid PTSD. This study will evaluate a newly-developed psychotherapy for insomnia disorder in the context of PTSD called “Acceptance and the Behavioral Changes to treat Insomnia (ABC-I), which incorporates the core behavioral components of CBT-I with the theoretical framework and techniques from Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT). The results of this study will improve knowledge about the best non-medication treatments for insomnia disorder for Veterans with PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: It has become increasingly clear that the genome, gut microbiome, diet, lifestyle, socioeconomic status, and environmental exposures all effect an individual’s metabolic state, contributing to brain health and Alzheimer’s disease (AD). In this application, we propose to build research infrastructure that can expand our coverage of the chemical exposome in large AD and epidemiological studies to evaluate the possible effects of environmental exposures on cognition and brain health; where all data will be made publicly available through Sage Bionetworks. We will coordinate with other large exposome initiatives including the Neighborhood Atlas (socioeconomic disadvantage), HHEAR and Netherlands Exposome Initiative (geolocation), biobanks and epidemiological studies (UK Biobank, FHS, Rotterdam) to enhance our understanding of the influences of the exposome in AD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed aims address a critically important gap in Veterans’ health care - specifically, the need to identify effective strategies for linking Veterans in VHA PC who screen positive for hazardous drinking and PTSD and/or depression to alcohol care. Our VHA partners in the Office of Primary Care and Office of Mental Health and Suicide Prevention are highly interested in implementing SLAC nationally should it be found to be effective in a subsequent, fully powered RCT. The aims of this proposal support VA HSR&D priorities (Access to Care, Mental Health, and Primary Care) by adapting and pilot testing a novel intervention to help facilitate Veterans’ linkage to alcohol care. Increasing the use of care among this high need Veteran population is likely to lead to significant reductions in acute health care costs and improved outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Major recent transformations in health care financing and delivery within and outside of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) are now presenting Veterans with unprecedented health care choices. These choices give Veterans opportunities to make decisions about their use of VA and non-VA health care that optimize the timeliness, affordability, quality, and patient-centeredness of their care. However, these decisions also carry great potential for unintended consequences if they are not well-informed. Despite such high stakes, little is known about how Veterans are currently making decisions about using VA and non-VA health care, what information they want to use in this decision-making, and how the provision of information to Veterans about their health care options could be improved. This research will examine how Veterans are now making decisions about using VA and non-VA health care and identify promising new strategies to better support Veterans in making well-informed, personalized decisions about their VA and non-VA health care options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Defects in cranial neural crest development lead to a variety of craniofacial diseases and malformations affecting the face, e.g. Treacher Collins syndrome, DiGeorge syndrome, and cleft palate to name a few. In this project, I will investigate the regulation and mechanism of function of the secreted protein Draxin, which will significantly enhance our understanding of the regulation of cranial neural crest delamination and migration, providing new scientific avenues for translational research applications in the treatment of craniofacial defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will focus on developing and validating new tools to measure financial hardship across families, including individuals living with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) and their families, partners, and caregivers. These measures of financial hardship in ADRD will be publicly available to inform researchers and policymakers about the extent of the burden and any disparities in who is most impacted. Ultimately, new measurement tools of financial hardship will address these disparities and improve quality of life for individuals living with ADRD and their families, partners, and caregivers, by providing early identification of financial stress and burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many consider proton beam radiotherapy (PBRT) to be a promising treatment for children with brain tumors as it may preserve cognitive functioning without sacrificing disease control. This will be the first large-scale study to prospectively compare symptom burden, treatment toxicity, and neurocognitive change between patients treated with PBRT vs. conventional photon radiotherapy on comparable treatment protocols and to assess important measures of daily functioning that will quantify the clinical significance of any differences identified between groups in survivorship. Ultimately, this line of research is intended to: (1) help physicians and families better understand the relative effect of PBRT on symptoms and neurocognitive functioning to inform treatment decisions, and (2) provide functional outcome data to be used toward justifying or reconciling the high cost and access limitations currently associated with PBRT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: This project has important public health implications because preterm birth affects approximately 1 in 10 infants worldwide, and preterm children face neurodevelopmental impairments, including listening difficulty (LiD). Elucidating the mechanisms and clinical antecedents of LiD will enable targeted therapies and early identification of those at risk, thereby improving neurodevelopmental outcomes and reducing the public health burden associated with preterm birth. By enhancing our understanding of this common communication disorder associated with preterm birth, this research will help improve neurodevelopmental outcomes and aligns with the mission to understand the pathogenesis of communication disorders and develop effective interventions.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project narrative Globally, over 58 million pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) survivors are at a high risk of developing chronic lung disease that leads to early death and an impaired health-related quality of life. Addressing the important gap for post-TB lung disease in TB endemic areas where respiratory symptoms are often attributed to recurrent TB infection is the central aim of this proposal. We will develop and test a clinical algorithm for timely diagnosis of post-TB lung disease in Uganda with an ultimate goal of improving the care of TB survivors worldwide.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Recent key studies have demonstrated that immune dysregulation is a defining component of fibromyalgia and chronic muscle pain. The goal of this proposal is to assess the mechanisms by which immunometabolism differentially contributes to chronic muscle pain in male and female mice. Understanding the metabolic processes underlying female-biased mechanisms will bolster research efforts in the development of novel targeted therapeutics for the alleviation of muscle pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The evolutionary and mechanistic relationship between spatial and abstract cognition remains understudied and elusive. Prior research addressing this connection has relied on limited methodology in a small number of primate subjects, despite the reality that rodent models possess excellent spatial and abstract abilities and are much more suitable for precise neural manipulation. My pre- and postdoctoral research will take a comparative approach towards investigating the neural mechanisms of higher order cognition where I will 1) utilize chemogenetic tools to manipulate rodent neural activity, and 2) expand my technical training, potentially including in vivo recording in primates and computational approaches – providing me with the intellectual, technical, and professional skills necessary to successfully pursue an independent career in comparative behavioral neuroscience at an academic research institution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Due to the similarities between pig and human brain anatomy, development, and neuroinflammatory response, pigs are a highly promising model for studying age-specific responses to mechanical trauma. Here we have developed a training plan where I will use a battery of multiparametric behavioral and physiological assessments to characterize post-injury changes in a pig model of pediatric concussion. The findings from these studies could encourage researchers to use the pig to develop novel therapies for use in neurotrauma patients, and ultimately improve diagnostics and prognostication on the front lines of TBI patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Optical coherence tomography angiography (OCTA) allows measurement of vessel density in the retina that provides novel information on retinal microvasculature associated with the development and worsening of glaucoma in a racially diverse cohort. We propose to improve detection and prediction of glaucomatous progression by disassociating age-related changes in OCTA measurements from glaucoma-related changes, by employing deep-learning analyses and by modifying predictive models by adding OCTA measurements. Enhanced detection of progression should lead to earlier and more effective treatment, thus reducing the rate of disease worsening and preventing loss of vision-related quality of life (including blindness).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After a stroke, individuals with sensory impairments have high instances of balance problems, falls, and lower extremity dysfunction, implicating the role of sensorimotor reorganization (i.e., plasticity). Here, we take an initial step in characterizing post-stroke sensorimotor plasticity and its relationship to walking using paired associative stimulation. The proposed work will lay the foundation for a career in which I aim to better inform lower extremity rehabilitation efforts by providing functional biomarkers as targets for modulation, and structural neural correlates to improve prognoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the clear link between type 1 diabetes (T1D), decreases in brain structures and functions, and challenges with mental flexibility, intelligence, memory, executive functioning, and processing speed, studies focused on neuroimaging and neurocognition in the context of T1D biomarkers; social determinants of health; sleep; diabetes technologies; academic achievement; and psychological, social, and school functioning in children with new-onset T1D in the United States are extremely sparse. Therefore, there is an urgent need to address these gaps in the extant literature to identify opportunities to prevent or mitigate cognitive challenges for individuals with T1D across the lifespan. The overarching goals of the Diabetes Brain and Cognitive Development – Type 1 Diabetes (DBCD-T1) study are consistent with NIDDK’s desire to understand neurocognitive complications of pediatric type 1 diabetes and the role of risk and protective factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Microglia, immune cells in the brain, address alterations in brain function and disease using selective signaling pathways. One of these pathways—the calcium pathway—becomes very active during epilepsy development, but its purpose is not well understood. By determining the function of this calcium pathway, we can establish its potential for therapeutic value and advance basic knowledge of its role in the disease process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The study aims to delineate targeted brain mechanisms that contribute to the speech processing difficulties underlying key aspects of social communication impairments in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). We utilize innovative encephalography methods to test the hypothesis that context-dependent auditory processing, i.e., the brain’s ability to fine-tune auditory signals based on prior predictions, is disrupted in ASD across levels of the neural auditory pathway. The extent to which disrupted context-dependent auditory processing contributes to key clinical- behavioral speech and social language phenotypes of ASD will be tested.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative With advancing age, many people develop mutant clones of blood cells that circulate throughout their body. Surprisingly, having such clones associates with protection against Alzheimer’s disease and some of these mutant cells are able to engraft in the brain. Here, we will use genetic data and brain samples from large cohorts and established brain banks to uncover how these mutant cells provide protection against Alzheimer’s.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuronal calcium dysregulation has been linked to numerous neurological and neurodegenerative disorders including Alzheimer’s Disease, Parkinson Disease, and Autism. This proposal will employ innovative imaging approaches and precise casual manipulations, including a novel optogenetic tool, to test the role of the endoplasmic reticulum calcium store in brain function and learning & memory. In so doing, this work may shed light on the mechanism(s) by which neuronal calcium contributes to neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative More than 20% of individuals over 70 have a mutant blood clone that increases risk of multiple aging diseases. We will use data from 1.5 million people to identify resiliency mechanisms that modify this blood clone expansion including genetics, circulating proteins, vitamins, and medications. This research will improve our knowledge about how to risk stratify and modify risk of aging diseases in individuals with mutant blood clones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we aim to combine advanced computer algorithms and fast experimental tests to develop improved proteins for medical purposes. By merging the power of artificial intelligence and physics-based simulations, we seek to speed up the process of designing enzymes that are both stable and functional. Specifically, we will focus on enhancing the diagnostic protein NanoLuc and the potential cancer treatment Onconase, paving the way for more effective and precise medical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The activation of proton-activated chloride channel (PAC) is one of the key factors that determines the severity of brain damage after ischemic stroke. The proposed study aims to elucidate the working mechanism of how PAC senses environmental pH and its pharmacological properties. This knowledge will serve as a foundation to develop novel treatment strategies for ischemic stroke and other diseases that are associated with tissue acidosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) persists for life in neurons as a latent infection and can reactivate to cause disease. The aims of this study are to develop and fully characterize a new model of HSV latent infection in human sensory neurons, along with testing the ability of a clinically relevant compound to prevent reactivation. This new model will be an easily scalable system in a relevant human neuronal type that can be used to investigate the mechanisms of HSV latency and reactivation, and ultimately permit the identification of new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study aims to uncover the long-term effects of early exposure to environmental toxicants on the development of Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD), utilizing extensive, longitudinal data from the CARDIA Study. It will employ advanced techniques in exposomic, genomic, epigenomic, transcriptomic data analyses to trace the biological impact of the toxicants and understand their role in cognitive decline and changes in brain structure. The research also seeks to understand the social determinants of health that contribute to racial disparities in AD/ADRD development, striving for a comprehensive view of environmental and societal influences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current cell therapies use a lentivirus to effectively deliver therapeutic genes to T cells and HSCs, but this strategy can be expensive and potentially hazardous. The goal of this project is to optimize the non-viral delivery, integration, and expression of genes in T cells and HSCs to provide a safer and less expensive alternative to viral gene delivery. Eighteen undergraduate students will be recruited to participate in this project as part of Villanova’s Senior Project Studio (a 2-semester research for credit course), while the PIs will also use the data and methods developed in this project to develop group projects and other learning experiences for dozens of other students in their lecture and lab courses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Clonal Hematopoiesis (CH) refers to somatic mutations that have a strong association with aging. However, the risk factors associated with CH development and the trajectory of aging- associated CH, as well as its relationship with age-related diseases are poorly understood. Through the means of this proposal, we will leverage a singular cohort enriched for exceptional longevity to comprehensively characterize CH and the role of protective longevity-related factors on disease prevalence and incidence in the presence of CH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After traumatic brain injury, the peripheral immune system and the injured brain interact with one another to exacerbate neuropathology and induce immunosuppression which can lead to chronic neurological deficits and increased susceptibility to secondary infections and death. However, the extent, mechanism(s), and duration of the effects of the peripheral immune system and the injured brain on each other is largely unknown. Within this proposal, we aim to investigate the interactions between these two organ systems in a clinically relevant injury model in order to understand neuro-immune interactions and to develop a translational treatment strategy that employs the immune system to protect the damaged brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Transforming rich and continuous experience into concise and temporally associated event sequences (i.e., event segmentation), a fundamental process for episodic memory, relies on the coordination between the hippocampus, prefrontal cortex, and substantia nigra. This proposal aims to reveal the underlying circuit-level neural dynamics using direct neural recordings (at both the single-cell and population levels), computational modeling, and electrical stimulation. The expected outcomes of this study will provide valuable insights on event segmentation and its influence on episodic memory in humans, which will shed light on developing neural prosthetics to help patients with memory-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Perineural invasion (PNI) is found in nearly all patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas (PDAC) and is associated with an increased incidence of tumor metastasis. PNI is a dynamic process in which distinct cellular players of the tumor microenvironment help tumor cells invade autonomic nerve fibers. The proposed work would help to explain how tumor cells, nerves and immune cells communicate in the setting of PNI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to identify novel gene-environmental (GxE) interactions that contribute to Pb-induced risk of Alzheimer's disease and related dementia (AD/ADRD) in aging brains by establishing a screening platform based on CRISPR a/i and elucidate the interactions between Pb-exposure and aging using engineered human neuronal models. Novel GxE targets will be identified and compared with those found using conventional approach. The collective findings will establish a new research paradigm for studying GxE interactions contributing to ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will investigate the use of proton pencil beam scanning (PBS) to deliver FLASH enhanced radiotherapy. The approach will examine the complex interplay between spatio-temporal beam parameters and FLASH, optimization algorithms for modeling biological effects and treatment planning, and development of FLASH specific methods for ultra-fast dose monitoring, robotic positioning, image guidance, and quality assurance. The goal is to further optimize the FLASH effect by PBS machine tuning and FLASH delivery with existing clinical proton accelerator technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Common genetic variants identified through genome-wide association studies have been reproducibly associated with risk for Alzheimer’s disease (AD), but the function of many risk variants are unknown and likely context-specific. At the same time, several environmental exposures have been implicated in AD and dementia, including particulate matter air pollution (PM2.5), heavy metals (especially lead (Pb)), and infections. Here, will identify interactions between genetic variants and the aforementioned exposures that influence neural cells, brain structure, and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed study has public health relevance due to the high prevalence of asthma in adolescence and their reactive management style that can lead to symptom exacerbations and increased healthcare cost. Although self-management is a critical element in achieving asthma control, a recent systematic review revealed that existing measures for assessing adolescent asthma self-management are limited in scope and lack validation, failing to account for cognitive processes and self-regulation characteristics. The proposed study aims to address the high prevalence of asthma in adolescence and bridge the gap by creating and validating an asthma self-management questionnaire for adolescents aged 12 to 21.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cadmium (Cd) heavy metal exposure has been implicated in its role to increase risk for Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and our proposal aims to study the role of genetic variation within immune genes to determine the extent of such genetic variation interacting with Cd exposure to cause AD. We plan to do so by the using a selected population of donor cells containing such variation, reprogramming them into induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) for differentiating into cerebral organoids (cOrgs) and testing for AD pathology by exposing the cOrgs to Cd and infecting them with herpes simplex 1 virus (HSV-1). We propose 3 complementary aims that utilize RNA-sequencing data, flow cytometery detection of AD and cell-type biomarkers as well as measuring the levels of multiple pro-inflammatory cytokines of the various cOrgs upon Cd exposure as well as HSV-1 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Persons with obesity have an increased risk of developing breast cancer. Our proposed research will address how obesity increases breast cancer growth and suggest new drugs to treat these patients. Thus, the proposed research is of high relevance to public health and perfectly aligns with NCI mission to support cancer research to advance scientific knowledge and help all people live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic stress is significantly linked to an elevated risk of metastasis and cancer recurrence, yet there remains a substantial knowledge gap regarding the underlying mechanisms driving this process. We discovered that stress induces the formation of metastasis-promoting neutrophil extracellular traps and local activation of the sympathetic nervous system at the metastatic site, while reciprocally metastasis alters the activity of stress-regulating neurons in the brain, thus establishing a stress-metastasis feedforward loop. In this application, we propose to elucidate the mechanisms driving this feedforward loop, with implications for preventing metastasis from disseminated cancer cells and treating stage IV cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project supports the purchase of a next-generation 3 Tesla human MRI scanner at the Athinoula A. Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging to serve a diverse array of NIMH- and NIH-funded studies at Mass General Brigham and across the greater Boston area research community. The new 3 Tesla human MRI will replace the obsolete scanner in the Martinos Center PET-MR & Radiochemistry Facility. It will also boost the imaging performance and provide major benefits to structural, functional, and multimodality PET-MR imaging and microstructural tissue characterization for understanding mental health and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Neuroinflammation is believed to contribute to the onset and/or the progression of neurodegenerative diseases. We propose experiments to test the hypothesis that during neuroinflammation, the cytokine IL-13 contributes to the loss of dopaminergic neurons expressing its receptor, IL-13Rα1. The originality and potential clinical significance of this work lie in the hypothesis that an anti-inflammatory cytokine can contribute to neurodegeneration. This represents a paradigm shift from the current view that anti-inflammatory cytokines are invariably neuroprotective and may open the way to novel therapeutic strategies. If successful, these experiments will show that IL-13 and IL-13Rα1 are potential novel targets for preventing Parkinson’s disease or slowing its progression, at least in a subset of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Growing evidence suggests that the potential causes of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD) in the aging population are multi-faceted and are likely mediated through an interaction of genetic and environmental risk factors (GxE), such as air pollution. In this application, using human induced pluripotent stem cell (hiPSC) and in vivo xenotransplantation models with different AD-related genetic backgrounds, we will study the targets of aberrant protein S-nitrosylation as mediators of the GxE interactions. Our proposed study will gain molecular insight into the air pollution-related cognitive decline in AD/ADRD, thus identifying potential new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In one sense, cancer represents an imbalance between pro-inflammatory and pro-resolving processes that promote tumor growth and suppress the immunity of the tumor microenvironment (TME). Here, we plan to understand how AA-rich Western diets are metabolized by ALOX5 and related genes that regulate the TME. These studies will lead to new therapeutic approaches to CRC through modulation of lipid-signaling in the TME.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A family of measurements known as wideband acoustic immittance has great potential for detecting a range of middle-ear problems with a simple noninvasive sound measurement made in the ear canal. Ultimately this approach will lead to better methods for identification of the causes of hearing loss for all ages, including newborn babies. The work proposed here expands the online database for published wideband acoustic immittance measures and uses these measurements, along with measurement validity criteria, to develop machine-learning models to differentiate between normal and abnormal ears.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narra+ve Adeno Associated Viruses (AAVs) are crucial to unraveling the behavioral function of neural circuits. We propose to establish a new AAV core – The BRAIN-STORRM Center at the University of Maryland Eastern Shore (UMES) – to validate and distribute a new generation of cell type specific AAVs with the potential to help unlock the mysteries of cognition and human disease. The BRAIN-STORRM Center will diversify participation in BRAIN-Initiative sponsored research by establishing an AAV hub at an HBCU, expand access to cutting edge AAVs by validating their effectiveness in the most common laboratory model organism (mice), and scale- up production and distribution channels such that novel, cell type specific AAVs can reach as many labs as possible to increase the pace, scope, and quality of neuroscientific discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRDs) are the leading causes of dementia and major contributors to morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs. Exposure to environmental toxicants increases risk for AD/ADRDs and is common in disadvantaged groups, raising concerns about health disparities, socioeconomic inequities, and environmental justice. This project (responsive to RFA-AG-24-023) leverages innovative mouse models (NIA MODEL-AD) that carry human AD/ADRD genetic risk factors to generate vital resources with the goal of identifying mechanisms by which three ubiquitous metal/metalloid neurotoxicants (lead, cadmium, arsenic) impact brain health and increase risk for AD/ADRDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Solid tumors are difficult to treat with cell-based immunotherapies due to the immunosuppressive environment created by the tumor mass, in part caused by the secretion of byproducts of dysregulated tumor metabolism. We have identified that succinate, a key metabolite that accumulates in tumors and is secreted into the tumor microenvironment, promotes the induction of Tregs from CD4+ T cells, and propose to further test the effects of succinate on enhancing the suppressive phenotype of Tregs that have infiltrated the tumor, driving the suppression of effector CD8+ T cell anti-tumor responses. Targeting succinate signaling is a promising therapeutic strategy to alleviate Treg-mediated suppression of CD8+ effector T cells and enhance anti-tumor immunity and improve response to immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Newborns in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) undergoing invasive procedures or surgeries are frequently exposed to prolonged pain, postoperative complications, and human suffering because of the major difficulties in measuring neonatal pain, inconsistent and ineffective pain management, and delayed pain treatments due to nursing workload. Our proposed research aims to develop an AI-driven automated system to objectively and continuously measure newborn pain and pain sensitization based on several biomarkers, and when detected, to send their pain alarms to bedside nurses in real-time. The proposed neonatal pain monitoring system allows us to create therapeutic strategies that minimize pain, stress, and total opioid doses given during the post-operative care of newborns, thereby improving their clinical and post-surgical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  It remains difficult to effectively alleviate asthmatic symptoms and limit disease progression in children with severe asthma. While corticosteroids can be effective, children with severe asthma develop corticosteroid insensitivity or resistance making their disease difficult to manage. The goal of this proposal is to understand how inflammation promotes corticosteroid resistance in the context of severe pediatric asthma. These studies are also aimed to assess the potential for therapeutic strategies to improve corticosteroid sensitivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Within the human genome, structural variations change more base pairs than point mutations, and those variations may lead to different diseases. This research aims to develop a system that will produce long molecules that can be analyzed with sequencing or physical mapping to find these larger variations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has had a detrimental effect on mental health, especially for emerging adults. Utilizing the longitudinal Early Steps Multisite prevention trial of diverse, low-income families (N=731) from three geographic areas across the United States, we plan to take advantage of an 18-year-long prospective dataset in conjunction with new mental health assessments to examine risk and resilience factors for at-risk emerging adults, transitioning from adolescence to adulthood in the context of a pandemic. With genotyping on an extensive contemporary array, prospective data on experiences of discrimination, and neighborhood and community risk/resilience factors, we plan to examine direct, interactive, and cascading effects on mental health outcomes, and the long-term preventive effects of the Family Check-Up, in the context of growing up in poverty, and, more recently, the pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) is associated with several age-related diseases including cardiovascular disease (CVD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) but the mechanisms driving CH progression and its impact on CVD and AD are largely undefined. Our central hypothesis is that inherited, and lifestyle risk factors impact CH evolution through immune dysregulation and that this, in turn, determines the development of disease. We will leverage existing data from large-scale biobanks alongside longitudinal CH and proteomic profiling in cohorts with rich phenotyping to determine (1) the impact of lifestyle and inherited risk factors on CH evolution, (2) the pathways that mediate CH evolution and (3) the pathways that mediate the association between CH with CVD and AD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Glaucoma remains a leading cause of irreversible blindness. Within 20 years, glaucoma will affect nearly 112 million people worldwide. Ocular hypertension has been identified as a primary risk factor for primary open angle glaucoma (POAG), the most common form of glaucoma. However, many POAG patients present with normal ocular tension, often referred to as normal-tension glaucoma. While the cause of normal-tension glaucoma remains unclear, recent studies implicate a role for a pressure gradient differential across the optic nerve head in affected patients. Here, we will test this thesis using guinea pigs as potential animal model of human normal-tension glaucoma. Successful completion of the proposed study will validate recent findings and establish the guinea pig as a clinically useful animal model in which to study human ocular disorders, including normal-tension glaucoma. Novel findings produced by this study will elucidate the role pressure gradient differential across the lamina cribrosa play in the development of this insidious disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will increase the understanding of the evolutionary predictability of antimicrobial resistance for the high-priority nosocomial pathogen, Acinetobacter baumannii. Using clinical isolates, the research proposed in this application will increase translational predictive measures of resistance adaptability, demystify the genotype- phenotype map of virulence and resistance associated phenotypes, and clarify the genetic level to which resistance evolution is predictable. The results will guide future treatment optimization and be applicable to other multidrug resistant bacterial pathogens.

PHR: Narrative This proposal will investigate how the human pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans senses host body temperature, responds, and establishes an infection leading to disease. Elucidation of these mechanisms may allow for process to be targeted to prevent successful infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Infections from pathogenic bacteria and viruses like SARS-CoV-2 cause alternative responses in the adaptive immune system that can alter the severity of the infection. Our studies will identify a component of these responses, memory B cells, to link as a network that controls humoral immunity in response to infection by creating superior protection. This research will lead to improved vaccine developments and memory B cell therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) that express the neuropeptide, tachykinin receptor 3 (Tacr3), are a distinct subpopulation of dopamine-producing neurons that promote reward reinforcement behavior. However, the intracellular signaling pathways that act downstream of this Gq-protein coupled receptor to regulate this behavior are unresolved. This proposal will investigate the role of transient receptor potential canonical type 6 channels in regulating the physiology and function of VTA-Tacr3 neurons, which will provide important insights into the therapeutic potential of this understudied ion channel in the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The delicate balance between pro- and anti- inflammatory programs is a critical prognostic factor following stroke. This project will investigate how the gut microbiota controls stroke outcome through action on dendritic cells, which provide a link between innate and adaptive immunity. Such studies are essential to understand how the microbiota, and diet which is closely linked, can affect susceptibility to poor stroke outcome and how implicated immune pathways can be targeted to develop potential stroke therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial cell wall synthesis is critical and effective target for antibiotics, yet we lack a fundamental understanding of how new cell wall material is synthesized at the septum between dividing bacteria. We will solve the structure of a novel, division-specific cell wall synthase and reconstitute its activity in vitro. By doing so, we will determine its enzymatic mechanism of action and elucidate how it is regulated by interactions with the cell wall and other division proteins to generate insight for the design of novel antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older kidney transplant (KT) recipients are at increased risk of developing dementia/Alzheimer’s disease (AD), which significantly increases the risk of mortality or graft loss. Despite these risks, predicting who will develop post-KT dementia/AD is not part of the pre-KT evaluation. The goal of the proposed project is to identify specific risk factors that are associated with developing post-KT dementia/AD, and to create a model that identifies which patients undergoing KT evaluation are at increased risk of developing post-KT dementia/AD, so that they can receive targeted pre- and post- transplant interventions and additional support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria kills hundreds of thousands of children in sub-Saharan Africa each year, but it remains unclear why some infections progress from mild to severe illness. Laboratory studies suggest that diverse parasite antigens called RIFINs and STEVORs may have several roles in severe malaria pathogenesis, but they have not been studied in clinical infections. The goal of this proposal is to identify RIFIN and STEVOR subtypes that are associated with vulnerability to severe malaria in sub-Saharan African children, illuminating the importance of these proteins in pathogenesis and informing the development of vaccines and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intestinal pathobionts can exacerbate lupus pathogenesis; however, how the immune system mediates their pathogenic effects remains unknown. The proposed research will use mouse models to identify how the peripheral expansion of thymic pathobiont-specific T cells mediate bacterial exacerbation of lupus pathogenesis. These studies will increase our understanding in host-microbe interactions in the context of autoimmunity, which will improve therapeutic and prophylactic approaches for patients with lupus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cell-surface glypican Dally-like protein (Dlp) interacts with several secreted Wnts to modulate their extracellular availability for signaling, which is critical for tissue development and homeostasis; and aberrant Wnt availability and signaling are linked with tumorigenesis. In this proposal, I will integrate powerful genetic tools available in Drosophila with biochemical, proteomic, and imaging approaches to investigate how Dlp-mediated regulation of Wnt signaling is affected by proteolytic cleavage of Dlp my Matrix Metalloprotease2 (Mmp2) in developmental and tumorigenic contexts. Additionally, I will investigate previously unappreciated roles of Dlp in Wnt ligand production, availability, and signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose an observational study to be conducted as part of a new network of clinical centers and a coordinating center to be assembled, to further explore the impact of type 1 diabetes (T1D) on the brain in young children of racial/ethnic and socioeconomic diversity, studied shortly after the diagnosis of T1D, compared to age-matched nondiabetic controls. We will use sophisticated neurocognitive assessments, structural and functional brain imaging, psychosocial questionaries, social determinants of health and glucose data, as children get insulinized for the first time and many are transitioned by their providers to advanced insulin delivery (closed- loop) systems over 2-years. These studies will provide critical insight as to whether earlier intervention aimed to near-normalize blood glucose could have a positive impact in cognitive outcomes in children, an area of great contemporary importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite the high prevalence of sexual health concerns in cancer survivorship, these concerns often go unaddressed. This project is expected to prepare our team for the successful launch of a multisite pragmatic trial to evaluate whether the virtual Mindful After Cancer intervention can be integrated into routine cancer and improve sexual health outcomes for breast and gynecological cancer survivors. This can make a significant contribution toward improving equity in access to comprehensive sexual health services and reducing the burden of cancer for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The brain can alter skeletal muscle metabolism, increasing calories burned by prompting the muscle to generate heat, a process called thermogenesis. We have shown that exposing animals like rats and mice to the odor of a predator triggers muscle thermogenesis, and that this involves activation of a brain region that is important in both metabolic regulation and determining how an animal responds to predators. Here, we probe the role of a cellular fuel sensor as the key brain mechanism triggering muscle thermogenesis, with the ultimate goal of identifying targets to increase muscle thermogenesis and caloric expenditure to combat weight gain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Persons with type 1 diabetes often have declines in cognitive function over time but the responsible mechanisms are not well understood. There is a growing evidence that the damage begins at diagnosis of diabetes and is especially severe with diabetic ketoacidosis and chronic hyperglycemia. In the proposed project, we will study risk factors for cognitive decline in a comprehensive, multi-center cohort of young children to find out how cognitive decline might be prevented.
