IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Because elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) and IOP fluctuations are the primary risk factors for loss of visual field in glaucoma, the current standard of care for adult-onset glaucoma includes treatment with IOP-lowering medications that are typically delivered topically as eye drops because of their ease of use and the ability for a patient to receive treatment from the comfort of their home. The requirement for multiple daily dosings along with associated eye irritation in addition to orbital and systemic side effects noted in available medications, collectively contribute to the low patient adherence documented by many eye care specialists. To directly address this unmet clinical need to increase patient adherence, within these SBIR Phase 1 studies, we will optimize and evaluate the IOP-lowering properties and safety of a subconjunctival biodegradable electrospun depot containing PRG.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (No change from original, funded submission) E-cigarette use produces toxicants, is addictive, and is associated with future use of combustible tobacco among young adults. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal supports Dr. Alex Herrera’s effort in his leadership of City of Hope Comprehensive Cancer Center’s (COHCCC’s) NCI-funded clinical trials network research as well as his national leadership of NCI-sponsored research. As a City of Hope clinical research leader, Dr. Herrera will facilitate the expansion and integration of the COHCCC clinical trials infrastructure with the goal of enhancing contributions to NCI clinical trials network research and improving the diversity of patients enrolled to NCI-sponsored trials at City of Hope. As a national leader in NCI-sponsored lymphoma research, Dr. Alex Herrera will continue to guide the cancer research agenda for patients with lymphoma, including designing and leading practice-changing clinical trials, and mentoring the next generation of NCI-sponsored clinical research leaders with the goal of reducing the burden of lymphoma and improving survival of patients with lymphoma in the United States.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human and animal populations are increasingly exposed to toxic environmental chemicals as a result of living in a heavily industrialized world. This proposal examines the novel hypothesis that dioxins exert their action through aryl hydrocarbon receptor-mediated uncoupling of homeostatic regulation of organismic circadian rhythms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Capitalizing on the pre-existing infrastructure for multi-site analysis and study coordination at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, the investigative team will establish the Subtyping Core for Research on the Etiology of Type 2 Diabetes (SCORE-T2D) biostatistics research center. SCORE-T2D will work with the Cohort Sites and NIDDK to employ multi-level, multi-dimensional approaches to characterize heterogeneity in type 2 diabetes in the Consortium. Establishment of SCORE-T2D and completion of the proposed goals will result in a broadly applicable framework for identifying type 2 diabetes subtypes and forge new research opportunities for effective precision interventions to prevent, reroute the clinical course, and optimize long-term prognosis of type 2 diabetes in diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T helper type 2 tissue-resident memory cells (Th2-Trm) are key drivers of allergic asthma due to their persistence in the airways and amnestic responses upon local allergen re-exposure. FoxP3+ regulatory T cells (Tregs) are potent suppressors of allergic inflammation. This proposal explores the possibility that allergen- specific tissue resident (r) Tregs in the lung are particularly effective at suppressing allergic inflammation due to their positioning in a unique niche alongside Th2-Trm through shared chemokine receptor systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is relevant to human health because it seeks to elucidate mechanisms of how key processes of protein import and bioenergetics in the mitochondrion are regulated in the yeast model system, and conserved in mammals, that will translate into a better understanding of the molecular basis of a subset of mitochondrial diseases. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission and the mission of the NIGMS because it seeks fundamental knowledge about cellular processes that has the potential for development of strategies for the treatment of mitochondrial disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Dr. Akhil Chawla has demonstrated long-term commitment to the support of NCI sponsored studies within at Northwestern and nationally through his service and leadership within the Alliance for Clinical Trials in Oncology (Alliance) and the National Cancer Institute (NCI). Dr. Chawla has focused goals to design and implement novel and practice changing clinical trials through Alliance, increase his impact within the NCI, lead integration to enhance infrastructural expansion to community cancer sites to reach underserved populations at Northwestern, and provide formalized mentorship to early career investigators. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative  Stress-related neuropsychiatric disorders including anxiety disorders and depression represent a significant public health problem, however the underlying neural causes of these disorders are poorly understood. The research outlined in this proposal will provide a detailed understanding of circuit and cellular mechanisms by which stress-related neuropsychiatric disorder models (anxiety and depression) are enhanced after social isolation during the critical period of adolescence. These studies will identify novel targets for the discovery of more effective treatments and interventions for these debilitating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PPAL® PHASE II PROJECT NARRATIVE Toileting injuries have detrimental effects on older adults and individuals with mobility disability; new, easy-to- use technologies that enable more efficient and safer toilet transfers are desperately needed. This Phase II project continues the development and testing of a novel bedside commode (the “PPAL®”) that enables care recipients to transfer themselves onto a commode to toilet, rather than wait for caregiver lift assistance. The PPAL® uniquely engages the transfer skill of care recipients to manage their own transfer onto a commode. In so doing, it advances the clinical science of fall prevention and (by reducing the manual labor required for toileting assistance), safe patient handling and mobility.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will conduct a phase II clinical trial of a novel targeted therapy combination in specific genomic subsets of two types of thyroid cancer: recurrent and/or metastatic differentiated thyroid carcinoma that does not respond to radioiodine and anaplastic thyroid cancer. To expeditiously determine the most effective use of this combination, we will assess the correlation of clinical findings with molecular analyses of biopsy tissues collected before and during treatment to identify the most promising ways this combination works against thyroid cancer. In differentiated thyroid cancer, we will also examine the potential of this combination to restore sensitivity to radioidine.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Phase II trial of avutometinib plus defactinib in RAF dimer-driven thyroid cancers

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Sunshine Education and Research Center focuses on interdisciplinary training of occupational safety and health professionals, training in evidence-based practice and research, continuing education and outreach. The home base for the ERC is in the University of South Florida College of Public Health and offers programs collaboratively with the USF Colleges Nursing and Arts and Sciences, with Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (ERAU) (Daytona Beach FL) and with the University of Central Florida (UCF) (Orlando FL). The academic programs are Occupational Health Nursing, Occupational Health Psychology, and Health Safety and Environment (HSE) at USF plus Occupational Safety Management from ERAU and Targeted Research Training at UCF; while we have phased out the industrial hygiene and occupational medicine training programs, we propose to add the DrPH in occupational health, safety and wellness and an MPH/Certificate program in social marketing.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Sunshine Education and Research Center

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Currently there are not enough people trained in occupational safety and health to protect the US workforce, particularly those trained in industrial hygiene practice and research. The University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center offers an ABET-accredited Master of Science degree in Industrial Hygiene and Environmental Health Sciences and a PhD degree in Occupational and Environmental Health that prepare students to anticipate, recognize, evaluate, and control occupational hazards. The training project grant will provide tuition and stipend support to attract students of diverse technical and cultural backgrounds into the occupational safety and health professional workforce, and prepare a new generation of industrial hygiene faculty and researchers.

PROJECT_TITLE: Great Plains Training for Industrial Hygiene Practice and Research

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Individuals with hearing loss often have trouble pinpointing the location of an audible sound source, particularly in noisy environments, but the reason for this is unknown. IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year, roughly 600,000 patients served in U.S. trauma centers develop posttraumatic stress disorder or depression after traumatic injury, but few receive mental health follow-up care. The Trauma Resilience and Recovery Program is a sustainable, stepped-care model that has addressed the mental health needs of over 8,000 patients in four Level I-II trauma centers and is being adopted by 8 additional trauma centers in the Carolinas. This study will examine the effectiveness and implementation of TRRP with a diverse sample of 350 patients served at The George Washington University hospital.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Testing a Scalable Model of Care to Improve Patients’ Access to Mental Health Services after Traumatic Injury

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Cell polarity and migration are critical life-long process required for developmental processes and homeostatic maintenance, as well as during the body’s response to external insults and disease states including wound-healing and tumor metastasis. The prior funded cycle identified a key mechanistic signaling pathway responsible for driving changes in cell architecture. The goals of the next funding cycle build upon these discoveries and new hypotheses that will determine how this signaling pathway coordinates the cellular machinery required for directed migration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type I diabetes (T1D) is linked to the gut microbiota, yet the underlying mechanism remains unclear. The proposed research investigates how T cell response to commensal microbes contributes to T1D and the potential use of gut immune responses as cellular biomarkers for disease prediction. Data generated from this study will provide fundamental knowledge on the underlying pathology in T1D and may uncover new biomarkers for early disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Our laboratory studies how estrogen modules immunity to promote progression of a rare and devastating lung disease found almost exclusively in women called lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM). In human patients and in animal models, estrogen promotes progression of LAM; however, estrogen does not only directly stimulate LAM cells - instead, it also enhances neutrophil production and activation and inhibits T cells, both of which lead to LAM progression. Understanding these mechanisms will apply not only to LAM but to many other cancers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Validated patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) can quantify knee osteoarthritis (OA) symptoms but clinicians lack guidelines to interpret PROMs in individual patient care. IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Decades of exciting progress in gene-based treatments for inherited retinal diseases (IRDs) have led to dozens of promising clinical trials with gene augmentation therapy. For the subset of severe binocular congenital blinding conditions called LCA, the greatest benefit is likely to be in children before the window of brain plasticity closes. This research plan is designed to perform a clinical trial using innovative outcome measures in adolescents with LCA5, and develop novel outcomes to evaluate efficacy in young children taking part in future trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Henry, Michael F. Project Narrative This proposed research seeks to better understand the causes of mitochondrial disorders; a group of diverse diseases that includes cancer, infertility, diabetes, heart disease, blindness, deafness and neurodegenerative diseases. The yeast model organism will be used to study a feature of mitochondrial genome expression conserved in humans. This information is necessary for discovering the underlying causes of mitochondrial disorders and may help identify potential therapies that could prevent, or even reverse, mitochondrial diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed research aims to investigate the prevalence of cardiometabolic medication substitution and its potential long-term health outcomes among older adults in the transition from acute hospitals to skilled nursing facilities (SNFs). Leveraging a novel nationwide SNF electronic health record linked to Medicare data will provide a comprehensive investigation of this prevalent practice. ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: In our previous research, we discovered neurons in the brain that produce the unpleasant quality of pain. Here, we have assembled a multidisciplinary team to launch a drug discovery program. Our goal is to develop molecules that can act on act these neurons and produce a novel type of painkiller that can treat pain emotional suffering across all pain types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with type 1 diabetes (T1D) are at increased risk for neurocognitive complications, but the risk and protective factors are not well understood. As a Clinical Center, our multidisciplinary team will establish a diverse cohort of school-aged children with newly diagnosed T1D and a comparison group of children without diabetes. This important project has the potential to influence standards of clinical care and identify targets for future interventions to improve brain health and psychosocial function for children with T1D.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Short interpregnancy interval is associated with adverse maternal and infant outcomes. Little is known about the sociocultural and demographic factors associated with short interpregnancy intervals in African immigrant women living in the US. The proposed mixed methods study is designed to elucidate a community-informed understanding of social and cultural norms and demographic factors related to birth spacing and short interpregnancy intervals, which will inform the modification of existing relevant measures or the development of a new measure, if needed, and validation of a measure of underlying sociocultural constructs related to birth spacing and interpregnancy intervals in African immigrant women in the US.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The majority of older Veterans do not meet the minimum healthy diet or physical activity recommendations, despite known benefits. Identifying novel ways to increase adherence to rehabilitation programs that improve dietary quality and physical activity may reduce the risk of disability in older Veterans. Peer-based interventions may be one method to facilitate lasting behavioral change since peers often share a common culture and knowledge about the problems that their community experiences. We propose to develop and evaluate a novel peer-led diet and exercise intervention that targets older Veterans with multiple chronic health conditions. Successful development and pilot of this intervention will provide the preliminary data for a larger multisite trial focused on the use of peer-led interventions to improve long-term compliance to lifestyle interventions in older Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the current proposal, we will examine the potential of PNPT1-mediated RNA decay as novel vulnerability of triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). We will assess the effect of PNPT1 perturbation on induction of dsRNA- mediated antiviral responses and on overall RNA metabolism in TNBCs, as well as evaluate the importance of PNPT1 on TNBC progression. The proposed project may provide novel insights into how RNA decay helps sustain TNBC growth and survival and serve as a foundation for the development of novel therapeutic approaches targeting PNPT1 for the potential treatment of TNBCs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Autonomic nervous system dysfunction and blood pressure (BP) fluctuations contribute to the increased cardiovascular disease risk in the spinal cord injury (SCI) population; however, treatment of BP fluctuations is not a clinical priority. This is due, in part, to the lack of safe and effective interventions, even though mounting evidence strongly supports adverse effects of BP instability on cognitive function and quality of life. Identifying individualized transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (TSCS) parameters that safely and effectively increase and stabilize BP in Veterans with SCI will provide the foundational evidence to support eventual wide-spread clinical utility throughout the VA healthcare system. It is anticipated that these data will begin to establish a standard methodology for TSCS mapping of spinal autonomic circuits to promote restoration of orthostatic BP, improve independence and quality of life for Veterans with SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) currently affects 6.2 million Americans over the age of 65 and this number is expected to double in the next 30 years. Recent studies have demonstrated that mitochondrial calcium transport is an effective therapeutic strategy in alleviating neurocognitive pathology in models of AD; given the repeated failure of amyloid-targeted therapeutics in clinical trials, this represents an exciting opportunity to overcome the barrier to effective AD treatments. This proposal aims to understand how MICU3, a CNS-specific regulator of mitochondrial calcium uptake that is downregulated in AD, affects development and progression of neurodegeneration in AD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Apathy, a profound loss of initiative and motivation, is often seen in older Veterans with memory problems. Apathy leads to serious health problems, increases dependency, and caregiver burden. If untreated, apathy hastens the progression to frank dementia. In a pilot study, we found that apathy, working memory, and function can be restored using magnetic stimulation in some but not all older Veterans. The reason for this variation is unknown. We propose a three-phase study in 125 older Veterans with mild memory problems. Their motivation, memory, and function will be measured periodically. Veterans with apathy that are eligible for treatment will receive either real or sham magnetic stimulation to the front part of their brain over 20 sessions. Genetic testing and biomarkers will be used to differentiate those who respond to magnetic stimulation from those who do not. Impact on function, quality of life, and rates of progression to dementia will also be studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The cerebral cortex is instrumental to all human and animal cognition, ranging from sensation to decision making to movement. The complexity of cortical circuits is a major obstacle to both understanding cortical function as a whole and to treating maladies that might afflict it, including numerous neurological and psychiatric disorders. The proposed studies will reveal how cortical circuits interact to execute cortical computations, how these interactions are impaired by aging and neurodegeneration, and how we can noninvasively stimulate cortical circuits to galvanize the brain to fight against pathologies caused by aging and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Cognitive deficits associated with aging, traumatic brain injury (TBI), and neurodegenerative diseases pose major challenges to healthcare systems throughout the world. To facilitate successful aging, we need effective methods for early detection of neurodegeneration and for monitoring cognitive function. Here, we propose to develop continuous and objective estimates of cognitive changes derived computationally and unobtrusively from smartphone-based data (location information, application use patters, and motor interactions with touchscreens, context inferences).).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our Research Center will leverage our extensive lung tissue biobank and expertise in multi-omics, induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC) differentiation, and bioinformatics to construct a multi-scale map of the developing acinar and alveolar structures for the normal human lung and those with childhood interstitial lung disease (chILD). We will establish new technologies, experimental protocols, and computational approaches to support the pulmonary research community and develop AI-powered analysis of complex multi-omic data to identify gene regulatory networks underlying normal lung formation and disease-related tissue remodeling. We will also generate patient-derived iPSCs to model and interrogate disease pathogenesis. LungMAP 2 - Project Narrative-v7

PHR: Narrative Platelets play important roles in health and disease. We have identified a platelet protein, called TREM Like transcript (TLT-1), that mediates leukocyte escape from the blood vessel without causing vessel damage. TLT-1 has the potential to be developed into therapeutic interventions where the immune system triggers hemostatic mechanisms such as cardiovascular disease and acute lung injury

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research tests mediating and moderating processes underlying racial discrimination’s harmful effect on sleep, a critical restorative process implicated in numerous health problems including immune functioning, heart disease, psychopathology, and suicidality. By investigating factors underlying racism’s effect on sleep, the proposed work offers new insights into pressing race- related health disparities generally and inequities in the far-reaching restorative process of sleep specifically. In addition to its scientific contribution, the proposed work will also offer undergraduate and graduate students cutting edge training in research design, survey methods and actigraphy, data analysis, and the development of research presentations and publications certain to improve their professional trajectories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The potential of Francisella tularensis, a Category A bioterror agent to cause severe infection is due to its ability to suppress the host’s innate immune system. The proposed studies will explore how Francisella evades the host innate immune responses. Defining the molecular mechanism(s) of suppression of innate immunity will be an essential first step towards the development of immunotherapeutic, as well as effective vaccine strategies to combat this fatal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop deep learning methods for analysis of single-cell RNA sequencing data, which have been generated for investigating various biomedical problems. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Production of the type IV mannose-sensitive hemagglutinin (MSHA) pilus is essential for biofilm formation and environmental survival of the pandemic cholera pathogen Vibrio cholerae, yet is detrimental to host colonization and establishment of infection. These proposed studies will define a novel msh transcriptional regulatory mechanism that facilitates the transition of V. cholerae from colonization of the environment to the host. Information obtained from these studies could be leveraged to the development of new strategies to prevent either environmental persistence or host pathogenesis of V. cholerae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project will study frontal temporal dementia (FTD), a devastating neurodegenerative disease without a cure, commonly caused by a mutation in C9ORF72, which causes the production of toxic RNA and proteins leading to neuronal death. This research will determine the roles of a major G-quadruplex helicase, DHX36, in stress responses and genomic integrity in C9 FTD (and related C9 ALS disease), and will also initiate the development of a novel therapeutic strategy targeting DHX36 in C9 ALS/FTD, while integrating dozens of students into cutting edge, biomedically-relevant research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative COVID-19 represents an unprecedented, multisystem shock to children’s educational and family environments, borne disproportionately by children from low-income families, those who are Latinx and Black, and children with special needs. Yet, little existing or emerging research is focusing on these subgroups of children, nor is the extant knowledge base able to identify pre-pandemic dimensions of child functioning or specific features of children’s family, school, and peer contexts, including culturally-embedded protective features, that can serve as effective targets for pandemic relief and recovery efforts aimed at restoring strong developmental growth as children recover from educational and family disruptions during school closures, and continued family disruptions after schools reopened. This application provides a unique opportunity to address these shortcomings by leveraging an existing longitudinal study of exclusively low-income children, with large subgroups of Latinx (including Spanish-speaking ELLs) and Black children, and children with special needs, first observed as preschoolers years prior to the pandemic and who will enter pre-adolescence as COVID-19 continues, to examine the moderating role of (1) children’s pre-existing strengths and vulnerabilities and (2) post-school-reopening family, school, and peer contexts as they explain effects of pandemic-induced educational and family disruption during the period of school closures, and continued family disruption following school reopening, on children’s immediate and longer-term recovery of cognitive/academic and self- regulatory skills, social functioning, and emotional/mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to understand the basic function of specific DNA sequences found near chromosomal centromeres – constricted regions to which spindle fibers attach, enabling duplicated chromosomes to segregate to opposite poles of a dividing cell. Tandemly repeated DNA sequences, called satellites, reside within these regions and their sequences have only recently been fully assembled, which allows for their full characterization for the first time. In cancer cells, these satellite sequences are misregulated such that they become expressed, and we aim to understand both their sequence diversity and consequences of their expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health, because a sustainable technology will be developed for the passive bioremediation of complex mixtures of groundwater contaminants, including chlorinated solvents and 1,4-dioxane via aerobic cometabolism. The co-encapsulation of pure cultures of bacteria along with slow release compounds in hydrogels beads has the potential to lower costs and achieve high treatment efficiencies. The beads can be used to treat a broad range of contaminants and in many different platforms, including permeable reactive barriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite their life-saving effectiveness, medications for opioid use disorder are often the subject of stigmatizing attitudes and actions, which has reduced their use in treatment and recovery settings. This form of stigma, known as Intervention Stigma, has been investigated using qualitative research, but existing methods to measure it are lacking, which prevents the development and testing of effective strategies to reduce stigmatizing beliefs and policies. This project will develop a measure of Intervention Stigma tailored for decision makers, healthcare personnel, and the general public, and will assess differences in endorsement and experience of Intervention Stigma among people with lived experience with opioid use disorder and those from racially minoritized groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: These studies will elucidate the roles of polyamines as endogenous glial cell molecules for extracellular signaling between glia and neurons in physiological and pathological situations. The results will provide important information for future efforts to understand and minimize neuronal damage during neurocognitive disorders, epilepsy and ischemia. Furthermore, the proposed studies should answer current critical questions regarding polyamine function in human CNS diseases, as well as lay the foundation for future work aimed at manipulating these processes therapeutically.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this proposal from the Association of Public Health Laboratories (APHL) is to support and enhance the capabilities of state human and animal food (HAF) testing laboratories that engage in surveillance and response activities associated with foodborne hazards, including foodborne outbreak investigations. APHL will build a competent HAF Laboratory workforce, plan and host conferences related to LFFM disciplines, the GenomeTrakr network, and NARMS, provide direct technical assistance to non-FDA funded HAF laboratories, maximize HAF laboratory participation in the GenomeTrakr network including development of the bioinformatics workforce, and promote information sharing between strategic partners. Leveraging our experience will better position FDA to work in partnership with state and local authorities to build an Integrated Food Safety System and achieve national public health goals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Building an Integrated Laboratory System to Advance the Safety of Human and Animal Food

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Autoimmune and immune-mediated diseases affect ~10% of the total population and are strongly inﬂuenced by genetic risk factors. These diseases severely affect the quality of life and can lead to fatality in their advanced stages. Early diagnosis and intervention in the preclinical phase before the diseases fully develop are critical for slowing down the progression, mitigating symptoms, and improving the quality of life. Developing software tools to understand the genetic risk factors that affect the progression from preclinical phase to disease states is of great public health relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The current pipeline of talent is insufficient to improve diversity in the scientific workforce in diabetes and metabolic diseases research. The Joslin-Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center Post-bac Program in Diabetes and Metabolism will recruit recent post-baccalaureates and provide them with the scientific, technical, and professional skills they will need to pursue doctoral degrees and the inspiration to dedicate their talents for prevention, treatment, and cure of diabetes and related metabolic disorders. By partnering with the Biomedical Sciences Career Program, University of Massachusetts Amherst, and Harvard College and by leveraging Handshake, a well-established online job-posting platform, we will identify and recruit diverse cohorts of post- bac participants to our program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Communication disorders, including hearing loss, swallowing difficulty, and impaired speech, are common in head and neck cancer survivors. The proposed research aims to test novel methods of increasing compliance with ototoxicity monitoring and identify clinical predictors of poor speech and swallowing function in older head and neck cancer survivors. This K24 will also allow Dr. Schmitt to pursue additional training in patient-oriented research and train the next generation of clinician-scientists in otolaryngology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The Minnesota Postbaccalaureate Research Education Programs in Diabetes, Endocrinology, and Metabolic Diseases Program (MN-PRIDE) fills a crucial gap at the University of Minnesota (UMN) by training the next generation of diverse researchers dedicated to addressing diabetes and its associated health issues. This endeavor is made possible through the collaboration of experienced faculty members known for their excellent mentoring and cutting-edge core facilities, creating an exceptional training program for our participants. The goal of the MN- PRIDE program is to help participants build a robust research portfolio, which will facilitate their smooth transition into research-focused doctoral degree (PhD, MD/PhD) programs, thus supporting their success in conducting research related to diabetes, endocrinology, and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a blood cancer that carries poor prognosis. Thus, novel therapies are needed to cure these patients. Our group has discovered that a protein called EGFL7 promotes AML. Targeting this protein using an antibody is a promising new way to kill AML cells. In this application, we propose to elucidate how EGFL7 facilitates leukemia and to develop novel combination therapies for AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Protein aggregation is associated with diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease and ALS, as well as biologically functional biomolecular condensates. Our project focuses on how molecular chaperones manage both types of aggregates. Understanding these important molecular mechanisms will broadening our general understanding of protein aggregation and uncover new avenues for chaperone-based therapies to treat these fatal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because there are a number of glutamate rich Intrinsically Disordered Regions (IDR), especially in the proteins that form the contractile machinery of muscle. The focus of the proposed work is to develop an understanding of the chemical and biological nature of nanoparticles with IDPs attached and what environmental signatures lead to changes in those properties. As a result, this work is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission pertaining to developing knowledge of basic biological mechanisms, which will facilitate the development of novel sensors that will have both potential therapeutic and research applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Nearly a quarter of diabetic patients develop a foot ulcer, which negatively affects the patients’ quality of life and productivity and is a substantial financial burden to the health care system. It is estimated that 12% of these individuals require lower extremity amputation. Current treatment options are costly, demonstrated mixed results and do not actively prevent infection. Current proposal evaluates a novel multifunctional bioadhesive’s ability to simultaneously promote wound healing and prevent infection, though the manipulation of a unique, biomimetic adhesive molecule and redox chemistry.

PHR: The patterns of astrocytic activity and their relationships with behaviors in health and disease conditions remain largely unexplored, due to the lack of high-speed volumetric imaging system. PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop a new computational paradigm to drastically accelerate the inversion of ultrasound measurements for imaging and the optimization of insonation profiles for therapies using limited computer resources. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This collaborative project utilizes synthetic organic chemistry, physical organic chemistry, and microbiological analysis to develop novel disinfectant compounds to combat pathogenic bacteria, and shed light on why bacteria can resist the traditional disinfectants that have been used for nearly a century. Moving beyond traditional structural classes of disinfectants that have become susceptible to bacterial resistance, we will develop fundamentally different structures that, when paired with careful analyses of their physical properties and solution behavior, will shape the next generation of antimicrobials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2D) vary markedly from one another in terms of their clinical features and response to treatment, but efforts to identify subtypes of diabetes are limited and have not yet been translated into clinical care. Our proposal aims to advance prior approaches by combining multiple data types together – clinical features, genetic information, and metabolomic markers – to identify specific subtypes of T2D that can predict treatment response and disease complications. We also plan to develop and assess simpler versions of these novel T2D subtypes that can be easily used by clinicians with the ultimate goal of improving personalized care of patients with T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) together are the largest causes of disability and death from chronic lung diseases worldwide. One of the key mechanisms causing both diseases is aberrant airway communication between the cells lining the airways in the lung (airway epithelial cells) and cells of the immune system, which leads to inflammation and remodeling of the lungs and airways. Our overall objective is to comprehensively define the signaling and spatial relationships between airway epithelial cells and airway immune cell populations in asthma and COPD to define therapeutic approaches that precisely target disease- specific mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Aggregation of serum amyloid A (SAA) and the formation of circulating amyloid fibrils is pivotal to the development of SAA amyloidosis which is a potentially life-threatening complication of chronic inflammatory diseases. The focus of this proposal is to experimentally determine the mechanism of SAA misfolding and compare it to recent theoretical models. A better understanding of the mechanism of SAA aggregation will lay the foundation for the development of potential therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancer immune surveillance depends on the presentation of tumor antigens and priming of antitumor T cells by myeloid antigen presenting cells, eg. macrophages and dendritic cells. A strategy to engage myeloid cells in antitumor immunity based on recombinant, highly attenuated poliovirus has shown great promise in Phase-1 clinical trials in glioblastoma and melanoma. In this project, we will investigate means to enhance immune stimulatory signaling in myeloid cells by modulating glucose metabolism with metabolic modifiers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Principle Investigator/Program Director (Last, first, middle): Dong, Vy, M Project Narrative Transition metal catalysis has significantly transformed the methods in which medicines are discovered and prepared. This can be seen through Nobel prize-winning work on asymmetric hydrogenation, metathesis, and C-C coupling reactions. There remains a conscious effort to produce enantioselective transformations that occur with high selectivity and atom-economy in order to furnish enantioenriched biomolecules. By use of transition metal catalysts, chemists have uncovered the functionalization of C-H bonds that previously were deemed inert. A particular motif of interest for small-molecule and natural product design are nitrogen-containing heterocycles. These strained ring systems such as cyclopropenes, azetidines, and cyclobutanes, all have been exploited in medicinal chemistry for their physicochemical properties and applications as functional group bioisosteres. Our program has a strong interest in utilizing the transformative power of hydroacylation—a process where C-H bond activation occurs with C-C bond formation, to introduce a creative method for resolving chiral strained rings. This work would not only develop more efficient methods to access such privileged motifs, but simultaneously open the door to future synthetic strategies in this chemical space.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health, as it will foster a better understanding of the relative influences psychological, social, and epigenomic factors have on cLBP and will also give insight into the mechanism the drives racial disparities in cLBP. The proposed project is in response to NIAMS RFA-AR-20-001, Mechanistic Ancillary Studies to Ongoing Clinical Projects. This work lays the foundation for a long-term program of research in developing targeted interventions to reduce cLBP disability and improve outcomes for racial minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study uses existing data gathered for other research to determine if white blood cells have a special response to severe tissue damage. This will help us understand why the white blood cells of some critically ill patients behave very differently than in other patients. Ultimately this understanding may help scientists find new ways to support the beneficial effects of inflammation on wound healing and immunity, while avoiding the harm uncontrolled inflammation can cause.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The All of Us Research Program, with its comprehensive electronic health records and whole genome sequencing, promises a discovery-rich environment to compare and contrast the multifarious contributors to a cancer diagnosis. Using data from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) and other major cancer-genomics repositories, we will move beyond tumor-specific phenotypes and explore the whole individual to find novel links, comorbidities, and triggers that fill the gaps in predicting cancer occurrence. The All of Us Research Program provides an optimal environment to address cancer questions and train undergraduates to become the next generation of bioinformaticians because of its comprehensive ethics training, exposure to cloud infrastructure, and sound practices to generate reproducible code.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Children and adults with type 1 diabetes (T1D) may develop declines in brain function over time, however, the causes of these declines are not well understood. In the proposed longitudinal study, we will evaluate children beginning at T1D diagnosis and over time using measurements of cognition, brain structure and metabolism, and systemic and neural inflammation. We will determine how diabetes-related variables such as glucose levels and glucose variability, exposure to diabetic ketoacidosis and episodes of hypoglycemia predict neurocognitive differences over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: It is estimated that ~15% of cancers are caused by virus infections. Viruses are intracellular parasites which lack their own metabolism, so they must hijack host cell metabolic machinery to create more energy, proteins, fats, and genetic material necessary to replicate. This proposal seeks to identify clinically relevant ant-metabolic drugs to treat herpesvirus infections that cause cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Proper control of cell division is crucial for the replenishment of hundreds of billions of blood cells on a daily basis. Mutations that disrupt the genetic machinery regulating cell division can cause cancer. This project would advance our understanding of the genetic machinery that stops cell division during the maturation of white blood cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The goal of this study is to understand the mechanisms of glucose sensing through the plasma membrane of yeast. The results of this research will provide significant insights into the processes involved in the maintenance of glucose homeostasis in humans, especially under pathological conditions, such as hyperglycemia in diabetics and the elevated rate of glycolysis observed in many solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Drugs of abuse cause addiction, negatively impact individuals, and costs the government ~$450 billion dollars/yr. in related expenses. In addition, the opiate epidemic has seen a 10-fold increase in opioid-caused deaths in the last 5 years, but unfortunately, we do not understand the full actions of opiates on the reward system and no selective treatment to alleviate addiction in general is available. We hope that by examining normal function in the brain’s reward center and more fully exploring morphine-induced negative impact in the reward circuit, it will provide a more complete picture for addiction treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During early development, patterning of the embryo into separate domains is essential to ensure the correct size and placement of subsequent tissue formation; indeed, disruption of this process can lead to malformations of structures such as the craniofacial bones in human patients. Multiple members of the TGF signaling pathway, including BMP, are essential for patterning events. Here, we seek to determine the molecular function of the Masp1 protein in contributing to patterning of the embryonic ectoderm through intersection with BMP signaling with implications for our understanding of Masp1- associated developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our overarching goal is to integrate clinical and multi-omic data into prediabetes and type 2 diabetes classification and build prediction models of disease trajectories over the lifespan. Our central hypothesis is that multi-omic data can refine definitions of type 2 diabetes, identify those patients most like to develop complications, and better identify people at risk for future development of type 2 diabetes. Our approach is to apply sophisticated clustering in diverse, longitudinal cohorts over rich omics data to identify subgroups of individuals who develop type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative In the post-COVID era, adoption of telepractice delivery of speech intervention has continued to grow due to its greater flexibility and efficiency and its ability to enhance access to specialized services such as visual-acoustic biofeedback. The proposed research will meet a public health need by expanding our basic understanding of perception-production relations in child speech while evaluating whether tasks involving perceptual training and biofeedback intervention are valid in the online modality. This translational research aligns with NIDCD’s mission to improve the lives of individuals with communication disorders, as it will explore the relationship between auditory-enhanced treatments and expand evidence for the online delivery of biofeedback intervention to sibilants, an additional class of frequently misarticulated sounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The project will establish a novel generation of personalized cardiac patch devices for remuscularization of heart with postinfarction LV remodeling, which is one of the most significant problem in public health. The central hypothesis is that the novel bioengineered and perfusable cardiac patch using novel hiPSC lines, can remuscularize the ischemic injured heart using minimally invasive technologies. The findings will have significant impact in diagnostic and treatment of heart failure, and improve the public health.

PHR: Project Narrative - Relevance  Using the Pavlovian fear conditioning paradigm, the proposed experiments outlined in this document will expand the current literature on the physiological underpinnings of fear memory storage. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no effective surgical strategies for the repair of volumetric muscle loss (VML) injuries. A nonsurgical strategy capable of restoring the muscle function that is lost to VML injury could improve the quality of life, enable a return to work, and ease the burdens associated with activities of daily living for thousands of people each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Leishmania parasites cause 0.7-1.3 million new cases and 50000-90000 deaths each year. Current treatments are inadequate and more research on Leishmania biology is needed to develop new drugs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Parkinson's disease (PD) is a chronic and progressive movement disorder, affecting one million people in the U.S. Our goal is to investigate the interaction between alpha-synuclein aggregates and neuronal membranes, which is believed to play an important role in PD development and progression. Such information will facilitate the ultimate development of the PD treatment modality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many cancer survivors experience challenges in performing daily activities and loss of work productivity due to the adverse effects of cancer and its treatments, resulting in financial burdens for both individuals and society. The overarching goal of this U34 Clinical Trials Planning Grant is to gather information regarding the feasibility of and barriers to implementing a remotely delivered exercise intervention in a diverse population of cancer patients, as well as to gain insight into the population of cancer patients most like to exercise a decline in function as a result of cancer treatment. Study results will be used to inform the development of a Phase III trial to assess the efficacy of an efficient technology-enabled exercise oncology intervention to prevent the decline in physical function often observed in patients receiving chemotherapy, toward the goal of increasing the capacity for full employment after cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goals of this research are to develop novel and high-impact statistical and computational tools to address some of the key analytical challenges in joint modeling of bulk-tissue and single-cell sequencing data. These methods will enable biomedical scientists to simultaneously characterize multi-level genomic variations and to accurately disentangle within- and between-subject cellular heterogeneity. The successful completion of the project will greatly facilitate the translation of basic research findings into clinical studies of human disease and have substantial implications for diagnosis and prognosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Often a social activity, problematic alcohol use (PAU) poses significant health problems in college students and may best be remedied by others intervening to stop this harmful behavior (bystander intervention). We currently do not understand why, when, and where PAU bystander intervention happens, because we currently have no way of assessing bystander behaviors in these situations. The proposed project extends our team's current work by finalizing the development of measures of PAU bystander behaviors across our recently developed Bystander Intervention for Problematic Alcohol Use Model (BIPAUM) and statistically testing the BIPAUM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Encapsulating drugs in polymer nanoparticles is a common strategy for improving their bioavailability, but there is currently a significant gap in our fundamental understanding of the formation process, leaving much of the development and optimization reliant on qualitative assessments and trial-and-error methods. This project aims to develop a general model for the creation of drug-encapsulated nanoparticles while also providing valuable training opportunities for multiple undergraduate students in a highly multidisciplinary domain, thereby contributing to the education of future drug development researchers. Anticipated outcomes include the formulation of design principles that will serve as a blueprint for a diverse spectrum of nanoparticle drug formulations, addressing a wide array of medical conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Preeclampsia is one of the most common pregnancy complications and involves high blood pressure and organ damage late in pregnancy. This project seeks to understand why women who survive preeclampsia have a much higher risk of developing heart disease after pregnancy, using new animal models of preeclampsia to examine how inflammation plays a role in the long-term process. The ultimate goal is to identify novel targets and treatments for women after preeclampsia to prevent future disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Proteins driving cellular death programs contribute to inflammation underlying tissue injury during infectious diseases. How they contribute in different cells to dictate protective versus injurious inflammation remains unresolved. We hypothesize that during critical illness or sepsis some members of cellular death programs contribute to essential protective inflammation, whereas other members emerge as potential therapy targets as they drive injurious inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The increased frequency and severity in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms has resulted in the increased presence of toxic microcystins (MCs) freshwater sources used for drinking water. Recently, we found that sub- chronic ingestion of non-lethal MC-LR levels caused the stress response in mice to be maladaptive, which may trigger non-physiological conditions favorable for anxiety or depression. Here, we probe whether maternal ingestion of MC-LR disrupts the formation and function of the stress response in the offspring, with the goal to elucidate how ingestion of environmental MCs may cause generational deficits in the stress response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular disease is a leading cause of death worldwide and in the USA with this due to two key underlying reasons: 1.a progressive disease called atherosclerosis and 2.thrombosis. The adequate localization of therapeutics to atherosclerotic plaque or thrombi remains a challenge for current therapies. My goal is to study the targeted delivery of therapeutics to atherosclerotic plaque and thrombi, using cell-mediated therapeutic delivery coupled with next-generation nanoparticle synthesis technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Candida albicans is among the most common fungal pathogens of humans, causing debilitating and life- threatening infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals. C. albicans can switch reversibly between two distinct pathogenic cell types – white and opaque – however the genes that underlie the unique virulence attributes of the opaque cell type are largely unknown and fundamental questions remain regarding the molecular mechanisms that govern switching between these two cell types. This proposal seeks to understand the role of white-opaque switching in C. albicans virulence and to uncover fundamental mechanisms that enable the heritable maintenance of the opaque cell type across hundreds of generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The negative regulation of inflammation is necessary to prevent an overzealous response. Perturbations in the balance of an appropriate response, either too aggressive or attenuated, underlie immunopathology, transformation and chronic metabolic syndrome. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of negative regulation of inflammation will be necessary for the generation of new strategies to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Smooth muscle cells (SMCs) play major roles in atherosclerosis, a leading cause of cardiovascular disease (CVD). Recent studies, including ours, applying SMC-lineage tracing murine models, human atherosclerosis plaques, and single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq), revealed novel SMC-derived cells during progression of atherosclerosis. The research outlined in this proposal aims to reveal molecular mechanisms governing a novel SMC-derived cell type in atherosclerosis and modulating functions of this cell type in established atherosclerosis and during disease regression, which will contribute to critical efforts to identify and understand novel molecular and cellular targets for prevention and treatment of atherosclerotic CVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to public health: The effective transport of drugs across biological membranes is critical to their ability to reach their target tissues from the site of administration, and particularly important for the potency of drugs with intracellular targets. While our knowledge of the role of active transport proteins in drug transport, the role of membrane proteins in mediating the passive flux of drugs is far less complete. These studies will hopefully she further light on the potential role of ion channels in mediating the movement of small molecule drugs across biological membranes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart disease is responsible for over 600,000 deaths annually, making it the number one killer of women and men in the United States. There are currently no small diameter vascular grafts that effectively treat this disease. This proposal seeks to use computational tools to fabricate a fully biodegradable small diameter vascular tissue engineered graft that is and remains compliance matched as it remodels in-vivo.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will provide recent college graduates from under-represented minority groups with an intensive two-year mentored research experience in a laboratory that studies diabetes, endocrinology, and metabolism, and tailored professional development coursework to successfully guide them through the graduate school application process and ensure their success in completing a research-focused biomedical degree program (PhD or MD/PhD). Through our proposed recruitment efforts and multi-layered mentoring approach, this proposal will build and enhance the diversity of the biomedical research workforce in NIDDK mission areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Type1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1D) affects an estimated ~150,000 youth in the U.S., with ~18,000 youth diagnosed annually, yet much remains unknown about the clinical, developmental, and environmental effects of T1D on neurocognitive function. This proposal will establish a UNC clinical research center to participate in the T1D consortium to evaluate the neurocognitive complications of pediatric T1D and identify potential risks and protective factors that affect brain and cognitive development trajectories in children with a first-time diagnosis of T1D. The project will contribute to a multi-site clinical research infrastructure to recruit and retain children and families with T1D through stakeholder engagement and effective dissemination, and will develop predictive models integrating multimodal brain, behavior and clinical data to assist in risk stratification and development of effective targeted early interventions and clinical care practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Radon is a colorless, odorless, toxic radioactive gas and radon exposure is rising steadily within the modern North American residential environment. The proposed study aims to examine the association between radon exposure and stroke risk and to investigate whether the distribution of radon concentration is a reason for the racial and geographic variations of stroke rate in the US. Since randomized clinical trials on radon exposure is not feasible, findings from this study will provide crucial information to help identify a potential modifiable common risk factor for stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ATP sensitive potassium channels (KATP) couple metabolic changes to changes in a cell’s electrical excitability, providing a crucial trigger for insulin secretion in response to elevated blood glucose and a protective response to ischemia in the heart. We have developed a combined spectroscopic and electrophysiological approach to study changes in the structure and function of KATP in response to metabolism. Understanding this process will illuminate KATP’s physiological role, provide mechanistic insight into diseases of KATP dysfunction (like neonatal diabetes), and serve as a template for understanding the structure/activity relationships of other protein complexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single-cell sequencing of clinical specimens uniquely enables studies of tissue heterogeneity, a significant barrier to precision medicine. However, the use of single-cell assays for clinical decision making is limited. This project bridges that gap and develops algorithms to integrate heterogeneous single-cell datasets to support the selection of combination therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cervical Cancer prevention programs treat Black Women as a cultural and ethnic monolith. The proposed project uses a cross-sectional, mixed-methods design to: 1) identify the distinct determinants of routine cervical cancer screening and follow-up among Black African Immigrant Women and African American Women and 2) determine the intervention components that can be tailored to address the relevant multi-level factors influencing cervical cancer screening and follow-up among both populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The signals sent from our brain to control our muscles require intricate interactions among large populations neurons in motor cortex and striatum. Recent advances in understanding population motor coding indicate the importance of high-dimensional geometric neural representations of body movement, but how these newly discovered motor coding mechanisms go wrong in brain disorders with motor dysfunction is unknown. The research proposed here would engage undergraduate researchers and reveal how high dimensional geometry of motor coding is disrupted in a transgenic animal model of Rett syndrome, a severe neurological disorder with prominent motor dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autoimmune diseases (ADs) affect over 25 million Americans, inflicting tremendous individual suffering and societal burdens. Exposure to the earth’s most abundant mineral, crystalline silica (quartz), is common in individuals involved in construction, mining, farming, manufacturing and military deployment and increases their risk of developing systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus) and other ADs. Here we seek to understand the underlying mechanisms by which consumption of the omega-3 fatty acid docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) blocks silica-triggered lupus, thus yielding important new insights into how environmental toxicants trigger AD and how manipulating the lipidome through dietary fatty acid supplementation can prevent it.

During my PhD I have helped develop an RNA liquid biopsy platform that the F99 will enable me to lead a validation for in patients diagnosed with lung adenocarcinoma. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most internal organs consist of a monolayer of polarized epithelial cells surrounding a central lumen, which functions to establish a barrier that segregates the internal medium from the outside environment in tissues and organs. This proposal will uncover the fundamental mechanisms controlling the function of a novel protein complex that coordinates junctional assembly, stability, and turnover in epithelial cells. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of these fundamental processes, which are essential for tissue morphogenesis and organ development, is a major obstacle in our quest to develop therapies treat or prevent epithelial cancers, which are mostly from epithelial origin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although, the importance of AR-regulating long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) has long been speculated, the direct negative regulation of AR (and AR-V7) transcription by lncRNA has not yet been reported. Serendipitously, we identified a lncRNA, NXTAR (LOC105373241), located convergently to the AR gene that is repressed in human prostate tumors and cell lines, and discovered that its reinstatement promotes binding upstream of the AR promoter, causing significant loss of expression of AR and its splice variant AR-V7.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life adversity significantly alters the trajectory to develop substance use disorders. These experiments use longitudinal animal models to manipulate a critical developmental period and utilize neuropharmacology and behavioral methods to reveal modulatory mechanisms of opioid reward and consummatory behaviors. Meeting these objectives will identify a critical developmental window and neurobiological alterations in serotonin receptor function that create vulnerable and resilient phenotypes in the context of opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Microcystins (MCs), anabenopeptins (APs), and cyanopeptolins (CPs) are toxic cyanopeptides that exist as multiple congeners and appear during harmful cyanobacterial blooms in Lake Erie and other water bodies. To avoid a potential threat to citizens that use those waterbodies as source of drinking water or other activities, the structures and toxicities of previously unreported congeners of these cyanotoxins must be investigated. Identification and purification of novel MC, AP, and CP congeners and will enable important investigation of their toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Environmentally benign organosilanes are increasingly utilized in an impressively wide range of synthetic applications pertaining to biomedically significant agents, catalysts, and drug delivery systems. The objectives of the proposed research program are to establish new, efficient synthetic strategies for the rapid and selective generation of various high-value synthetic building blocks and biologically significant molecules. Achieving success in these endeavors will expedite the utilization of a range of novel small molecules in drug discovery and development, ultimately contributing to the advancement of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE (Project Narrative) The ideal, most efficient and cost-effective tool to reduce, eliminate and eventually eradicate malaria, which has devastating effects causing 241 million clinical cases and 627,000 deaths worldwide in 2020 alone, would be a highly effective, long-acting vaccine that prevents infection, disease and parasite transmission. Sanaria® PfSPZ vaccines are the leading candidates that fit these characteristics. This proposal will accelerate the licensure and marketing of the safest and most protective PfSPZ vaccine (anticipated to be PfSPZ-LARC2) by providing support for the Quality Assurance, Quality Control, Manufacturing, Regulatory and Clinical tasks required for the submission of licensure applications in Europe and the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to develop targeted, non-pharmacologic interventions to increase DNA repair in healthy cells decreasing chemotherapy-linked stem cell senescence to improve clinical outcomes and quality of life in cancer survivors. This project will yield a novel understanding of how external mechanical force in the form of low intensity vibration can decrease side effects and long-term sequelae following chemotherapeutic treatment modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibodies play a vital and growing role in life science applications, such as protein therapeutics. The research described in this proposal is designed to explore new methods to generate pH dependent antibodies. The relevance of this project to public health is two-fold: (1) it will provide new opportunities for the use of antibodies to preferentially target certain microenvironments, such as that found in cancerous tumors, and (2) it will provide fundamental insight towards the development and novel use of protein reagents for life science applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because defects in membrane remodeling underlie debilitating diseases from cancer to neurological disorders, and because membrane trafficking vesicles serve as the cellular entry mechanism for both harmful pathogens and therapeutic drugs. Therefore, the proposed research on the basic physical mechanisms underlying membrane remodeling is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability and disease. Ultimately, it is envisioned that a fundamental understanding of membrane remodeling will enable therapeutic manipulation of membrane traffic and other points of intersection between membranes and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE. Loss-of-function mutations in PTEN-induced kinase 1 (PINK1) contribute to a recessive form of Parkinson's disease with early cognitive dysfunction. In the prior grant period, we discovered that loss of PINK1 results in diminished numbers of dendritic spines, particularly the type of spine most closely associated with long- term memory storage. We will determine whether mitochondrial transport into dendrites is impaired by loss of PINK1, and how PINK1 activity regulates brain cell responses involved in learning and memory in cultured mouse and human neurons. These studies will help identify new strategies to prevent or slow the loss of brain cell function in Parkinson's disease and related neurodegenerative dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alkyne hydrofunctionalization is a fundamentally important and challenging organic transformation for atom-efficient construction of carbon-heteroatom bonds from abundant building blocks. Our proposed research aims to advance the method development and mechanism understanding of nickel-catalyzed alkyne hydrofunctionalization reactions assisted by alkyne-tethered directing groups. This work will provide new synthetic methods for heteroatom-containing molecules that are valuable in biomedical research and drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Neuropeptides play a critical role in cell signaling, mediating development, physiology, and behavior. Abnormalities in the synthesis, trafficking or release of neuropeptides have been strongly linked with a wide range of neurological and neurodegenerative diseases and disorders like Alzheimer’s. Completion of these studies will elucidate potential mechanisms, pathways, and proteins that could be candidate targets for genetic and pharmacological treatments once their roles in governing neuropeptides in the nervous system are illuminated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative During sleep, patients who suffer from obstructive sleep apnea stop breathing many times a night because upper airway muscles including the tongue collapse and block the airway, which leads to cyclically low levels of oxygen. This project will test the hypothesis that the cyclical low levels of oxygen change the effects of acetylcholine (normally released during sleep) at the motoneurons that control the tongue. This proposal will advance understanding of this important mechanism that regulates airway tone during sleep to facilitate discovery of potential novel treatment options for obstructive sleep apnea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal adult-onset neurological disease in which motor neurons degenerate, thereby leading to paralysis and death due to respiratory failure. There are no existing therapies that specifically target the repeat expansions in the C9ORF72 gene that are known to cause ALS. Acrobat Genomics will protein engineer optimized and compact RNA- guided nucleases to precisely target and deplete repeat-bearing C9ORF72 transcripts as a potential therapeutic for patients with ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Control of protein synthesis by translational regulation is a critical layer of regulation for development and homeostasis of the nervous system. When this process goes awry, it can lead to the onset of developmental and degenerative neurological disorders. This proposal will investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms that coordinate translational regulatory networks associated with neuron specification and wiring, providing fundamental insights that can be translated into therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nucleobases are critical for nucleic acid synthesis, macromolecules that are essential for all forms of life. This proposal focuses on identifying mechanisms used by Clostridioides difficile to salvage an unconventional, toxic, modified uracil nucleobase from the vertebrate gastrointestinal tract, an environment depleted of conventional nucleobases. Completion of studies proposed herein has the potential to define a cellular pathway for detoxifying and utilizing 4-thiouracil as a nucleobase source and elucidate the importance of 4-thiouracil metabolism during C. difficile pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative An estimated two out of three Americans experience some form of cognitive impairment, ranging from mild to severe dementia, by age 70. There is a need to understand the molecular and epigenetic regulation of memory in the aging brain to develop therapeutic intervention strategies to preserve cognitive function in old age. The experiments in this proposal will determine if HDAC3 phosphorylation is necessary and sufficient mechanism for HDAC’s epigenetic regulation of long-term memory formation in the young and aging brain an if dysregulation in this mechanism contributes to age-related memory impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemic heart disease affects more than 197 million patients worldwide every year and is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the endogenous mechanisms of angiogenesis and myocardial regeneration following ischemic injury in neonatal mouse and pig models. By investigating the single-cell spatial relationships and paracrine signaling of efficient, complete neovascularization and myocardial regeneration in neonatal mammals, the results of this study will inform future translational research efforts to reactivate key pathways in adults, which has the potential to benefit millions of patients with ischemic heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS) patients are considered to be accumulating mutations in the bone marrow before the onset of characteristic symptoms. DDX41 is one of the most frequently mutated genes in MDS and its functional role has not been fully understood. We will study the functional role of DDX41 in MDS and reveal its function in G4 accumulation.
