IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) may be an effective avenue for preventing adolescent mental health challenges; however, to maximize its potential requires a deeper understanding of processes underlying MBI efficacy. The proposed study will conduct a mechanistic investigation of the role of engagement (i.e., the degree of productive involvement in an activity) in adolescent MBI through examining the longitudinal, time-ordered change associations between engagement and target processes of MBI (e.g., emotion regulation and mindfulness), as well as integrating qualitative data with quantitative findings to identify facilitators and barriers to engagement. Findings may provide important directions for individuals involved in the development and delivery of MBI in terms of leveraging engagement to support adolescents in deriving maximal benefit from MBIs.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phthalates are common chemicals in the environment that can disrupt hormones and change how the body accumulates and stores fat. When pregnant women are exposed to these chemicals it may have negative impacts on their children, including increasing their risk for obesity. We will investigate how being exposed to these chemicals before birth is linked to childhood obesity, and whether certain diets can help prevent this.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this work is to understand function of specific cell types in cortical microcircuits, focusing on inhibitory interneurons, and similarities and differences in their local network impacts in sensory and association areas of cortex. Two-photon imaging of calcium activity is used to monitor the responses of hundreds of genetically labeled inhibitory and excitatory neurons, while subjects perform a sound localization task in virtual reality. These experiments will lead to the development of testable models of the local circuit mechanisms underlying flexible information processing across cortex, with relevance for brain disorders with altered cognitive flexibility, such as schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative  Urinary incontinence (UI) and symptoms of overactive bladder (OAB) become more prevalent with age, and because the impact on the elderly and their caregivers makes it difficult to continue at-home care, UI is a top reason for institutionalizing the elderly. More than half of nursing home residents have UI and over ¾ of those with dementia have UI. The current application proposes to develop new formulations of drugs that are instilled into the bladder (intravesical delivery) and produce long-term relief of symptoms (> 3 months) in patients who are refractory to current therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will address a critical health care disparity by adapting an evidence-based suicide risk detection and management program, the NIMH Clinical Pathway, to be delivered in the rural Appalachian school-based health care setting. Implementation strategies, materials, and data from this project will be used to facilitate the widespread adoption and evaluation of the pathway as a routine suicide risk detection management program across rural Appalachia. This addresses the critical need for effective and sustainable suicide prevention programs for this high-risk, underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Circadian rhythm and sleep disruptions are central to major psychiatric diseases like major depression, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia. Better understanding of how rhythms are altered in these diseases will facilitate design of targeted treatments to realign or amplify disrupted rhythms. Synchronization of these rhythms may prevent the precipitation of manic, depressive, or psychotic episodes and help in overall mood stabilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Postpartum depression impacts 1 in 8 women with a live birth and has well-documented negative effects on maternal and infant health. In this K01, Dr. Gordon will evaluate how postpartum Medicaid policies affect screening, diagnosis, and treatment for postpartum depression among low-income mothers in the postpartum year, contributing timely and policy-relevant evidence to reduce income-based disparities in maternal mental health. Dr. Gordon’s mentorship team and training in the delivery of mental health services, mixed-methods research, qualitative methods, and tools to measure and map area-level variation in policy effects will support her goal of becoming an independent mental health services researcher focusing on access to mental health care among low-income populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Understanding Neurocognition in Youth with Type 1 Diabetes (UNYT1D) multi-institution clinical consortium will develop and implement a uniform protocol to investigate the neurocognitive impact of new onset type 1 diabetes (T1D) in pre-pubertal children. Our Biostatistics Research Center for UNYT1D will provide scientific leadership for the consortium and consortium-wide infrastructure related to stakeholder engagement, data management and sharing, study design and statistical analysis, and governance and coordination of consortium activities. By combining these activities into a single hub, the BRC will promote rigorous and reproducible research across the consortium and help UNYT1D achieve its scientific objectives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer progression is heavily influenced by supportive cells in the tumor microenvironment. The project aims to investigate the previously unknown connection between TREM1-positive leukemia-associated macrophages (LAMs) and leukemogenesis. If successfully completed, the project would uncover novel roles of TREM1 in LAM- leukemia interaction during leukemia development, and yield valuable information on whether targeting TREM1 or its signaling components may be therapeutically useful in the prevention and treatment of leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Elevating Indigenous Wellbeing through Assets-Based Prevention Science (ELEVATE) Training Program seeks to address significant health inequities in premature mortality faced by Indigenous communities by equipping a new generation of scholars with specialized training in prevention science and health equity research. The ELEVATE program addresses key gaps in funding and training for Indigenous health and is aligned with NIH priorities related to addressing health disparities and building a robust and diverse public health scientific workforce. By focusing on the key mental and behavioral health drivers of early mortality, such as suicide and drug- and alcohol-related deaths, this initiative aims to nurture Indigenous and other diverse leadership in scientific research and shape a healthier future for these communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss affects over 40 million adults in the United States and can negatively impact many areas of life for adults. The lack of access to diagnostic hearing tests prevents timely diagnosis and treatment of hearing loss, especially, among adults who live in rural areas. This study will (1) evaluate the experiences and challenges in obtaining hearing tests among adults who live in rural areas and are patients at rural health clinics, and (2) develop a program, in partnership with rural patients and medical providers, which can help rural adults get easier access to hearing tests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research addresses a conundrum: Why do twice as many boys as girls receive services to treat Developmental Language Disorder when community samples reveal gender parity in the prevalence of the condition? This research will advance public health by determining the extent to which gender-specific patterns of compensation or disability on the part of the children or gender bias on the part of parents and professionals contribute to the treatment disparity. Either outcome holds direct implications for refining the tools and processes used to diagnose and treat DLD and the polices by which we distribute limited clinical resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to contribute to a consortium of studies that will generate new knowledge on the physiological drivers of type 2 diabetes subtypes by providing an expert team and an extensive array of data from existing studies. We will use hard-clustering and soft-clustering statistical methods coupled with phenotypic, genotypic, and metabolomic data to develop a framework for identifying reproducible and physiologically driven subtypes of type 2 diabetes. We believe that this information will be used by clinicians and patients to better guide type 2 diabetes prevention and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The present proposal will test the efficacy of two fumarate-based drugs, dimethyl fumarate (DMF) and its derivative IMF, to prevent or delay the development of lethal cardiomyopathy in Friedreich's ataxia (FA). Currently, there are no drug therapies that ameliorate FA cardiomyopathy and most with FA die of the cardiomyopathy in their 30s. We will identify the optimal dosing and determine underlying cardioprotective mechanisms of these drugs in validated mouse models of FA which can generate important pre-clinical data because it would address the primary cause of mortality in Friedreich's patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE FDA-approved mineralocorticoid receptor (MR) antagonists (MRAs) have clinical benefits for cardiomyopathy in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) patients and preclinical benefits on skeletal muscle pathology. However, their effects on skeletal muscle fibroblasts, the cell type involved in deleterious fibrosis, have not been defined. This application will define direct and indirect effects of MRAs on fibroblasts to optimize MR modulation for DMD, other muscle diseases and for muscle injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss and balance problems affect millions of people world-wide and are most commonly caused by loss of specialized cells called hair cells, which are small mechanical sensors that send information about hearing and balance to the brain. In this project, we use mouse tissues to understand the different types of RNA that cells from the inner ear organs make. We will look to see how different types of RNA shape these organs in young and adult mice to ultimately learn how to treat hearing and balance disorders in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Myotonic dystrophy type 2 is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle wasting and weakness that is caused by long CCTG DNA repeats. Individuals can have up to 11,000 CCTG repeats within the gene responsible for disease. The proposed project will elucidate the molecular mechanisms of long CCTG repeats including contractions, DNA fragility, and effects on transcription using budding yeast S. cerevisiae as an experimental model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a prevalent childhood autoimmune disease, marked by the immune-driven destruction of insulin-producing pancreatic islet cells. Our proposed ancillary study within the Environmental Determinants of Diabetes in Young (TEDDY) project aims to enhance our comprehension of the relationship between infections in T1D triggering and progression, focusing on pivotal moments like autoantibody "seroconversion" and "stage 3 diabetes disease onset." This research will contribute to the advancement of innovative prevention approaches, including vaccination and other antimicrobial strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many individuals living with Type 1 diabetes (T1D) experience significant cognitive impairments, and strategies to decrease the likelihood of this chronic disease complication are needed. With this application, we propose a study to be implemented by a collaborative multisite consortium that will work with stakeholder partners to address current gaps in our knowledge regarding the underpinnings of neurocognitive changes in very young children with T1D. Success will ultimately be measured by the consortium elucidating modifiable determinants, enabling strategies to optimize neurocognitive functioning for persons living with T1D throughout their lifespans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Brain connections undergo short- and long-term modifications during developmental refinement of neural circuits, as well as in learning and memory. The proposed study investigates the actin-based mechanism underlying the development and modification of chemical synapses. This line of work is directly relevant to public health since it will contribute to our understanding of brain development and functions under both physiological and pathological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  People with schizophrenia are characterized by marked impairments in cognitive function, for which there are no current pharmacological treatments. The development of an effective intervention for cognitive impairments remains a major therapeutic challenge. Prebiotics are dietary fibers that promote the growth or activity of gut microorganisms, which leads to the enhanced well-being of the host. The proposed R61 and R33 projects are designed to evaluate the hypothesis that prebiotic administration will lead to increased production of butyrate, through increased activity of butyrate-producing bacteria in the gut microbiota; the increase in serum butyrate levels will be associated with changes in cognitive function, symptoms, and metabolic measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Organ transplantation as a lifesaving therapy remains constrained by severe complications associated with lifelong immunosuppression and relentless graft loss over time. Our project is designed to uncover novel mechanisms of innate immune responses that hinder transplant survival. Our proposed studies will also have broad implications in the design of new innovative therapies for transplant patients as well as for patients with autoimmune diseases and cancers.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is considerable interest in understanding factors that impact adolescent experiences of depression. We propose to conduct secondary data analysis with latent class and mixed modeling methods to holistically answer the question “How do caregiver experiences of discrimination, psychosocial factors, and environmental influences interact to influence adolescent depression over time?”. Findings from this study will improve our understanding of these complex dynamics, contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of the factors that impact adolescent depression, and could inform interventions and policies to support the well-being of adolescents in diverse contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many children with type 1 diabetes (T1D) are at risk of neurocognitive impairments, and these children often struggle with memory and learning deficits and the ability to pay attention. Throughout the study, our team will observe a group of diverse children with a new T1D diagnosis, and age-matched healthy control children, to identify nutritional and lifestyle behaviors, environmental exposures, and social determinants of health (SDOH) known to contribute to these neurocognitive outcomes. Our team will study these children over time to explore the potential protective effects of diabetes management technologies and other factors to defend children’s thinking and processing function and to protect their brain development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide are lung diseases, including Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disorder (COPD) and other chronic lung diseases (CLDs) which have no cure, have poor patient outcomes and increasing rapidly in prevalence. The Molecular Atlas of Lung Development Program (LungMap3) was created with the overarching goal to characterize the cellular and molecular causes of lung diseases in order to develop novel and more efficacious therapies. For LungMAP Phase 3, we propose to focus on three emerging concepts and current challenges in the field: 1) accurately and precisely phenotype adult human lung diseases at the spatial and single cell level with a focus on COPD, CLDs and more rare diseases including alpha-1 anti- trypsin deficiency (A1AT), 2) identify the molecular defects present in progenitor cell populations in human CLDs through spatial and genomic single cell resolution technologies, and 3) develop and implement new research models to better define the molecular and cellular defects that occur during the progression of CLDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In Alzheimer’s disease, immune cells in the brain called microglial cells become activated and drive disease. We will investigate the ability of regulatory T cells induced by the nasal administration of a monoclonal antibody against T cells to treat the 3xTg mouse model of AD by decreasing microglia and astrocyte activation. Our studies have translational possibilities given that such an antibody has been given to healthy volunteers and has shown positive effects in a pilot study of subjects suffering from COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of this proposal is to improve outcomes for bilingual patients in the Audiology Clinic. Bilingual listeners, even those who are highly proficient in their non-native language(s), may experience challenges when communicating in acoustically complex environments that are not accurately captured by current patient reported outcome measures utilized by clinicians. This work aims to determine the considerations necessary for interpreting patient reported outcome measures with a bilingual patient population, by establishing the relationships between objective and subjective suprathreshold auditory performance, native speaker status, and aging in bilingual adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This planned research will enroll a large, diverse cohort of pre-pubertal children shortly after T1D diagnosis, as well as comparison participants without T1D, and assess differences in cognitive function, academic achievement, MRI-based microstructural, volumetric, functional and physiological measures, as well as their relationship to glycemic and non-glycemic factors. We hypothesize that: 1) T1D impacts the developing brain, producing impairments in neurocognitive functioning compared to controls; 2) these impairments are mediated by risk and protective factors, such as magnitude and duration of blood glucose time in range, time spent in hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia, and episodes of severe hypoglycemia and DKA; and 3) indirect effects of hyperglycemia and non-glycemic factors will mediate the effect of hyperglycemia on cognitive function and brain development in children with T1D. The NYU Clinical Center (NYU CC) and the assembled team in this proposal have expertise in neurocognitive studies in T1D, neuroimaging in young children, diabetes management, data management, quality control, statistical analysis, and stakeholder engagement and aim to participate actively and collaboratively with the Biostatistics Research Coordinating Center (BRC), NIH, and other CC clinical sites in designing and implementing the study protocol to engage and follow a diverse population sample of children with recent onset of T1D and then disseminate the findings from the study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases of the lung are among the leading causes of death in the United States and worldwide. In Phase 3 of the Molecular Atlas of Lung Development Program (LungMAP), the data coordination center (DCC) in conjunction with its research centers and human tissue core, will work to define the regulatory mechanisms of lung disease progression and nominate new targets for therapy. To achieve this goal, the DCC will develop advanced systems biology resources and tools leveraging advances in artificial intelligence, harmonize LungMAP datasets and will coordinate educational outreach. 2

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: NARRATIVE Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) presents a major health hazard to our population and can be devastating to the individual, even with exogenous insulin treatment. The first immunotherapy was recently approved to delay progression to T1D, but there is no prevention or cure. Prevention will be enabled by understanding earlier pathogenesis. The proposed studies will investigate clonal expansion of T cells in stage 1 T1D as a biomarker of disease activity. These studies may guide timing and selection of early therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Human health depends on the appropriate control of gene expression, much of which is exerted at the assembly of the RNA polymerase II (Pol II) preinitiation complex (PIC) at promoters and the successful advance of Pol II into productive elongation. It is generally thought that the local chromatin structure of promoters is an important modulator of these processes but the mechanisms through which such control might occur are not well understood. Our goal is to reveal these mechanisms by biochemically dissecting Pol II initiation and early elongation in vitro in an appropriate chromatin context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A better understanding of the impact of failure and approaches that de-stigmatize and normalize failure are needed to assure greater success and retention of diverse students in the biomedical sciences. The goal of this research is to understand the impact of a video intervention on student responses to failure in two educational contexts. This study will test the hypothesis that if students are taught about failures experienced by successful scientists or learn to troubleshoot experiments, they will be less discouraged when they experience difficulties or failures, and therefore more likely to persist in the biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The risk of a child developing Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) appears to be increased by exposure to particular viruses, but the nature, timing, and strength of such triggers remain ill-defined. By applying a sensitive new technology to study large cohorts sampled throughout childhood, we will catalog the timing and precise cause of 10,000s of virus infections, and determine which correlate with the development of T1D or associated autoimmunity. The resulting insights may enable new strategies to prevent T1D and the morbidity, reduced lifespan and large economic burden that it entails.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The inhibition of DNA replication initiation is a promising new strategy for cancer therapies, but more research is needed to fully understand mechanisms of replication initiation in metazoans. This project seeks to understand how higher eukaryotes load the replicative helicase Mcm2-7 onto DNA replication origins, and how this process is inhibited by small molecules. This study will provide a greater understanding of molecular mechanisms of DNA replication initiation in higher eukaryotes, which will identify new drug targets and assist in the development of improved DNA replication initiation inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Expression of mutant U2AF1(S34F), SF3B1(K700E), or SRSF2(P95H) alters RNA splicing in genetically-engineered mouse models and primary clinical samples, including increased production of nonsense transcripts that rely on nonsense–mediated RNA decay (NMD) for clearance. Our preliminary data suggest that spliceosome mutant cells are more sensitive to NMD inhibition than wild-type cells and the differential sensitivity is partially dependent on excessive R loop formation and DNA damage. Ongoing pre-clinical in vivo efficacy studies will test the potential for SMG1i to treat hematologic malignancies that have splicing factor mutations.

PHR: Craniofacial anomalies accounts for one-third of all congenital defects, and are primarily associated with defects in neural crest cells that give rise to most of the craniofacial bone and cartilage. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chromosomes must be equally segregated during cell division or else catastrophic events, such as spontaneous abortion, birth defects, and carcinogenesis, may occur. The chromosomal locus that ensures the equal segregation of chromosomes is the centromere. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the sequence, structure, and variation of human centromeres and to define their role in ensuring the equal segregation of chromosomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Candida-associated denture stomatitis (CADS) is a common, recurring disease that impacts the oral health and overall well-being of denture wearers, especially those who are older and/or immunologically/medically compromised. This project will use a layer-by-layer self-assembly technique to coat multiple layers of natural salivary anticandidal peptides/proteins onto denture materials, for long-term management of CADS, which will reduce drug toxicity and minimize the risk of Candida resistance. This technology also has potential application on next generation medical devices (e.g., catheters, endotracheal tubes) to decrease biofilm formation, infections, and provide a safer healthcare environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative More than 20,000 people in the United States are diagnosed with myeloproliferative neoplasms every year. Currently, we lack the tools to identify which patients will progress to acute leukemias and the only existing cure is allogeneic bone marrow transplant, a risky procedure that is feasible in only a small subset of the patients. Here, we propose a comprehensive research program to characterize individual cancer cells and reconstruct the history of disease progression in each patient, ultimately, identifying patient-specific targeted therapies that eradicate the cancer cells or hinder their growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE People living with dementia from racial-ethnic minoritized groups and socioeconomically disadvantaged environments are more likely to experience disparities in early diagnosis, treatment, quality of care, health outcomes, and access to end-of-life care. Our proposed project will use electronic health records data and machine learning algorithms to develop a personalized social risk management platform to improve the quality of care, well-being, and health equity among people living with dementia. Our long-term goal is to integrate social care into dementia clinical care, leading to a necessary paradigm shift in US health care delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease-Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) are common particularly in Black and low-income populations. New anti-amyloid medications have demonstrated efficacy, but also raise challenges including adverse events as well as diagnostic, monitoring, delivery, transportation, and financial burdens, which may be particularly problematic in vulnerable populations. In this project, we will determine the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of anti-amyloid medications in Black, low-income populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Within the United States’ opioid crisis, Black individuals face rapidly increasing rates of overdose death yet significant disparities in access to treatment. The current project will use geospatial technology to identify social determinants of health that underlie opioid overdose death among Black individuals. It will provide a model that can be replicated in localities across the country that face increasing racial inequities in opioid overdose death to guide culturally-relevant prevention and ultimately reduce opioid morbidity and mortality among Black Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Adeno-associated virus (AAV)-mediated gene therapy for inherited retinal dystrophies is finally a clinical reality. However, AAV therapies are expensive, limited by gene size, and randomly integrate in the host genome. This proposal hypothesizes that a combination of self-amplifying and self-circularizing mRNAs can increase mRNA stability, decrease immunogenicity, and provide proof-of-principle that mRNA is a viable gene therapy approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Sensitive Treponema pallidum genome recovery through tiling amplicon sequencing Genomic epidemiology is now a routine part of the public health response to pathogen outbreaks. Here, we propose to design and validate a tiling amplicon sequencing approach for complete genome recovery from Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis. Amplicon tiling approaches recently enabled the sequencing of >16 million SARS-CoV-2 genomes and we expect these methods will allow for more sensitive and rapid recovery of T. pallidum sequencing in laboratories across the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic parenchymal lung diseases including idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), other adult interstitial lung diseases (ILD) and bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) are among the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in the US and around the world, yet there is little in the way of disease-modifying therapies for these conditions. We hypothesize that disrupted cellular signaling leads to dysfunction of critical specialized cellular functions in the lung alveolus, leading to progressive lung pathology and declining lung function. In this LungMAP3.0 Research Center, we will use state-of-the-art spatial transcriptomic and single-cell multiomic approaches to investigate the mechanisms that underlie the initiation and progression of IPF, other ILDs and BPD and test therapies aimed at restoring alveolar homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Federated learning is a technique that allows researchers to build common machine learning models without sharing data. However, current implementations present challenges related to bias, data heterogeneity, data privacy, and interoperability among institutions. We propose new mathematical and algorithmic approaches to make federated learning a practical reality in biomedical research by developing domain- specific add-on algorithms that leverage techniques such as optimal transport and secure multiparty computation to overcome statistical and algorithmic bias and privacy concerns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Identifying modifiable factors that can improve nursing home resident outcomes after exposure to severe weather events is relevant to both public health and to the emerging priorities of the National Institute on Aging. By linking administrative compliance and health data with geospatial data classifying exposure to Hurricane Michael, the proposed research will quantify the relative importance of federal emergency preparedness standards to nursing home resident outcomes and empirically evaluate mechanisms (effect modification and mediation) by which compliance with these standards could affect post-disaster resident outcomes. The findings from the proposed work will elucidate opportunities for regulators and nursing home staff to intervene upon the factors that render residents most susceptible to adverse outcomes after severe weather events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Early adolescence is a high-risk time for deterioration of blood glucose levels in young people with type 1 diabetes (T1DM). This application will assess the feasibility, acceptability and preliminary effects of an intervention that incorporates the structured care of a pet fish into a family-based diabetes self-care routine combined with communication skills training on glycemic control, blood glucose monitoring frequency and blood glucose review in early adolescents with T1DM and elevated blood glucose levels. It is expected that the proposed study will provide information to guide a subsequent larger multi-site randomized clinical trial to evaluate efficacy of the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Millions of older adults receive care in intensive care units (ICUs) annually. However, because there are few evidence-based interventions designed to help ICU clinicians themselves provide primary palliative care to patients, we developed ICUconnect—a mobile app-based intervention for clinicians and family members—and found in a pilot trial that it reduced palliative care needs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In-hospital cardiac arrest is a significant public health concern, affecting approximately 292,000 Americans each year, with a survival rate to hospital discharge as low as 18.8%. Although Black patients exhibit a lower survival rate than White patients, the reasons for this health inequity remain unclear. This proposal aims to evaluate racial and ethnic differences in patient outcomes and intra- arrest care processes in order to identify specific areas that can be improved to mitigate the health inequity following in-hospital cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Internal targeted radionuclide therapy uses radioactive drugs to destroy tumors and can also be applied for imaging or diagnostic applications. From a therapeutic perspective, those that emit a specific form of radiation called alpha particles are highly effective and have been the subject of many promising clinical trials within recent years, but are generally not amenable for imaging. This project will develop new chemistry to enable the highly efficacious alpha-emitting drugs to be used in conjunction with identical radioactive imaging agents, leading to substantial improvements in patient treatment and diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narra�ve To advance the science of AD/ADRD risk, resilience, and disparities, the proposed Gateway Exposome Coordinating Center (GECC) will bring together experts and stakeholders to identify exposome research priorities, develop harmonized exposome measures based on those priorities, and establish guidance and best practices for their use. By engaging stakeholders and bringing together expertise across broad domains of exposures, including the climate, physical environment, social environment, policy environment, community services environment, and life experiences, the GECC will facilitate interdisciplinary research to achieve a better understanding of how different components of the exposome relate to each other and interact to influence AD/ADRD outcomes. Through an inclusive and transparent curation of exposome data for research, the GECC will lower the efforts required by individual researchers or stakeholders to capture diverse exposomes over the life course and make high-quality harmonized measures and guidance freely and publicly available, maximizing benefits to the AD/ADRD research community.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will combine large birth cohorts, state-of-the-art algorithms, and animal models to elucidate the intricate mechanisms through which breastfeeding and microbial colonization modulates childhood respiratory health outcomes years in advance. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory disease accounts for over $170 billion/year in health care costs in the United States, and globally chronic respiratory diseases are the 5th and 6th leading cause of death and disability. The URMC- BRINDL(NL) Human Tissue Core continues to be a cornerstone of the multi-center LungMAP effort to develop a multi-dimensional molecular, cellular, and structural atlas of normal, and entering into Phase III, diseased human lung from preterm birth through adulthood, in an ultimate effort to identify mechanisms, novel and more effective treatments, and prevention of lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to understand the role of CEBPA mutations in the pathobiology of acute myeloid leukemia. Specifically, we are studying how CEBPA mutations (AML) block differentiation of myeloid cells, to cause an accumulation of immature myeloid blasts characteristic of this deadly disease. Understanding how CEBPA mutations impair differentiation through alteration of chromatin architecture and activation of cellular signaling pathways will help create a mechanist foundation for the development of more efficacious therapies to treat patients with AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease-Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) often go undiagnosed or are diagnosed after substantial delays, leading to undertreatment and delays in care. This project will derive a novel AD/ADRD classification to accurately quantify AD/ADRD diagnostic errors and delays that disproportionately affect racial and ethnic minority groups and underserved populations, and to measure the impact on health care utilization and costs. The findings will inform health care policy and public health efforts to reduce disparities in diagnosis and care, improve health outcomes, and reduce avoidable health care costs for people living with dementia and their caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Obesity causes multiple complications including hypertension and sleep apnea, which contribute to high cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. In the parent grant, we have discovered a novel mechanism of these diseases related to signaling of leptin in the carotid body. In this supplement, we will test if an important component of the leptin pathway, melanocortin 4 receptor in the carotid body, is involved in the development of hypertension and sleep apnea in obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although neuroactive steroids (NAS) and the gamma-aminobutyric acid-A receptor (GABAAR) are thought to be involved in the serious affective disorder premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), comprehensive studies in humans are lacking. We propose to study the concentrations of GABAergic NAS and ratios of NAS to their precursors, expression of the rate-limiting neurosteroidogenic enzymes, and expression of GABAAR subunits across the luteal phase in controls and PMDD, and within PMDD among those who receive a low-dose selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) versus placebo. The results will provide a comprehensive view of the dynamic changes in these systems across the menstrual cycle and will add to our understanding of the mechanisms that underlie PMDD, as well as therapeutic mechanisms of the first-line PMDD treatment, low- dose SSRI.

The NASH Clinical Research Network (NASH CRN) will continue to conduct clinical and translational research that will advance our knowledge of the pathogenesis, natural history, management and outcomes of MASLD and MASH with a goal to improve the clinical care and treatment of patients with MASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 2016 CDC guidelines on opioid prescribing were intended to reduce the inappropriate use of opioids, but little is known about their unintended impact on legitimate opioid prescribing. Those who may have been unintentionally affected by these guidelines include diverse racial/ethnic minorities, the economically disadvantaged, and older adults with Alzheimer’s and related dementias (ADRD) who have a pain-associated condition, such as cancer or falls-related orthopedic fracture. This GEMSSTAR will identify the association of the 2016 CDC opioid guidelines with disparities in opioid-based pain management for either cancer or orthopedic fracture among three vulnerable subgroups of community-dwelling Medicare beneficiaries– those with ADRD, those experiencing poverty, and those identifying as racial/ethnic minoritized individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Culturally grounded mental health prevention interventions hold significant promise to reduce suicide among American Indian/Alaska Native (AI/AN) youth, a group at highest risk in the nation. However, there is little research to understand how core components included in these interventions impact mental health outcomes and promote resiliency against suicide. The proposed study with White Mountain Apache Tribe research partners will focus on an innovative, culturally grounded AI youth suicide prevention intervention, “The Elders’ Resilience Curriculum,” to: a) identify core components that impact protective factors against suicide; b) develop a youth resilience theoretical model; c) culturally adapt measures to assess outcomes; and d) pilot a culturally acceptable and rigorous evaluation to inform future research and scaling of this intervention to other AI/AN communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ribosomes are nanomachines responsible for all protein production within the cell, and different cell types contain different numbers of ribosomes. It is largely unknown how ribosome numbers are controlled in the cell types that make up the human blood system. We will re-analyze existing datasets to extract hidden information about ribosome production and numbers in human bone marrow, with the goal of gaining insight into the control of ribosome production in health and disease, and generating better therapies for marrow disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Polycystic ovary disease is a common disorder of reproductive-aged women and is associated with infertility and metabolic dysfunction. The contribution of polycystic ovary dysfunction to metabolic dysregulation is not fully defined, but may be driven by altered signaling by members of the transforming growth factor beta family (TGFβ), including anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH). Our goal is to use a novel SMAD variant discovered by the Rare and Atypical Diabetes Network (RADIANT) in a PCOS family to define how changes in SMAD signaling disrupts female fertility and promotes metabolic disease in non-reproductive tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our overarching goal is to understand how fibrotic lung diseases arise and how they progress and we will therefore collect samples from these patients and analyze the individual cells in the tissue in their locations and study how they interact with one another. We will also examine what each of the cells is secreting and how this could drive progression of fibrosis. Lastly, we will use our human 3D model of lung fibrosis to test specific ways in which cell interactions might drive fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: SUPPLEMENT SPECIFIC NARRATIVE Approximately 15 million people in the United States are at risk for developing cirrhosis, liver failure, hepatocellular carcinoma and death due to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), while there are less than 10,000 liver transplants performed annually in the United States. This Research Supplement adds to the training of the diverse biomedical workforce and, in doing so, will develop novel cell and bioengineering-based platforms to investigate the effect of matrix stiffness in NASH. Together, the improved understanding of these underlying mechanisms will aid in the development of new treatments for NASH and progressive liver fibrosis and dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although neuroactive steroids (NAS) and the gamma-aminobutyric acid-A receptor (GABAAR) are thought to be involved in the serious affective disorder premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), comprehensive studies in humans are lacking. We propose to study the concentrations of GABAergic NAS and ratios of NAS to their precursors, expression of the rate-limiting neurosteroidogenic enzymes, and expression of GABAAR subunits across the luteal phase in controls and PMDD, and within PMDD among those who receive a low-dose selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) versus placebo. The results will provide a comprehensive view of the dynamic changes in these systems across the menstrual cycle and will add to our understanding of the mechanisms that underlie PMDD, as well as therapeutic mechanisms of the first-line PMDD treatment, low-dose SSRI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term care industry is one of the fastest growing sectors of the economy, but also creates some of the lowest-paid and lowest-quality jobs. Precarious working conditions are costly for workers – who are disproportionately women and women of color – and the patients they care for, who have a high prevalence of AD/ADRD. This project will estimate the impact of three economic policy levers – wages, unionization, and staffing regulations – on improving the lives of the dementia care workforce and their patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE NHL is the most common hematologic malignancy, and there are many unmet clinical and public health needs of this growing patient population. The goal of the LEO infrastructure grant is to support a cohort of over 16,000 non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) patients in order to address broad and cutting-edge research that identifies clinical, epidemiologic (including lifestyle and other exposures), host genetic, tumor, and treatment factors, and the interaction among these factors, on short and long-term outcomes. The efforts of this Research Supplement are well aligned with the ultimate goal of identifying new approaches to improve the survival and well-being of NHL patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  To treat wounds that won’t heal for patients with Recessive Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa, we have developed induced pluripotent cell (iPS)-cell derived, scaleable induced skin composites (iSC) and find that TFAP2 and GRHL2-dependent regulate surface ectoderm signaling, with reciprocal GATA3-Gibbin dependent mesodermal signaling controlling surface ectoderm stratification and graftable iSCs. Using newly developed reagents, we will dissect the spatial and temporal TFAP2-GRHL2 driven early surface ectoderm commitment and elucidate the mechanism of Gibbin-dependent mesoderm regulation of epidermal stratification, with successful completion providing deep mechanistic insights into multi-lineage tissue differentiation, provide disease-relevant mechanistic insights into surface ectoderm- related developing tissues, and establish a detailed epigenetic characterization that enables development of our novel cell therapy for a previously untreatable genetic skin disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is a key risk factor for the development of cerebral small vessel disease, the foremost source of vascular cognitive impairment, the second most common cause of dementia after Alzheimer’s disease. Given the prevalence of hypertension rises from 46% of U.S. adults aged 20-44 to >78% of U.S. adults above the age of 65 and that hypertension incidence increases dramatically post-menopause in there is a critical public health need for a greater understanding of the mechanistic link(s) between sex, age-dependent hypertension and vascular cognitive impairment. Our collaborative research strategy, which is directly aligned with NIA Stratetgic Goals that address Alzheimer's disease and its related dementias, will define the sex dependent mechanistic sequelae of events and underlying neural dysfunction that is associated with age-dependent hypertension-driven vascular cognitive impairment and potentially identify new therapeutic targets and approaches for the treatment age-dependent hypertension-driven vascular cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Binge alcohol consumption poses a major public health burden in the U.S., leading to increased rates of mortality and other pathophysiologies, such as anxiety and depression. The proposed work will examine how repeated cycles of binge-like alcohol drinking dysregulate serotonin signaling in a discrete neural circuit, which may drive future binge alcohol intake and contribute to negative health outcomes. This may lead to the identification of more effective therapeutic strategies for the treatment of alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This study seeks to discover the reason why patients with long COVID suffer from persistent chest pain symptoms. Using advanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), this study will determine: (a) whether MRI accurately and precisely detects blockage in small blood vessels supplying oxygen to the heart in long COVID patients; (b) whether the said blockage is the cause of persistent chest pain symptoms in long COVID patients; (c) whether the said blockage resolves better with medicine. Our findings will inform future clinical trials aimed at preventing and/or reversing persistent chest pain caused by long COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The tremendous diversity across lung diseases is well acknowledged but coarsely defined. Leveraging recent advancements in single cell and spatial transcriptomic technologies, we will fulfill the mission of LungMAP phase III by conducting direct cross-disease comparisons at the single cell resolution. We expect that the datasets that we will generate and make publicly available will seed paradigm-shifting studies by the collective research community to uncover high resolution disease-specific mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement We will employ a mixed methods approach to evaluate potential paradigm-shifting approaches to xylazine testing and assessment of associations between xylazine exposure and skin and soft tissue infection rates while also assessing the context surrounding risks, outcomes, and willingness to be treated. Through multiple testing modalities and longitudinal assessments, our proposed study will provide an enhanced understanding of xylazine exposure over an extended timeframe and more precise measures of association with SSTIs. In addition, we will conduct qualitative interviews with people who have experienced SSTIs to better assess the context surrounding xylazine exposure, other risk factors, and SSTIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with advanced ovarian and uterine cancer experience severe functional decline from symptomatic burden. The choice of treatment and timing is predominantly age-based and dependent upon subjective assessments by surgeons, and the balance of over- and under-treatment in prolonging survival against the harms of aggressive surgery and chemotherapy may be better achieved through objective frailty assessments. This study proposes to utilize an existing research infrastructure to objectively assess physical frailty and deeply characterize its quantitative associations with treatment side effects, functional recovery, and quality of life to ultimately improve the ability of our field to assess these risks and make treatment decisions that align with outcomes important to older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The formation of a new memory requires a rapid increase in the synthesis of messenger RNAs via the process of gene transcription in the brain, and many of the molecular processes underlying gene transcription regulation are disrupted in cognitive disorders. Rapidly inducible gene transcription requires a set of factors that regulate a poised, ready for activation, state within the nucleus, but how this poise is established has not been investigated in neurons. This project will examine the molecular players that regulate the poised state before, during, and after neuronal stimulation to understand whether they influence the capacity of the brain to form memories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The type IV collagens are fundamental basement membranes components. They are encoded by 6 genes (COL4A1-COL4A6) that form three heterotrimers – a1a1a2(IV), a3a4a5(IV), and a5a5a6(IV). Mutations in five of the six genes cause life threatening nephropathies. We will develop novel genetic tools enabling unprecedented ability to study their deposition, turnover, and biochemical properties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Maui wildfires of 2023 had devastating consequences, exacerbating pre-existing health and socioeconomic disparities among the island's diverse residents. Our research endeavors to comprehensively examine the multifaceted impacts of this disaster, collecting both social and biological data. This study aims to guide informed recovery strategies, highlight health implications, and emphasize the need for resilience planning in the face of potential future calamities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To fuel malignant proliferation, cancer cells require a continuous supply of metabolic building blocks, and yet some tumors arise following genetic disruption of critical metabolic pathways, including the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle. How tumors cope with impaired TCA cycle activity—and whether the pathways that compensate for TCA cycle disruption can be targeted—remains largely unknown. The goal of this proposal is to test the hypothesis that ATP citrate lyase (ACL) activity compensates for impaired TCA cycle function in renal cell carcinoma and to determine whether targeting alternative metabolic pathways provides a novel strategy to treat a subset of tumors with defective TCA cycle function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Common chronic pain syndromes, such as fibromyalgia and temporomandibular disorder, constitute one of our nation’s most significant healthcare problems, yet are ineffectively treated because the underlying molecular mechanisms remain largely unknown. We hypothesize that these conditions are driven by catecholamine activation of beta-adrenergic receptor 3 and subsequent dysregulation in microRNA 374 which regulates the expression of genes important for pain and inflammation. Therefore, this proposal applies diverse methodologies in a clinically-relevant animal model in order to (1) define the relationship between beta-3 adrenergic receptor activation, microRNA 374, and complimentary mRNA expression with regards to cell type and sex, and (2) test the hypothesis that altered levels of miRNA 374 in mice directly contributes to pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Because elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) and IOP fluctuations are the primary risk factors for loss of visual field in glaucoma, the current standard of care for adult-onset glaucoma includes treatment with IOP-lowering medications that are typically delivered topically as eye drops because of their ease of use and the ability for a patient to receive treatment from the comfort of their home. The requirement for multiple daily dosings along with associated eye irritation in addition to orbital and systemic side effects noted in available medications, collectively contribute to the low patient adherence documented by many eye care specialists. To directly address this unmet clinical need to increase patient adherence, within these SBIR Phase 1 studies, we will optimize and evaluate the IOP-lowering properties and safety of a subconjunctival biodegradable electrospun depot containing PRG.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Multiple myeloma constitutes 12-13% of hematologic malignancies in the US and is a significant problem in our aging veteran population, especially those exposed to Agent Orange. Nearly half of patients with myeloma have an associated kidney dysfunction and at least one large study found that reversibility of renal function was a more important prognostic factor than response to chemotherapy. The present application proposes to address gaps in knowledge in defining the role of immunoglobulin free light chains in the progression of kidney injury. The specific focus will be on the interaction of free light chains with the proximal tubule and the generation of kidney fibrosis in the setting of multiple myeloma. !

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This bench-to-bedside pilot study evaluates the safety of a novel medical technology, LANT (Laser-Activated NanoTherapy), for treating a type of skin cancer called cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC). Veterans have a high risk for this type of skin cancer due to extensive exposures during the line of duty to the sun and chemical warfare agents like Agent Blue and Lewisite. This project is of significant interest because Veterans with difficult-to-treat cancer facing poor clinical outcomes could greatly benefit from LANT. This new cancer treatment may address the unmet need for a local and minimally invasive alternative to radiation when surgery is not a viable option.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Patients with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) exhibit co-morbid alcohol use disorder (AUD) at far greater rates than the general population, but we have no effective therapies for these diseases when they present simultaneously. In Veteran populations the relationship between AUD and PTSD is even more prevalent as 63% of Veterans diagnosed with AUD are co-diagnosed with PTSD. Fibroblast growth factor 21 (FGF21) is a secreted endocrine molecule that signals to the brain to decrease alcohol consumption and genetic variation in genes encoding FGF21 and its receptor, β-klotho, are associated with increased alcohol consumption in humans. More recently we have observed that FGF21 also increases fear memory following chronic alcohol consumption in mice and propose to investigate how FGF21 signaling in the brain influences both alcohol consumption and fear to provide new therapeutic targets to treat Veterans suffering from both PTSD and AUD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to Veteran health because it focuses on innovative ways to electronically measure frailty and multimorbidity in older Veterans with multiple myeloma using data from the integrated national VA health system. This work will lead to tools for VA oncologists to identify age-related vulnerabilities that can inform decision making regarding intensity and type of initial treatment for myeloma. Moreover, these electronic measures will allow VA investigators to study the safety and effectiveness of current and future myeloma treatment regimens as they are applied to older Veterans with frailty and multimorbidity. The proposed research seeks to combine geriatric measures with cancer-specific measures toward better individualizing care for older Veterans, intersecting the missions of the VA Geriatrics Research Education and Clinical Centers (GRECC) and the National VA Precision Oncology Program.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Integration of Geriatric Measures Alongside Disease-Based Measures to Advance Precision Oncology for Older Veterans with Multiple Myeloma

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Mutational processes that underlie human cancer leave mutational signatures identifiable by whole genome sequencing. Precision Oncology aims to target these underlying mutational processes. Seminal work by the Sanger Institute has identified mutational patterns, including single and doublet base pair substitutions, indels, and copy number alterations, and structural variants, that are indicative of defects in DNA replication and repair, mutagen exposures, and enzymatic modification of DNA. These mutational signatures could be prognostic or predictive. Determining if these mutational signatures predict treatment response in Veterans could provide expanded therapeutic indications for larger numbers of Veterans. At a fundamental level, whether the mutational signatures identified in civilian tumors are found in tumors from United States Veterans and whether novel signatures might develop due to war-time exposures is unknown. Identification of these novel mutational signatures may reveal new therapeutic targets and inform preventative measures to reduce exposure risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Cell adhesion structures called desmosomes provide tissues with mechanical stability and coordinate many aspects of cell function. Disruption of desmosomes leads to blistering diseases of the skin and cardiomyopathies. Our work will increase our understanding of how desmosomes organize the cell and localize and control translational pathways. These studies are expected to yield novel insights into how desmosomes and skin respond to both wounding and autoimmune blistering diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative This Cycle 2 renewal proposal directly addresses the public health concerns regarding health equity for underserved and vulnerable populations such as rural children and adolescents with serious illness. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Negative affective disturbances, including stress, anxiety, and depression, are characteristic of alcohol abstinence, and a leading cause of relapse. A greater understanding of the complex neural circuitry regulating the disease state will lead to better diagnostic tools and treatment options for abstinence-induced negative affect. This project will investigate the functional state of the insular cortex-bed nucleus of the stria terminalis neural pathway in alcohol abstinence, two regions implicated in alcohol use disorders and negative affect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the dramatic health inequities faced by sexual and gender minority (SGM) individuals, there are a dearth of training opportunities focused on SGM health in general, and especially in the Deep South. AdvanceSGM is committed to training the next generation of diverse researchers in the risks and resiliencies of SGM populations and providing them with the skills needed to address SGM health inequities. Over 5 years, we will train 15 predoctoral students in both the didactic and experiential skills needed to lead a successful research career in SGM health.
PROJECT_TERMS: Health;Research
PROJECT_TITLE: ADVANCE SGM Health for Research Diversity

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative New drugs for Alzheimer's and related dementias (ADRD) show potential value, but their optimal use remains uncertain due to risks and modest efficacy. Traditional value assessment methods do not fully capture the diverse user-experiences; therefore, we will survey diverse older Americans to elicit their preferences and risk attitudes towards new ADRD medications to inform an innovative microsimulation model. This model will help us to better understand the value of new ADRD medications and help ensure equitable use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Glioblastoma is a very aggressive tumor of the Central Nervous System that responds poorly to conventional treatments and develops resistance to chemo- and radiotherapy. In this project we will investigate a novel mechanism that contributes to tumor cell survival and resistance to radiation; we will also develop novel agents to disrupt this mechanism and make glioblastoma more sensitive to radiotherapy. Our research will identify effective strategies to weaken the tumor, contributing to more effective treatments for patients with malignant brain cancers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Teens with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) have high rates of negative driving outcomes, including motor vehicle crashes, which may be caused by visual inattention (i.e., looking away from the roadway to perform secondary tasks). A driver training program that effectively trains teens to reduce instances of looking away from the roadway and reduces crash rates will be converted to an immersive virtual reality platform in order to increase adoption and implementation. The relative effectiveness and cost effectiveness of the immersive virtual reality version of the driver training will be assessed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this secondary data analysis proposal, we will address critical and timely questions about effects of social inequality on the brain and on substance use. We leverage existing datasets from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study and the Minnesota Center for Twin and Family Research (MCTFR) to identify neurobehavioral deviations linking childhood socioeconomic disadvantage and substance use trajectories in adolescence and adulthood. Identifying individuals and families at the greatest risk for problematic substance use trajectories informs development of the most targeted prevention and intervention efforts possible for substance misuse and use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep is known to relate to general health but the effect of abnormal sleep on cardiac aging is yet to be fully determined. This proposal will take advantage of the longitudinal measure of sleep pathology in the Korean Genome and Epidemiology Study, a well-characterized cohort, and assess its impact on cardiac aging over one decade. The outlined strategy will identify novel digital sleep biomarkers and provide new avenues for future intervention to reduce the burden of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is a significant problem in care partners of people living with dementia; despite the expansion of options for accessing evidence-based treatments, most care partners of people living with dementia are not screened for depression and do not receive treatment. The objective of this project is to identify a screening method for depression that is feasible and acceptable to care partners and to adapt an innovative pathway to online evidence-based treatment for depression (iPath*D) as a means of increasing mental health literacy, screening rates and treatment access for care partners of people living with dementia. The results are expected to have a major positive impact by providing proof-of-principle for the use of an online pathway to evidence based treatment with the potential for reaching an unprecedented number of care partners who have unmet mental health needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain induced by aromatase inhibitor therapy is a common and debilitating symptom impacting breast cancer survivors. The Enhanced Pain Coping in Cancer (EPIC) trial investigates a novel, scalable, neuroscience-based, non-pharmacological virtual intervention with potential to change the paradigm of pain clinical care for millions of breast cancer survivors with aromatase inhibitor-associated arthralgia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a devastating illness with high mortality. Most studies have investigated inflammation in ARDS, although many people are prone to immune suppression with impaired ability to fight infections. We have discovered a new model that may explain immune suppression in ARDS that led us to propose characterizing a protein that restores immune function and discovered a compound that preserves immune function. This discovery fulfills an unmet need in this critical illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Ewing Sarcoma (ES) is an aggressive tumor often leading to the death of children and adolescents, particularly when it spreads to distant bones. Unfortunately, bone metastases are also difficult to study, due to the lack of clinical samples and problems with reproducing their formation in animal models. Thus, the goal of our project is to test the utility of a bioengineered device that mimics the conditions that ES cells encounter during bone metastasis for studies aiming at identifying key drivers of this process that can become targets for novel therapies tailored for patients with bone metastases; an approach that can be later adapted to other cancers.

PHR: Project Narrative: The overall objective of this study is to determine whether the application of a targeted resistance torque to the knee joint during overground walking will induce improvements in crouch gait in children with CP. Results from this study are expected to demonstrate the effect of error size and error variability on the motor learning of improved crouch gait in children with CP, which is likely to provide a strong scientific foundation whereby new intervention strategies can be developed to improve crouch gait in children with CP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory neurons use small antenna-like structures called cilia to detect and transmit external cues, and damage to these structures due to genetic or environmental causes leads to multiple disorders including loss of smell, vision, and hearing. We will use the nematode C. elegans as an experimental system in which to explore how cilia in neurons regenerate following injury in the adult, and identify the required molecules. Since cilia are formed by remarkably similar mechanisms across species, we expect that findings from this work will be broadly translatable to other organisms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NIH Common Fund initiated Metabolomics Workbench – National Metabolomics Data Repository is a unique resource that provides houses and provides metabolomics data for the biomedical research community and serves as a one-stop-shop for metabolomics research. Given its unique status and its service as an invaluable resource for biomedical research, there is an imperative need for its continued maintenance and enhancement. This proposal deals with its continued maintenance with additional improvements and enhancements in the form of new query capabilities, additional discoverability through filtering with human subjects’ metadata, and making the data available on the cloud through extant and AI-ready formats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is considered the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and patients with TNBC exhibit a poor prognosis, despite current treatment regimens. Although the reasons for such poor survival outcomes remain incompletely understood, it has become clear that non-cancerous cell types within the tumor microenvironment (TME) are integral players in disease progression and resistance to diverse oncologic therapies. Here, we seek to decipher a novel biology of a previously identified oncogene known as TAZ in TNBC progression, a biology that governs the mobilization of pro-tumorigenic myeloid populations to the TME and one that also provides opportunities for novel biomarker or therapeutic target discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although it is the most common systemic rheumatic disease in older adults, polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) remains critically understudied. PMR is associated with persistent symptoms which also lead to prolonged use of glucocorticoids. Frailty in PMR identifies a group of patients with worse symptoms, and risk for prolonged treatment. Further understanding of the prevalence and impact of frailty can lead to the development of interventions such as physical and occupational therapy that can improve function and decrease pain, cardinal symptoms of PMR. This study proposes to utilize claims data to better understand these associations and inform the creation of future interventions to improve the care of older adults with PMR.

PHR: NARRATIVE Non-typhoidal Salmonella infects the gastrointestinal tract and is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. We aim to integrate multiomics approaches to elucidate new mechanisms of competition between Salmonella and the gut microbiota. Our long-term goal is to develop new prebiotics and probiotics to limit Salmonella infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Black and Latinx adults bear a disproportionate share of the burden of disease from asthma but attempts at reducing this disparity have mostly been unsuccessful partly due to an insufficiently understood relationship with social determinants of health (SDOH). Our group demonstrated in a large pragmatic clinical trial (the PREPARE study) that a ‘Patient-Activated, Reliever-Triggered Inhaled CorticoSteroid’ (‘PARTICS’) strategy added to usual care successfully reduced asthma attacks in 1,201 Black and Latinx adults with moderate-severe asthma relative to usual care, and in doing so created a rich dataset of demographic, clinical, and phenotypic data, now enhanced with geocoding data available from participants’ zip codes—a wealth of data on two racial and ethnic groups for whom there is few clinical research studies available. We now have an opportunity with the richness of our dataset to identify unique sets of SDOH characteristics for Black and Latinx adults that may lead to high-yield interventions, plus facilitate our work implementing the PARTICS strategy, both of which may reduce morbidity in these two highly impacted populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The utero-placental circulations are specifically designed to regulate the flow of blood and transport of essential nutrients to the fetus; this coordinated exchange is highly susceptible to disruption from environmental exposure, which can result in miscarriage and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). Unfortunately, the vascular and endothelial-dependent mechanisms by which utero-placental blood flow is reduced in IUGR are unknown, resulting in few treatment options beyond preterm delivery. We will use our model of environmentally-inducible IUGR to reveal novel mechanisms of altered hemodynamic molecular signaling that contribute to the development of IUGR as well as test nutritional interventions to mitigate IUGR severity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative The development of therapeutic RNAi which reduces expression of both normal and mutant alleles is not appropriate in many cases for dominantly inherited disorders. As such, there is a dire need to develop mutant-specific RNAi as a therapeutic treatment for such diseases. Here, we will execute the comprehensive development of a novel approach for the allele-specific knockdown for mutations in the TARDBP and KIF5A genes which are causative for ALS/FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Common acquired or congenital airway abnormalities in children, such as subglottic stenosis (SGS), Robin sequence (PRS), and tracheobronchomalacia, are typically assessed using semi-quantitative measures. Normative data can be used to establish quantitative measures of airway abnormality, but existing normative models do not fully assess airway geometry as they only consider airway cross-sectional area. This project will therefore develop a pediatric airway shape atlas to better capture 3D airway geometry and will explore its utility for predicting airway development and to assess airway abnormalities in children with subglottic stenosis and Robin sequence.

PHR: Project Narrative The Northwestern genetics-enabled learning health system (Northwestern gLHS) brings together a team of investigators with expertise in learning health systems, implementation science, and cardiovascular and cancer genetics. We will design, implement, and continuously refine strategies and resources to enhance equitable genetic medicine among diverse populations. We propose 3 projects on cascade genetic testing (CGT) for hereditary conditions within cardiovascular disease and cancer as our use case to address different aspects of a primary barrier in CGT, overreliance on probands to transmit the importance of CGT to family members.
